context:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / NSAIDS (Non-Steroidal 
Anti-Inflammatory Drug) / Cephalosporins
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain and blood per-rectum
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
flexible sigmoidoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ hx sarcoidosis, CAD, HTN and COPD p/w crampy abdominal
pain and BRBPR starting ~1200 noon day of presentation. 
Initially
one episode of soft dark stools, then ___ episodes BRBPR, last 
in
ED. Reports nausea without emesis.  Last colonoscopy ___ years
prior with report of 'benign polyps', no history of
diverticulosis or GIB, no history of atrial fibrillation.  WBC
18.5, hematocrit 42.7, lactate 2.9, CTAP with mural colonic
thickening in ___ distribution, patent ___ with significant but
non-flow limiting calcified atherosclerotic disease at the ___
take-off with patent ___ and normal colonic mucosa enhancement.

At time of consultation, pt AFVSS with obscured abdominal exam 
in
setting of significant pannus and recent narcotic 
administration.
 
Past Medical History:
sarcoidosis, CAD, COPD, HTN

PSH: TAH 

ALL: Sulfa
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
CAD. Denies CRC, IBD.  Mother: lung CA, Father: lung CA
 
Physical Exam:
VS: T 97.8, HR 87, BP 115/98, RR 18, SaO2 99%rm air
GEN: NAD, A/Ox3
HEENT: MMM
CV: regular
PULM: CTAB
BACK: No CVAT
ABD: obese, dull tenderness elicited in LUQ on deep palpation, 
no
rebound or guarding. [unreliable exam in setting of recent
narcotic administration]. 
PELVIS: DRE - nl tone, no stool, blood on tip of examination
glove
EXT: warm
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 08:00PM BLOOD WBC-18.5* RBC-4.83 Hgb-13.3 Hct-42.7 
MCV-88 MCH-27.5 MCHC-31.1* RDW-13.7 RDWSD-44.1 Plt ___
___ 08:00PM BLOOD Neuts-85.5* Lymphs-9.3* Monos-4.2* 
Eos-0.0* Baso-0.4 Im ___ AbsNeut-15.79* AbsLymp-1.71 
AbsMono-0.77 AbsEos-0.00* AbsBaso-0.07
___ 08:00PM BLOOD Glucose-116* UreaN-25* Creat-0.8 Na-137 
K-4.2 Cl-98 HCO3-27 AnGap-16
___ 09:26PM BLOOD Lactate-2.9*
___ 04:06AM BLOOD Lactate-1.6
___ 06:02AM BLOOD WBC-23.3* RBC-3.60* Hgb-10.1* Hct-32.9* 
MCV-91 MCH-28.1 MCHC-30.7* RDW-14.2 RDWSD-47.8* Plt ___
___ 07:55AM BLOOD WBC-17.3* RBC-4.26 Hgb-11.6 Hct-38.7 
MCV-91 MCH-27.2 MCHC-30.0* RDW-14.2 RDWSD-47.3* Plt ___
___ 05:50AM BLOOD Glucose-84 UreaN-11 Creat-0.7 Na-142 
K-4.1 Cl-106 HCO3-29 AnGap-11
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to Emergency Department on ___. Pt was 
evaluated by upon arrival to ED.  Given findings and concern for 
acute ischemia, the patient was taken for CT of abdomen and 
pelvis which demonstrated "Marked wall thickening of distal 
transverse colon and descending colon with adjacent fat 
stranding consistent with
colitis. No free air or free fluid in abdomen or pelvis. No 
fluid
collections." The patient was then transferred to the ward for 
observation, colonoscopy, serial abdominal exams, empiric 
antibiotics (Zosyn).
 
Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout 
hospitalization; optimal pain control was ultimately achieved 
with oral vicodin which patient takes at home. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO. On HD2 patient 
received bowel prep and went of flexible sigmoidoscopy with 
biopsy by gastroenterology.  Findings werw patchy
erythema and scattered ulcers considered not classic for 
ischemic colitis. Biopsies confirmed mild ischemic colitis with 
chronic changes. Lact and WBC downtrended from 2.9--> 1.6 and 
18-->16, respectively and the patient's symptoms gradually 
improved. Diet was advanced sequentially to a Regular diet, 
which was well tolerated on HD 3. Patient's intake and output 
were closely monitored.
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none. Stool was sent for cultures 
and O&P which resulted negative, no campylobacter, salmonella, 
shigella, or e. coli O157:H7. CMV PCR, BCx and UCx also were 
negative.
HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs 
of bleeding. The patient continued to have small amounts of 
bloody BMs through HD2. Her H&H remained stable thereafter.
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and ___ 
dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.  Patient was discharged with 
PO augmentin and instructions to follow-up in ___ clinic.

 
Medications on Admission:
ASA 81, Lipitor, Atenolol, Albuterol, Symbicort, Enalipril,
Verapamil, APAP
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Amoxicillin-Clavulanic Acid ___ mg PO Q8H Duration: 14 Days 
Please stop taking medication and call your doctor or 911 if you 
have hives or difficulty breathing. 
RX *amoxicillin-pot clavulanate 500 mg-125 mg 1 tablet(s) by 
mouth every eight (8) hours Disp #*42 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Atenolol 50 mg PO DAILY 
3. Atorvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
Do not take if you are having diarrhea 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0
5. Enalapril Maleate 5 mg PO DAILY 
6. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 
7. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q8H pain 
please do not take if you are sedated or breathing less than 8 
times per minute 
RX *hydrocodone-acetaminophen 5 mg-325 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth 
every eight (8) hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0
8. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
Do not take if you are having diarrhea 
RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 capsule by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0
9. Tiotropium Bromide 1 CAP IH DAILY 
10. Topiramate (Topamax) 50 mg PO BID 
11. Verapamil 120 mg PO Q8H 
12. TraMADOL (Ultram) 25 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
please do not take if you are sedated or breathing less than 8 
times per minute 
RX *tramadol 50 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
fulminant segmental colitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent flexible sigmoidoscopy and treatment with antibiotics. 
You are recovering well and are now ready for discharge. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

The patient presented to Emergency Department on ___. Pt was

standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.

received bowel prep and went of flexible sigmoidoscopy with 
biopsy by gastroenterology.  Findings werw patchy
erythema and scattered ulcers considered not classic for 
ischemic colitis. Biopsies confirmed mild ischemic colitis with 
chronic changes. Lact and WBC downtrended from 2.9--> 1.6 and

improved. Diet was advanced sequentially to a Regular diet, 
which was well tolerated on HD 3. Patient's intake and output 
were closely monitored.

infection, of which there were none. Stool was sent for cultures 
and O&P which resulted negative, no campylobacter, salmonella, 
shigella, or e. coli O157:H7. CMV PCR, BCx and UCx also were 
negative.

of bleeding. The patient continued to have small amounts of 
bloody BMs through HD2. Her H&H remained stable thereafter.

dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.

___ YOM PMHx ankylosing spondylitis c/b subsequent 
steroid-induced DM, paroxysmal afib (not on warfarin), and 
gastroparesis who presented with emesis and back pain x 12 hours 
admitted to ICU for sepsis. 

Per patient, he was feeling well until this AM, when he had ___ 
episodes of "spitting up" associated with significant episodes 
of dry heaving. He reports these symptoms were consistent with 
his typical gastroparesis symptoms. In addition, patient reports 
he has had a cough, although this is chronic for him. He reports 
his wife has been sick with a cough but she is getting better. 
He denies fever/chills, abdominal pain, hematemesis, diarrhea, 
melena, hematochezia, dysuria. 

In the ED, initial vitals: 101.1, ___, 18, reportedly 
in mid-80s on RA (not recorded per ED signout)
- Exam notable for: ill appearing, diaphoretic man. Lung exam 
c/f diffuse wheeze/rhonchi. Abdominal exam was benign.
- Labs were notable for: 
23.8>12.1/37.3<451
Lactate 2.5 -> Lactate 1.1
Normal LFTs, lipase
U/A with (+) ketones
VBG pH 7.54 pCO2 28 pO2 123 HCO3 25 
- While in the ED patient triggered for SBPs 82/52 and worsening 
hypoxia requiring 5L NC. He received 1L IVF, stress-dose 
steroids, and was initiated on broad-spectrum abx 
(vanc/cefepime/flagyl) with improvement in SBPs to 100s.
- Imaging was notable for:
CXR (___): IMPRESSION: Mild basal atelectasis. Otherwise 
unremarkable. 
CT A/P (___):
1. Bilateral lower lobe pneumonia. Enlarged mediastinal lymph 
node is likely reactive.
2. Re- demonstration of multifocal ground-glass opacities which 
may represent a component of multifocal pneumonia, though the 
distribution appears somewhat similar to the prior examination 
and may represent drug reaction.
3. No acute aortic abnormality or pulmonary embolus.
4. New, subtle 3.9 x 2.6 cm hypoattenuating lesion in hepatic 
segment IV B.
5. Bony sequela of ankylosing spondylitis, as above. Stable 
vertebral body compression deformities, as above. Gadolinium 
enhanced MR is recommended for further evaluation of a new 
hepatic lesion.

- Patient received:
Dilaudid, Tylenol 
Cefepime, vancomycin, Flagyl 
100mg IV hydrocortisone
3L IVF with NS
Nebulizer treatments
- VS prior to transfer: 98.5, 95, 118/79, 16, 94% Nasal Cannula 

On arrival to the MICU, patient reports severe pain in his lower 
back and shoulders because he has not gotten his normal pain 
medications. He reports he has been unable to keep anything 
down.

Of note, patient was discharged on ___ for gastroparesis; his 
symptoms of nausea and vomiting were controlled with 
Ativan/Zofran and he was tolerating PO well prior to discharge. 

ROS: 10-point ROS negative except as noted above in HPI

___ (EGD suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis)
Esophageal ulcerations seen on EGD ___, H.pylori negative
Hyperlipidemia
Psoriasis
GERD
Anxiety
Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation noted on multiple admissions in 
setting of vomiting (previously on Pradaxa, changes to aspirin 
___ for c/f esophageal tear/bleeing ___ recurrent retching)

s/p lumbar laminectomy ___
s/p spondylolisthesis surgery ___
s/p right inguinal hernia repair in ___, now with right 
hydrocele

congestion and mild cardiomegaly persists but mediastinal veins

___ Echocardiogram
Very limited image quality. The left atrium is normal in size. 
Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size, and global 
systolic function are normal (LVEF = 70%). Due to suboptimal 
technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be 
fully excluded. Tissue Doppler imaging suggests a normal left 
ventricular filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). Right ventricular 
chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The ascending 
aorta is mildly dilated. The number of aortic valve leaflets 
cannot be determined. The aortic valve is not well seen. There 
is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. 
The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) 
mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure could not be determined. The pulmonary artery is not 
well visualized. There is a small pericardial effusion. There 
are no echocardiographic signs of tamponade.
Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___ the 
findings are grossly similar, but the technically suboptimal 
nature of both studies precludes definitive comparison.

IMPRESSION:
In comparison to chest radiograph of ___, multifocal 
poorly defined pulmonary opacities have progressed in the 
interval including an ill-defined opacity in the left juxta 
hilar region and poorly defined nodular opacities in the right 
upper and mid lungs.  Left basilar atelectasis has improved.  No 
pleural effusion.

___ M PMHx ankylosing spondylitis c/b subsequent 
steroid-induced DM, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (not on 
warfarin), and gastroparesis who presented with emesis and back 
pain x 12 hours admitted to ICU for sepsis and acute hypoxemic 
respiratory failure, found bilateral pulmonary embolism and 
multi-focal pneumonia

ACTIVE ISSUES: 
==================================
# SEPSIS
# Multi-focal pneumonia
Patient presented with CT scan that was concerning for 
pneumonia. Since he was in the hospital 1.5 months ago, he was 
put on antibiotics for HCAP vs aspiration PNA due to recent 
multiple episodes of nausea/vomiting. Atypical PNA was also 
considered given the multifocal nature of PNA on CT scan. He 
received Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl and Levaquin, and was given 
boluses of IV fluids. Blood cultures, urine legionella antigen 
and urine strep pneumonia antigen were all NEGATIVE. . Patient 
had persistent fevers while on medicine floor. Given 
immunocompromised state on prednisone and infliximab, pulmonary 
was consulted but did not suggest bronchoscopy as pt's symptoms 
and fevers improved shortly after Pulmonary consultation.  
Patient's antibiotics were narrowed to levofloxacin only and he 
completed 7 days of antibiotics after his last fever on ___.

# PULMONARY EMBOLISM:
CT scan of chest on admission showed bilateral sub segmental 
PEs.  Patient was previously on dabigatran which was held given 
his severe gastroparesis with retching due to bleeding risk in 
patient with low CHADS-2. After discussion with outpatient 
providers it was decided to start the patient on warfarin 
instead of a NOAC, as he has history of recurrent vomiting, with 
increased risk for UGIB.  This is his ___ time VTE and appears 
unprovoked.  We recommend 3 months minimum of anticoagulation.  
He will need thrombophillia work-up and routine cancer 
screening.  He had an echocardiogram that did NOT show any 
evidence of right heart strain.  He is being referred to the 
___ (multi-disciplinary pulmonary ___ clinic) and 
has follow up scheduled in Hematology. INR on discharge 2.3

# DELIRIUM
# Altered mental status
Patient was noted to have waxing and waning mental status, 
consistent with delirium.  Unclear trigger for his delirium.  
Head CT without bleed.  No new medications.  No evidence of new 
infection.  No significant
metabolic derangement.  He was treated with a few dose of PRN 
Zyprexa. He was seen by occupational therapy and was found to 
have significant improvement in mental status. His mental status 
was back to baseline prior to discharge.

# FALL:
While admitted the patient had an unwitnessed mechanical fall 
while anticoagulated. Patient was on telemetry when he tripped 
and no cardiac events occurred during that time. The patient 
initially refused CT scans of head and neck and was able to 
verbalize and communicate the risk of intracranial hemorrhage 
including death. Patient's neurologic exam remained stable 
throughout his hospitalization.  He ultimately had a CT Head 
that did NOT show any bleed.

# NAUSEA/VOMITING DUE TO GASTROPARESIS:
Patient had extensive history of nausea/vomiting flares 
occurring 5x/year for the past ___ years. He has had extensive 
prior workup, including EGD, tryptase, C1-esterase, small bowel 
follow through (SBFT); all were negative. He also had tried many 
medications before this (amitriptyline, fexofenadine, 
erythromycin), which all failed. On admission, he was unable to 
tolerate PO due to gastroparesis. IV Zofran & Ativan were 
continued. ___ 2.5mg BID were continued.  He was seen by 
Swallow and SLP did not feel a video swallow or dietary 
modifications needed.

# ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS: 
Continued prednisome 5mg BID and calcium carbonate 500mg BID 
with qmonthly Remicade injections. On admission, patient had 
severe pain, so was started on IV dilaudid as needed. He was 
converted to PO Dilaudid 2mg BID, which is reportedly a home 
medication for him, prescribed by an outpatient MD. 

# AFIB: 
CHADS-2 score 2 (DM2, HTN), takes ASA 325mg at home. Was 
continued initially on home aspirin and diltiazem 240mg daily. 
While in the hospital, his home metoprolol succinate 100mg daily 
was fractionated to metoprolol tartrate 25mg q6 hours.  His ASA 
was reduced to 81mg once he was started on systemic 
anticoagulation for acute PE, as noted above.

___ M PMHx ankylosing spondylitis c/b subsequent 
steroid-induced DM, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (not on 
warfarin), and gastroparesis who presented with emesis and back 
pain x 12 hours admitted to ICU for sepsis and acute hypoxemic 
respiratory failure, found bilateral pulmonary embolism and 
multi-focal pneumonia

ACTIVE ISSUES: 
==================================
# SEPSIS
# Multi-focal pneumonia
Patient presented with CT scan that was concerning for 
pneumonia. Since he was in the hospital 1.5 months ago, he was 
put on antibiotics for HCAP vs aspiration PNA due to recent 
multiple episodes of nausea/vomiting. Atypical PNA was also 
considered given the multifocal nature of PNA on CT scan. He 
received Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl and Levaquin, and was given 
boluses of IV fluids. Blood cultures, urine legionella antigen 
and urine strep pneumonia antigen were all NEGATIVE. . Patient 
had persistent fevers while on medicine floor. Given 
immunocompromised state on prednisone and infliximab, pulmonary 
was consulted but did not suggest bronchoscopy as pt's symptoms 
and fevers improved shortly after Pulmonary consultation.  
Patient's antibiotics were narrowed to levofloxacin only and he 
completed 7 days of antibiotics after his last fever on ___.

# PULMONARY EMBOLISM:
CT scan of chest on admission showed bilateral sub segmental 
PEs.  Patient was previously on dabigatran which was held given 
his severe gastroparesis with retching due to bleeding risk in 
patient with low CHADS-2. After discussion with outpatient 
providers it was decided to start the patient on warfarin 
instead of a NOAC, as he has history of recurrent vomiting, with 
increased risk for UGIB.  This is his ___ time VTE and appears 
unprovoked.  We recommend 3 months minimum of anticoagulation.  
He will need thrombophillia work-up and routine cancer 
screening.  He had an echocardiogram that did NOT show any 
evidence of right heart strain.  He is being referred to the 
___ (multi-disciplinary pulmonary ___ clinic) and 
has follow up scheduled in Hematology. INR on discharge 2.3

# DELIRIUM
# Altered mental status
Patient was noted to have waxing and waning mental status, 
consistent with delirium.  Unclear trigger for his delirium.  
Head CT without bleed.  No new medications.  No evidence of new 
infection.  No significant
metabolic derangement.  He was treated with a few dose of PRN 
Zyprexa. He was seen by occupational therapy and was found to 
have significant improvement in mental status. His mental status 
was back to baseline prior to discharge.

# FALL:
While admitted the patient had an unwitnessed mechanical fall 
while anticoagulated. Patient was on telemetry when he tripped 
and no cardiac events occurred during that time. The patient 
initially refused CT scans of head and neck and was able to 
verbalize and communicate the risk of intracranial hemorrhage 
including death. Patient's neurologic exam remained stable 
throughout his hospitalization.  He ultimately had a CT Head 
that did NOT show any bleed.

# NAUSEA/VOMITING DUE TO GASTROPARESIS:
Patient had extensive history of nausea/vomiting flares 
occurring 5x/year for the past ___ years. He has had extensive 
prior workup, including EGD, tryptase, C1-esterase, small bowel 
follow through (SBFT); all were negative. He also had tried many 
medications before this (amitriptyline, fexofenadine, 
erythromycin), which all failed. On admission, he was unable to 
tolerate PO due to gastroparesis. IV Zofran & Ativan were 
continued. ___ 2.5mg BID were continued.  He was seen by 
Swallow and SLP did not feel a video swallow or dietary 
modifications needed.

# ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS: 
Continued prednisome 5mg BID and calcium carbonate 500mg BID 
with qmonthly Remicade injections. On admission, patient had 
severe pain, so was started on IV dilaudid as needed. He was 
converted to PO Dilaudid 2mg BID, which is reportedly a home 
medication for him, prescribed by an outpatient MD. 

# AFIB: 
CHADS-2 score 2 (DM2, HTN), takes ASA 325mg at home. Was 
continued initially on home aspirin and diltiazem 240mg daily. 
While in the hospital, his home metoprolol succinate 100mg daily 
was fractionated to metoprolol tartrate 25mg q6 hours.  His ASA 
was reduced to 81mg once he was started on systemic 
anticoagulation for acute PE, as noted above.

CHRONIC STABLE ISSUES:
=====================================
# T2DM - Reportedly steroid-induced. last A1C was 7.7 in ___
Continued home Lantus, albeit at reduced dose given acute 
illness.  Mealtime blood sugar managed with SSI.

# GERD: Continued home omeprazole, ranitidine 
 
# Depression/Anxiety: Continued home Fluoxetine 40 mg PO daily;  


# Hyperlipidemia/CAD: Continued aspirin (reduced to 81mg now 
that he is on systemic anticoagulation with VKA) and pravastatin 
40 mg PO QHS.  TTE this admission to eval for right heart strain 
shows preserved EF, no focal wall motion abnormality.

CTA Torso
3.  INR monitoring and Coumadin dosing to be titrated, please 
check IN Rom ___. Goal INR ___.  f/u for PE with Hematology  Will need thrombophilia work-up, 
up-to-date cancer screening and consider Hematology referral for 
w/u of unprovoked PE.

==================================
___ M PMHx ankylosing spondylitis c/b subsequent 
steroid-induced DM, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (not on 
warfarin), and gastroparesis who presented with emesis and back 
pain x 12 hours admitted to ICU for sepsis and acute hypoxemic 
respiratory failure, found bilateral pulmonary embolism and 
multi-focal pneumonia

ACTIVE ISSUES: 
==================================
# SEPSIS
# Multi-focal pneumonia
Patient presented with CT scan that was concerning for 
pneumonia. Since he was in the hospital 1.5 months ago, he was 
put on antibiotics for HCAP vs aspiration PNA due to recent 
multiple episodes of nausea/vomiting. Atypical PNA was also 
considered given the multifocal nature of PNA on CT scan. He 
received Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl and Levaquin, and was given 
boluses of IV fluids. Blood cultures, urine legionella antigen 
and urine strep pneumonia antigen were all NEGATIVE. . Patient 
had persistent fevers while on medicine floor. Given 
immunocompromised state on prednisone and infliximab, pulmonary 
was consulted but did not suggest bronchoscopy as pt's symptoms 
and fevers improved shortly after Pulmonary consultation.  
Patient's antibiotics were narrowed to levofloxacin only and he 
completed 7 days of antibiotics after his last fever on ___.

# PULMONARY EMBOLISM:
CT scan of chest on admission showed bilateral sub segmental 
PEs.  Patient was previously on dabigatran which was held given 
his severe gastroparesis with retching due to bleeding risk in 
patient with low CHADS-2. After discussion with outpatient 
providers it was decided to start the patient on warfarin 
instead of a NOAC, as he has history of recurrent vomiting, with 
increased risk for UGIB.  This is his ___ time VTE and appears 
unprovoked.  We recommend 3 months minimum of anticoagulation.  
He will need thrombophillia work-up and routine cancer 
screening.  He had an echocardiogram that did NOT show any 
evidence of right heart strain.  He is being referred to the 
___ (multi-disciplinary pulmonary ___ clinic) and 
has follow up scheduled in Hematology. INR on discharge 2.3

# DELIRIUM
# Altered mental status
Patient was noted to have waxing and waning mental status, 
consistent with delirium.  Unclear trigger for his delirium.  
Head CT without bleed.  No new medications.  No evidence of new 
infection.  No significant
metabolic derangement.  He was treated with a few dose of PRN 
Zyprexa. He was seen by occupational therapy and was found to 
have significant improvement in mental status. His mental status 
was back to baseline prior to discharge.

# FALL:
While admitted the patient had an unwitnessed mechanical fall 
while anticoagulated. Patient was on telemetry when he tripped 
and no cardiac events occurred during that time. The patient 
initially refused CT scans of head and neck and was able to 
verbalize and communicate the risk of intracranial hemorrhage 
including death. Patient's neurologic exam remained stable 
throughout his hospitalization.  He ultimately had a CT Head 
that did NOT show any bleed.

# NAUSEA/VOMITING DUE TO GASTROPARESIS:
Patient had extensive history of nausea/vomiting flares 
occurring 5x/year for the past ___ years. He has had extensive 
prior workup, including EGD, tryptase, C1-esterase, small bowel 
follow through (SBFT); all were negative. He also had tried many 
medications before this (amitriptyline, fexofenadine, 
erythromycin), which all failed. On admission, he was unable to 
tolerate PO due to gastroparesis. IV Zofran & Ativan were 
continued. ___ 2.5mg BID were continued.  He was seen by 
Swallow and SLP did not feel a video swallow or dietary 
modifications needed.

# ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS: 
Continued prednisome 5mg BID and calcium carbonate 500mg BID 
with qmonthly Remicade injections. On admission, patient had 
severe pain, so was started on IV dilaudid as needed. He was 
converted to PO Dilaudid 2mg BID, which is reportedly a home 
medication for him, prescribed by an outpatient MD. 

# AFIB: 
CHADS-2 score 2 (DM2, HTN), takes ASA 325mg at home. Was 
continued initially on home aspirin and diltiazem 240mg daily. 
While in the hospital, his home metoprolol succinate 100mg daily 
was fractionated to metoprolol tartrate 25mg q6 hours.  His ASA 
was reduced to 81mg once he was started on systemic 
anticoagulation for acute PE, as noted above.

# Depression/Anxiety: Continued home Fluoxetine 40 mg PO daily;  


# Hyperlipidemia/CAD: Continued aspirin (reduced to 81mg now

and had no signs of increased intracranial pressure suggesting

to be progression of disease versus new intraspinal masses for 
example affecting the spinocerebellar tract however there is no

showed stable disease. Also could consider paraneoplastic 
syndromes. Spinal MRI, lumber, thoracic and cervical, without 
lesion to explain examination findings. He was discharged with

agressive insulin regimen. Continued this while inpatient per 
patient request.  Discharged home on prior regimen of Lantus and 
Humalog sliding scale.

(4) Hypertension: Patient taking Lisinopril 10mg at home. Blood 
pressure here 90-100 systolic. Thus, his Lisinopril was 
decreased to 5 mg daily but was kept at low dose for renal 
protection given diabetes.

(5) Chronic Pain: Continued narcotics and gabapentin.

(6) Hyperlipidemia:  Continued Atorvastatin.

(7) Right Shoulder Pain: Per patient, is chronic for several 
months. He cannot use his shoulder at baseline. Unclear if 
frozen shoulder vs torn rotator cuff but is followed by outside 
Orthopedist for this issue.  Have deferred further treatment to 
this physician on an as needed basis.

the presacral space and bowel wall thickening at the level of 
the rectum are concerning for stercoral colitis. There is no

CT Head w/o Contrast ___
IMPRESSION: No acute intracranial process.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman with dementia, DMII, HTN, CVA x2 (on plavix 
and coumadin), and CRI who was transferred from ___ 
___ yesterday for concern of sepsis ___ cholangitis.

# Septic Shock
She underwent a CT abdomen/pelvis, which revealed extensive 
fecal loading but no evidence of biliary pathology. She was 
admitted to the MICU given her hypotension (SBP 70-80s). Stool 
disimpaction was performed aggressively multiple times with 
retrieval of a large amount of stool, which was trace guaiac 
positive. However, despite this, her lactate continued to trend 
up (from 3.7 to 5.8) and she remained hypotensive despite 
generous fluid resuscitation. She had received 4L prior to her 
MICU admission and received a further 3L while in the ICU but 
was still requiring levophed. She received empiric vanc/zosyn, 
as well as IV flagyl for coverage of c diff empirically. The ACS 
service was consulted for consideration of ischemic colitis as 
potential source of rising lactate and persistent hypotension. 
Her exam was concerning for abdominal distension and apparent 
discomfort with abdominal palpation, and CT was suggestive of 
possible ischemic colitis related to massive dilaion of bowel 
with stool. They thought her sepsis was likely due to a urinary 
source rather than ischemic bowel, and did not think surgical 
intervention was indicated. Overnight, her lactate continued 
trend up with increasing pressor requirements. Urine and blood 
cultures remained negative. Her family decided to make her CMO 
and she expired shortly after.

# Septic Shock
She underwent a CT abdomen/pelvis, which revealed extensive 
fecal loading but no evidence of biliary pathology. She was 
admitted to the MICU given her hypotension (SBP 70-80s). Stool 
disimpaction was performed aggressively multiple times with 
retrieval of a large amount of stool, which was trace guaiac 
positive. However, despite this, her lactate continued to trend 
up (from 3.7 to 5.8) and she remained hypotensive despite 
generous fluid resuscitation. She had received 4L prior to her 
MICU admission and received a further 3L while in the ICU but 
was still requiring levophed. She received empiric vanc/zosyn, 
as well as IV flagyl for coverage of c diff empirically. The ACS 
service was consulted for consideration of ischemic colitis as 
potential source of rising lactate and persistent hypotension. 
Her exam was concerning for abdominal distension and apparent 
discomfort with abdominal palpation, and CT was suggestive of 
possible ischemic colitis related to massive dilaion of bowel 
with stool. They thought her sepsis was likely due to a urinary 
source rather than ischemic bowel, and did not think surgical 
intervention was indicated. Overnight, her lactate continued 
trend up with increasing pressor requirements. Urine and blood 
cultures remained negative. Her family decided to make her CMO 
and she expired shortly after.

Ms. ___ is a ___ yo female with long-standing Type I

discontinuation of her home insulin (patient out-wardedly

positive urine ketones initially in the ED.  She was managed 
with normal saline and subcutaneous insulin; electrolyte 
abnormalities quickly improved and she did not require an

patient while in-house and recommended changes to her sliding 
scale. Her acid-base status stabilized rapidly and she was 
medically cleared for discharge.

where she does not take her insulin as instructed in order to 
loose weight.  She was followed by the psychiatry consult 
service while in-house, who recommended placement in a treatment 
facility and no further changes to her medications.  She was 
continued on seroquel 50mg qhs, clonopin 0.5mg TID, Zoloft 100mg 
qAM, BusPar 15mg TID and prn Xanax 1mg.

# Acute renal failure on Chronic Kidney disease:
Baseline creatinine in the ___ range with episodes of 
elevation to 3.0.  The patient was given IV fluids with 
improvement in her creatinine to 2.6. The patient was seen by 
nephrology who discussed with the patient's outpatient 
nephrologist. SPEP was sent and showed only 
hypogammaglobulinemia. The patient likely has underlying CKD 
with changes in her renal function related to volume status. She 
was advised to continue to measure her urine output and to have 
repeat urine studies as an outpatient. 

# Diarrhea: To date has been attributed to small bowel resection 
and SIBO. Longstanding, refractory to supportive outpatient 
care, based on rising Cr appears unable to maintain adequate 
intake even with frequent IVF boluses via port. The patient was 
followed by gastroenterology. Stool studies were checked which 
were negative. She had a ttG which was normal. Upper GI series 
with small bowel follow through showed rapid movement of barium 
into the small bowel confirming short gut syndrome. The 
patient's diarrhea improved during her hospitalization. She was 
advised to take creon- open the capusles 15 minutes before 
meals. She was also advised to cook with MCT oil and to use 
liquid loperamide to help control her diarrhea as an outpatient. 
She will follow up with Dr. ___ discharge.

# Anemia: Normocytic with normal RDW, confirmed on repeat check. 
Supports diagnosis of progressive CKD. H/H was stable throughtou 
hospitalization. 

# Nonanion gap metabolic acidosis: In  setting of chronic 
diarrhea, on sodium bicarb supplementation at home which was 
continued.

#Thyroid studies
Patient noted to have THS of 9.8 with T4 of 3.7 and T3 of 70. 
Advised to discuss these results with her PCP or endocrinologist

# Neuropathy:
- Continue home neuropathy

# Mild Alzheimer's disease:
- Continue home donepezil - recently started
- Continue home folic acid

care, based on rising Cr appears unable to maintain adequate 
intake even with frequent IVF boluses via port. The patient was 
followed by gastroenterology. Stool studies were checked which 
were negative. She had a ttG which was normal. Upper GI series 
with small bowel follow through showed rapid movement of barium 
into the small bowel confirming short gut syndrome. The 
patient's diarrhea improved during her hospitalization. She was 
advised to take creon- open the capusles 15 minutes before 
meals. She was also advised to cook with MCT oil and to use 
liquid loperamide to help control her diarrhea as an outpatient. 
She will follow up with Dr. ___ discharge.

# Anemia: Normocytic with normal RDW, confirmed on repeat check. 
Supports diagnosis of progressive CKD. H/H was stable throughtou 
hospitalization. 

# Nonanion gap metabolic acidosis: In  setting of chronic 
diarrhea, on sodium bicarb supplementation at home which was 
continued.

#Thyroid studies
Patient noted to have THS of 9.8 with T4 of 3.7 and T3 of 70. 
Advised to discuss these results with her PCP or endocrinologist

# Neuropathy:
- Continue home neuropathy

# Mild Alzheimer's disease:
- Continue home donepezil - recently started
- Continue home folic acid

since her gastric bypass operation, who presented to ___ 
___ yesterday with abdominal pain and vomiting. The pain 
started yesterday suddenly in her LLQ, and was cramping in 
nature. She had associated bilious, non-bloody emesis. No 
fevers, with some associated chills. She has had a decreased 
appetite for months. An NGT was placed, and she was kept NPO and 
placed on IVF. A CT abdomen/pelvis showed jejunal 
intussusception at the level of her distal anastomosis (also 
seen on CTs on ___ and ___, cholelithiasis unchanged from 
prior CTs, and she was transferred to ___ for surgical 
consultation for her intussusception. Her last BM was this 
morning, which she noted to have some associated dry blood, 
which is her baseline (she has stool only 1x week ___ her UC).
.
Of note, she presented with similar symptoms last week to ___ 
___, where a CT abdomen/pelvis similary showed 
intussesception at her distal anastamosis. No surgical consult 
was obtained at that time, and her abdominal pain and nausea 
improved with IVF and prn zofran.  A gastroscopy from ___ 
showed normal gastric bypass anatomy with normal and widely 
patent anastomosis, normal efferent limb and normal appearing 
mucosa. Colonoscopy from the same date showed minimal reactive

___b/pelvis with po/iv contrast:
CT ABDOMEN AND PELVIS:
There is extensive postsurgical change in the upper abdomen as 
before. Lapsed displaced bowel is now demonstrated in the left 
upper quadrant most suggestive of jejunal intussusception at the 
level of the distal anastomosis.  Nasogastric tube is in place 
as before.  Bowel contrast does not pass below the level of the 
distal anastomosis.  Gallstones are again noted in the dependent 
portion of the gallbladder. The liver, pancreas, spleen, adrenal 
glands and kidneys are unremarkable as demonstrated previously.  
No lymphadenopathy is apparent. A large left pelvic adnexal cyst 
that appears to contain at least one septation, is unchanged.  
This measures 7.4 cm in greatest dimension in transverse 
section. In addition, there is now a smaller right pelvic 
adnexal cyst that measures approximately 1.7 cm in diameter. No 
free fluid is apparent.
IMPRESSION:
1) USUAL POSTSURGICAL FINDINGS IN THE LEFT UPPER QUADRANT ARE
REDEMONSTRATED.  ON THE CURRENT STUDY, FINDINGS ARE MOST
SUGGESTIVE OF INTUSSUSCEPTION IN THE REGION OF A JEJUNOJEJUNAL
ANASTOMOSIS.       
2) CHOLELITHIASIS.
.
___b/pelvis with po/iv contrast:
CT ABDOMEN AND PELVIS:
There is extensive postsurgical change in the upper abdomen as 
before. Findings are consistent with gastric bypass procedure. 
There are suture lines across the body of the stomach and in the 
left upper quadrant between two loops of small bowel.  A viscus 
consistent with a segregated portion of the stomach in this 
region is indented by a second loop of bowel which is contiguous 
with the second suture line and inverted. There are multiple 
gallstones in the dependent portion of the gallbladder as 
before. The liver, pancreas, spleen, adrenal glands and kidneys 
are unremarkable.  No lymphadenopathy is apparent. There is a 
large left pelvic adnexal cyst as demonstrated earlier. This now 
measures 7.5 cm x 5.8 cm in greatest dimension in transverse 
section, probably unchanged. There is evidence for septation 
along the medial aspect of this lesion.  Pelvic structures are 
otherwise unremarkable.  No free fluid is noted. IMPRESSION:
1) UNUSUAL POSTSURGICAL FINDINGS IN THE LEFT UPPER QUADRANT. 
ALTHOUGH A SHORT JEJUNO-JEJUNAL INTUSSUSCEPTION IS POSSIBLE, THE
APPEARANCE IS MORE SUGGESTIVE OF A TWISTED OR COMPRESSED SHORT
LOOP OF SMALL BOWEL AT THE SURGICAL SITE (seen also in ___
CT). 
.
___ OSH gastroscopy:
PROCEDURE:
After informed consent was obtained, video gastroscope was 
advanced through the mouth, esophagus, gastric pouch and into 
the efferent limb of bowel. A careful inspection was made upon 
withdrawal of the scope including careful views of the 
anastomosis.  FINDINGS: The patient has normal gastric bypass 
anatomy with normal and widely patent anastomosis, normal 
efferent limb and normal mucosa.  Esophagus is normal. 
IMPRESSION: Normal post bypass gastroscopy.
.
___ OSH Colonoscopy:
FINDINGS: There was faint erythema and faint loss of vascular 
pattern in the rectum and distal sigmoid consistent with very 
mildly active ulcerative proctosigmoiditis.  The remainder of 
the exam is normal with the  exception of a very slight patchy 
erythema in various colonic segments throughout the colon.  
IMPRESSION: Minimal reactive proctosigmoiditis with likely 
minimal more proximal histologic involvement.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ ___ s/p Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in ___ at ___ 
___, presented to ___ for 
surgical consultation after she was seen at ___ with 
nausea/vomiting/abdominal pain found to have evidence of 
intussesception at her jejunojejunostomy anastamosis site (see 
report above). At ___ a nasogastric tube was placed, 
and labs were all unremarkable, with a normal lactate. She was 
made NPO and IVF were begun. On arrival to ___ ED, her 
abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting had improved, and on exam 
she had a non-acute abdomen. She had a bowel movement the 
morning of admission, and was passing flatus. Given her 
non-actue abdomen without clinical signs of obstruction, the 
decision was made not to go to the operating room for treatment 
of her radiologic intussesception. She was admitted overnight 
and received a "banana bag," IVF, with NGT left in overnight. 
Nutrition labs were sent and were all normal, with thiamine 
pending on discharge. NGT was removed on HD2. The patient was 
given the option to follow up at ___ for 
potential future revision of her bypass, or at ___. She 
elected to follow up at the ___ Bariatric Surgery 
program for ongoing management, and was given the necessary 
enrollment forms on discharge. Of note, she did present with a 
depressed mood and frustrated with her nausea/abdominal pain for 
the past ___ years since her bypass: she was evaluated by the 
Psychiatry service, who determined she has major depressive 
disorder, and recommended she begin Remeron 7.5 mg qhs. She will 
follow up with her PCP to manage her Remeron dosage. She was 
also instructed to coordiante with her PCP and insurance company 
arrangement for an outpatient psychiatrist and therapist. On 
discharge her abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting had all 
improved. She was discharged on a regular diet which she was 
tolerating.   
 
Medications on Admission:

Intussussception
Major Depressive Disorder

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and 
nausea.  You were treated with intravenous fluids, intravenous 
fluids containing thiamine, folic acid and vitamin B12 and 
antiemetics.  Your symptoms have improved and you were able to 
tolerate a regular diet.  You are now preparing for discharge to 
home with the following instructions: 
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.
Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

CT ABDOMEN AND PELVIS:
There is extensive postsurgical change in the upper abdomen as 
before. Lapsed displaced bowel is now demonstrated in the left 
upper quadrant most suggestive of jejunal intussusception at the 
level of the distal anastomosis.  Nasogastric tube is in place 
as before.  Bowel contrast does not pass below the level of the 
distal anastomosis.  Gallstones are again noted in the dependent 
portion of the gallbladder. The liver, pancreas, spleen, adrenal 
glands and kidneys are unremarkable as demonstrated previously.  
No lymphadenopathy is apparent. A large left pelvic adnexal cyst 
that appears to contain at least one septation, is unchanged.  
This measures 7.4 cm in greatest dimension in transverse 
section. In addition, there is now a smaller right pelvic 
adnexal cyst that measures approximately 1.7 cm in diameter. No 
free fluid is apparent.
IMPRESSION:
1) USUAL POSTSURGICAL FINDINGS IN THE LEFT UPPER QUADRANT ARE
REDEMONSTRATED.  ON THE CURRENT STUDY, FINDINGS ARE MOST
SUGGESTIVE OF INTUSSUSCEPTION IN THE REGION OF A JEJUNOJEJUNAL
ANASTOMOSIS.       
2) CHOLELITHIASIS.
.
___b/pelvis with po/iv contrast:
CT ABDOMEN AND PELVIS:
There is extensive postsurgical change in the upper abdomen as 
before. Findings are consistent with gastric bypass procedure. 
There are suture lines across the body of the stomach and in the 
left upper quadrant between two loops of small bowel.  A viscus 
consistent with a segregated portion of the stomach in this 
region is indented by a second loop of bowel which is contiguous 
with the second suture line and inverted. There are multiple 
gallstones in the dependent portion of the gallbladder as 
before. The liver, pancreas, spleen, adrenal glands and kidneys 
are unremarkable.  No lymphadenopathy is apparent. There is a 
large left pelvic adnexal cyst as demonstrated earlier. This now 
measures 7.5 cm x 5.8 cm in greatest dimension in transverse 
section, probably unchanged. There is evidence for septation 
along the medial aspect of this lesion.  Pelvic structures are 
otherwise unremarkable.  No free fluid is noted. IMPRESSION:
1) UNUSUAL POSTSURGICAL FINDINGS IN THE LEFT UPPER QUADRANT. 
ALTHOUGH A SHORT JEJUNO-JEJUNAL INTUSSUSCEPTION IS POSSIBLE, THE
APPEARANCE IS MORE SUGGESTIVE OF A TWISTED OR COMPRESSED SHORT
LOOP OF SMALL BOWEL AT THE SURGICAL SITE (seen also in ___
CT). 
.
___ OSH gastroscopy:
PROCEDURE:
After informed consent was obtained, video gastroscope was 
advanced through the mouth, esophagus, gastric pouch and into 
the efferent limb of bowel. A careful inspection was made upon 
withdrawal of the scope including careful views of the 
anastomosis.  FINDINGS: The patient has normal gastric bypass 
anatomy with normal and widely patent anastomosis, normal 
efferent limb and normal mucosa.  Esophagus is normal. 
IMPRESSION: Normal post bypass gastroscopy.
.
___ OSH Colonoscopy:
FINDINGS: There was faint erythema and faint loss of vascular 
pattern in the rectum and distal sigmoid consistent with very 
mildly active ulcerative proctosigmoiditis.  The remainder of 
the exam is normal with the  exception of a very slight patchy 
erythema in various colonic segments throughout the colon.  
IMPRESSION: Minimal reactive proctosigmoiditis with likely 
minimal more proximal histologic involvement.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ ___ s/p Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in ___ at ___ 
___, presented to ___ for 
surgical consultation after she was seen at ___ with 
nausea/vomiting/abdominal pain found to have evidence of 
intussesception at her jejunojejunostomy anastamosis site (see 
report above). At ___ a nasogastric tube was placed, 
and labs were all unremarkable, with a normal lactate. She was 
made NPO and IVF were begun. On arrival to ___ ED, her 
abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting had improved, and on exam 
she had a non-acute abdomen. She had a bowel movement the 
morning of admission, and was passing flatus. Given her 
non-actue abdomen without clinical signs of obstruction, the 
decision was made not to go to the operating room for treatment 
of her radiologic intussesception. She was admitted overnight 
and received a "banana bag," IVF, with NGT left in overnight. 
Nutrition labs were sent and were all normal, with thiamine 
pending on discharge. NGT was removed on HD2. The patient was 
given the option to follow up at ___ for 
potential future revision of her bypass, or at ___. She 
elected to follow up at the ___ Bariatric Surgery 
program for ongoing management, and was given the necessary 
enrollment forms on discharge. Of note, she did present with a 
depressed mood and frustrated with her nausea/abdominal pain for 
the past ___ years since her bypass: she was evaluated by the 
Psychiatry service, who determined she has major depressive 
disorder, and recommended she begin Remeron 7.5 mg qhs. She will 
follow up with her PCP to manage her Remeron dosage. She was 
also instructed to coordiante with her PCP and insurance company 
arrangement for an outpatient psychiatrist and therapist. On 
discharge her abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting had all 
improved. She was discharged on a regular diet which she was 
tolerating.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ ___ s/p Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in ___ at ___

intussesception at her jejunojejunostomy anastamosis site (see 
report above). At ___ a nasogastric tube was placed, 
and labs were all unremarkable, with a normal lactate. She was 
made NPO and IVF were begun. On arrival to ___ ED, her 
abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting had improved, and on exam 
she had a non-acute abdomen. She had a bowel movement the 
morning of admission, and was passing flatus. Given her 
non-actue abdomen without clinical signs of obstruction, the 
decision was made not to go to the operating room for treatment 
of her radiologic intussesception. She was admitted overnight 
and received a "banana bag," IVF, with NGT left in overnight. 
Nutrition labs were sent and were all normal, with thiamine 
pending on discharge. NGT was removed on HD2. The patient was 
given the option to follow up at ___ for 
potential future revision of her bypass, or at ___. She 
elected to follow up at the ___ Bariatric Surgery 
program for ongoing management, and was given the necessary 
enrollment forms on discharge. Of note, she did present with a 
depressed mood and frustrated with her nausea/abdominal pain for 
the past ___ years since her bypass: she was evaluated by the 
Psychiatry service, who determined she has major depressive 
disorder, and recommended she begin Remeron 7.5 mg qhs. She will 
follow up with her PCP to manage her Remeron dosage. She was 
also instructed to coordiante with her PCP and insurance company 
arrangement for an outpatient psychiatrist and therapist. On 
discharge her abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting had all 
improved. She was discharged on a regular diet which she was 
tolerating.

right sided heart failure with right heart catheterization and

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms ___,

It was our pleasure to care for you at ___.

You were admitted for a right heart catheterization and to 
anticoagulate you on a heparin drip while your INR was less than 
2.5.  

We found on right heart catheterization that the difficulty 
breathing is likely due your mitral valve leaking a little bit 
of from your left ventricle and into your lungs.  We confirmed 
on transesophageal echo that you had 2+ mitral regurgitation 
(leaking), which is consistent with what we had seen earlier on 
previous echos.  We will manage this medically, with a higher 
dose of torsemide (50mg daily, which you were taking) and with 
lower doses of your other blood pressure medications to allow 
you a chance to diurese without your blood pressure decreasing 
too much.

We made the following changes to your medications.
Please DECREASE metoprolol XL to 100mg daily
Please STOP taking Enalapril
Please START Lisinopril 5mg
Please CONTINUE torsemide 50mg daily, like you were taking.

Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.

outpatient transthroacic echocardiogram. Right heart

significan mitral regurgitation, along with mean PCW 25 mm Hg,

pressures in the 80-90s systolic range, which was asymptomatic, 
however, in an effort to diurese the patient and reduce her

restrictions.

medications.

CT head ___
IMPRESSIONS: 
1. Large right intraparenchymal hemorrhage centered in the right 
basal 
ganglia, unchanged in size from the prior study, with new 
intraventricular 
extension. Stable 2 cm of subfalcine leftward herniation and

CT head ___
IMPRESSION: Overall increase in size of the large right 
parenchymal 
hemorrhage, now 7 x 5.9 cm, with increased leftward shift of 
midline 
structures, now 2.8 cm, and worsening uncal herniation with new 
compression 
and leftward deviation of the midbrain. Increased size of the 
occipital horn 
and atrium of the left lateral ventricle concerning for 
"trapping" of this 
ventricle. New left hemispheric subarachnoid and unchanged 
intraventricular 
hemorrhage. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with history of AF, HTN, 
hyperlipidemia, and s/p
an old left MCA infarct with residual aphasia and mild right 
sided weakness.  He was found confused, then suddenly collapsed 
per his wife earlier today.  He was taken to ___ 
___, where head CT showed an ICH. He was intubated, loaded 
with phosphenytoin & treated with vitamin K for presumed 
coagulopathy; then transferred to ___ for surgical management 
of his ICH.
.
Upon transfer from the outside hospital, the patient was 
initially evaluated by the neurosurgery service in regards to a 
possible right temporoparietal craniotomy.  In lengthy 
discussion with the neurosurgery service and neurology service, 
the family decided against surgical intervention as they did not 
want the patient to suffer.  
.
The neurology service was asked to see him urgently by 
Neurosurgery to assist with ICH management and to render our 
opinion regarding the futility of surgical intervention.  At 
time of examination, the patient had no spontaneous movement and 
did not respond to voice.  He had a mild gag reflex. Pupils were 
small ~ 1 to 1.5 mm but reactive.  Eyes were midline.  He had 
corneals bilaterally.  Doll's eye was not elicited.  He moved 
the right side to pain & nasal stimulation. He postures on the 
left in response to pain.  Toes were upgoing. Overall, his GCS 
was 4.  Head CT showed a large right parenchymal ICH with IVH 
and extension into the brainstem, midline shift of ~ 22mm, and 
ventricular dilatation in addition to an old left
temporo-parietal infarct. 
.
Overall, the cause of his ICH was difficult to ascertain.  It is 
likely hypertensive, but one cannot entirely rule out a 
secondary cause.  Regardless, his prognosis appeared grim. His 
ICH score was 4, indicating a 30-day mortality of ~ 97%.  
Multiple members of the neurology and neurosurgery service had 
lengthy discussions with multiple family members regarding his 
condition, expected prognosis, and treatment options.  His 
chances for any meaningful recovery, if he survives, are 
minimal.  While surgery could be life-saving, it is unlikely to 
improve his functional outcome. They decided on a DNR status, 
but wanted to
discuss the surgical option with Dr. ___ further.  They 
were initially inclined to proceed with surgery, but later 
reversed their decision.
.
The patient was admitted to the NSICU for medical management.  A 
repeat CT head several hours after arrival revealed worsening 
hemorrhage with midline shift and uncal herniation.  Social work 
consult was requested to help the family cope with the difficult 
situation and after further discussions, the patient was 
ultimately made CMO.  He was pronoucned dead at ___ at 6:20 
AM.
.

 

 
Medications on Admission:
coumadin, lisinopril & simvastatin.
 
Discharge Medications:
none

Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
intraparenchymal hemorrhage
 
Discharge Condition:
expired
 
Discharge Instructions:
expired

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with history of AF, HTN, 
hyperlipidemia, and s/p
an old left MCA infarct with residual aphasia and mild right 
sided weakness.  He was found confused, then suddenly collapsed 
per his wife earlier today.  He was taken to ___ 
___, where head CT showed an ICH. He was intubated, loaded 
with phosphenytoin & treated with vitamin K for presumed 
coagulopathy; then transferred to ___ for surgical management 
of his ICH.
.
Upon transfer from the outside hospital, the patient was 
initially evaluated by the neurosurgery service in regards to a 
possible right temporoparietal craniotomy.  In lengthy 
discussion with the neurosurgery service and neurology service, 
the family decided against surgical intervention as they did not 
want the patient to suffer.  
.
The neurology service was asked to see him urgently by 
Neurosurgery to assist with ICH management and to render our 
opinion regarding the futility of surgical intervention.  At 
time of examination, the patient had no spontaneous movement and 
did not respond to voice.  He had a mild gag reflex. Pupils were 
small ~ 1 to 1.5 mm but reactive.  Eyes were midline.  He had 
corneals bilaterally.  Doll's eye was not elicited.  He moved 
the right side to pain & nasal stimulation. He postures on the 
left in response to pain.  Toes were upgoing. Overall, his GCS 
was 4.  Head CT showed a large right parenchymal ICH with IVH 
and extension into the brainstem, midline shift of ~ 22mm, and 
ventricular dilatation in addition to an old left
temporo-parietal infarct. 
.
Overall, the cause of his ICH was difficult to ascertain.  It is 
likely hypertensive, but one cannot entirely rule out a 
secondary cause.  Regardless, his prognosis appeared grim. His 
ICH score was 4, indicating a 30-day mortality of ~ 97%.  
Multiple members of the neurology and neurosurgery service had 
lengthy discussions with multiple family members regarding his 
condition, expected prognosis, and treatment options.  His 
chances for any meaningful recovery, if he survives, are 
minimal.  While surgery could be life-saving, it is unlikely to 
improve his functional outcome. They decided on a DNR status, 
but wanted to
discuss the surgical option with Dr. ___ further.  They 
were initially inclined to proceed with surgery, but later 
reversed their decision.
.
The patient was admitted to the NSICU for medical management.  A 
repeat CT head several hours after arrival revealed worsening 
hemorrhage with midline shift and uncal herniation.  Social work 
consult was requested to help the family cope with the difficult 
situation and after further discussions, the patient was 
ultimately made CMO.  He was pronoucned dead at ___ at 6:20 
AM.

NSTEMI and ruled out for CVA infarct, treated with IV 
antibiotics for suspicion of coag-negative Staph bacteremia, 
MSSA soft tissue infection, and E. coli UTI. His course was 
complicated by hematemesis for which he underwent 
esophagogastroduodenoscopy on ___ showing esophagitis, an ulcer 
at the GE junction with a vessel that was clipped, and an 
additional antral ulcer that was biopsied, without further 
evidence of bleeding subsequently.

creatinine slightly elevated above

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  

Why was I admitted to the hospital?  
 
- You were admitted because you had high blood pressure and you 
were confused. 

What happened while I was in the hospital?  

- You received medicine to help lower your blood pressure. Due 
to your elevated blood pressure, you were found to be having a 
non ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (a kind of heart 
attack), which did not progress further after your blood 
pressure was under better control. You received an MRI of your 
___ which showed evidence of an old stroke, but no new strokes. 
There was concern for blood stream infection so you were treated 
with intravenous antibiotics.
- You underwent numerous tests, including multiple ultrasounds 
of your heart (echocardiograms). These showed signs of regional 
motion problems likely due to coronary artery disease (narrowing 
of the blood vessels around the heart). However, you did not 
undergo stenting given the likely chronic nature of your heart 
disease and due to concern for your gastrointestinal bleeding.
- You underwent regular hemodialysis on ___, and 
___ as scheduled.
- During this admission, you were also nauseous and vomiting 
blood. To evaluate the source of the bleeding, you were seen by 
the gastroenterologists and taken for esophagoduodenoscopy (EGD 
or "upper endoscopy"), and were found to have esophagitis 
(inflammation of the tube connecting your mouth to your stomach) 
and 2 different ulcers, one of which had a blood vessel that was 
clipped to prevent bleeding. you also had evidence of 
inflammation in your duodenum. For your ulcers, you were started 
on the medication pantoprazole.
-You were treated with intravenous antibiotics for suspicion for 
a bloodstream infection, a soft tissue infection at the site of 
your AV fistula, and a urinary tract infection.
-You developed diarrhea and were found to have C. difficile 
infection, for which you were started on treatment with oral 
vancomycin.
-You were also found to have difficulty speaking, and were 
evaluated by the speech language pathology team.
-You were found to have masses in both of your parotid glands 
(the largest glands in your cheeks that make saliva), which will

schizophrenia, and depression who presented from rehab with AMS, 
bacteremia, NSTEMI in the setting of hypertensive emergency, 
stabilized on an oral antihypertensive regimen and worked up for 
NSTEMI and ruled out for CVA infarct, treated with IV 
antibiotics for suspicion of coag-negative Staph bacteremia, 
MSSA soft tissue infection, and E. coli UTI. His course was 
complicated by hematemesis for which he underwent 
esophagogastroduodenoscopy on ___ showing esophagitis, an ulcer 
at the GE junction with a vessel that was clipped, and an 
additional antral ulcer that was biopsied, without further 
evidence of bleeding subsequently.

Acute Medical Issues

#Hypertensive Emergency
Patient presented with BP 215/115 at ___ and was started on 
nicardipine gtt. His BP ranged from 127-196/68-132 in the ED. He 
had evidence of end organ damage from HTN (demand ischemia, SOB, 
creatinine slightly elevated above
baseline). He was seen by cardiology and due to risk of stroke, 
MI, end-organ dysfunction, decision was made to not decrease BP 
more than 25% over first 24hrs. He was restarted on his home 
antihypertensives once SBP was <180, and was ultimately 
stabilized on a PO regimen of labetalol 200 mg bid, hydralazine 
75mg q6h, nifedipine 60mg ER BID, isosorbide dinitrate 30 mg 
tid, and lisinopril 40mg daily. Of note, patient was noted to 
have significant intradialytic hypertension and should be 
receiving all antiHTNs before HD on MWF. 
[] Continue to f/u blood pressures and ensure compliance with 
hemodialysis

including in the morning before dialysis on dialysis days. If he

labetalol to carvedilol for intradialytic hypertension.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  

Why was I admitted to the hospital?  
 
- You were admitted because you had high blood pressure and you 
were confused. 

What happened while I was in the hospital?  

- You received medicine to help lower your blood pressure. Due 
to your elevated blood pressure, you were found to be having a 
non ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (a kind of heart 
attack), which did not progress further after your blood 
pressure was under better control. You received an MRI of your 
___ which showed evidence of an old stroke, but no new strokes. 
There was concern for blood stream infection so you were treated 
with intravenous antibiotics.
- You underwent numerous tests, including multiple ultrasounds 
of your heart (echocardiograms). These showed signs of regional 
motion problems likely due to coronary artery disease (narrowing 
of the blood vessels around the heart). However, you did not 
undergo stenting given the likely chronic nature of your heart 
disease and due to concern for your gastrointestinal bleeding.
- You underwent regular hemodialysis on ___, and 
___ as scheduled.
- During this admission, you were also nauseous and vomiting 
blood. To evaluate the source of the bleeding, you were seen by 
the gastroenterologists and taken for esophagoduodenoscopy (EGD 
or "upper endoscopy"), and were found to have esophagitis 
(inflammation of the tube connecting your mouth to your stomach) 
and 2 different ulcers, one of which had a blood vessel that was 
clipped to prevent bleeding. you also had evidence of 
inflammation in your duodenum. For your ulcers, you were started 
on the medication pantoprazole.
-You were treated with intravenous antibiotics for suspicion for 
a bloodstream infection, a soft tissue infection at the site of 
your AV fistula, and a urinary tract infection.
-You developed diarrhea and were found to have C. difficile 
infection, for which you were started on treatment with oral 
vancomycin.
-You were also found to have difficulty speaking, and were 
evaluated by the speech language pathology team.
-You were found to have masses in both of your parotid glands 
(the largest glands in your cheeks that make saliva), which will 
require follow-up as an outpatient.

What should I do after leaving the hospital?  
-  Please take your medications as listed in discharge summary 
and follow up at the listed appointments. 

Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish 
you all the best!  

Sincerely,

Your ___ Healthcare Team

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY: Mr. ___ is a ___ w/ PMH of HTN, ESRD on HD, CAD, DM2, 
schizophrenia, and depression who presented from rehab with AMS, 
bacteremia, NSTEMI in the setting of hypertensive emergency, 
stabilized on an oral antihypertensive regimen and worked up for 
NSTEMI and ruled out for CVA infarct, treated with IV 
antibiotics for suspicion of coag-negative Staph bacteremia, 
MSSA soft tissue infection, and E. coli UTI. His course was 
complicated by hematemesis for which he underwent 
esophagogastroduodenoscopy on ___ showing esophagitis, an ulcer 
at the GE junction with a vessel that was clipped, and an 
additional antral ulcer that was biopsied, without further 
evidence of bleeding subsequently.

Acute Medical Issues

#Hypertensive Emergency
Patient presented with BP 215/115 at ___ and was started on 
nicardipine gtt. His BP ranged from 127-196/68-132 in the ED. He 
had evidence of end organ damage from HTN (demand ischemia, SOB, 
creatinine slightly elevated above
baseline). He was seen by cardiology and due to risk of stroke, 
MI, end-organ dysfunction, decision was made to not decrease BP 
more than 25% over first 24hrs. He was restarted on his home 
antihypertensives once SBP was <180, and was ultimately 
stabilized on a PO regimen of labetalol 200 mg bid, hydralazine 
75mg q6h, nifedipine 60mg ER BID, isosorbide dinitrate 30 mg 
tid, and lisinopril 40mg daily. Of note, patient was noted to 
have significant intradialytic hypertension and should be 
receiving all antiHTNs before HD on MWF. 
[] Continue to f/u blood pressures and ensure compliance with 
hemodialysis
[] Please ensure that he continues all his antihypertensives, 
including in the morning before dialysis on dialysis days. If he 
continues to be hypertensive, can consider switching the 
labetalol to carvedilol for intradialytic hypertension.

# NSTEMI
# CAD

hypertensive emergency. EKG showed lateral ST depressions in the 
context of intermittent chest discomfort. It was unclear whether

AV fistula, and there were records of a cardiac catheterization 
in ___ but by report no coronary stent was placed. Lipid panel

showed regional wall motion abnormalities in a RCA distribution.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  

Why was I admitted to the hospital?  
 
- You were admitted because you had high blood pressure and you 
were confused. 

What happened while I was in the hospital?  

- You received medicine to help lower your blood pressure. Due 
to your elevated blood pressure, you were found to be having a 
non ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (a kind of heart 
attack), which did not progress further after your blood 
pressure was under better control. You received an MRI of your 
___ which showed evidence of an old stroke, but no new strokes. 
There was concern for blood stream infection so you were treated 
with intravenous antibiotics.
- You underwent numerous tests, including multiple ultrasounds 
of your heart (echocardiograms). These showed signs of regional 
motion problems likely due to coronary artery disease (narrowing 
of the blood vessels around the heart). However, you did not 
undergo stenting given the likely chronic nature of your heart 
disease and due to concern for your gastrointestinal bleeding.
- You underwent regular hemodialysis on ___, and 
___ as scheduled.
- During this admission, you were also nauseous and vomiting 
blood. To evaluate the source of the bleeding, you were seen by 
the gastroenterologists and taken for esophagoduodenoscopy (EGD 
or "upper endoscopy"), and were found to have esophagitis 
(inflammation of the tube connecting your mouth to your stomach) 
and 2 different ulcers, one of which had a blood vessel that was 
clipped to prevent bleeding. you also had evidence of 
inflammation in your duodenum. For your ulcers, you were started 
on the medication pantoprazole.
-You were treated with intravenous antibiotics for suspicion for 
a bloodstream infection, a soft tissue infection at the site of 
your AV fistula, and a urinary tract infection.
-You developed diarrhea and were found to have C. difficile 
infection, for which you were started on treatment with oral 
vancomycin.
-You were also found to have difficulty speaking, and were 
evaluated by the speech language pathology team.
-You were found to have masses in both of your parotid glands 
(the largest glands in your cheeks that make saliva), which will 
require follow-up as an outpatient.

What should I do after leaving the hospital?  
-  Please take your medications as listed in discharge summary 
and follow up at the listed appointments. 

Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish 
you all the best!  

Sincerely,

Your ___ Healthcare Team

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  

Why was I admitted to the hospital?  
 
- You were admitted because you had high blood pressure and you 
were confused. 

What happened while I was in the hospital?  

- You received medicine to help lower your blood pressure. Due 
to your elevated blood pressure, you were found to be having a 
non ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (a kind of heart 
attack), which did not progress further after your blood 
pressure was under better control. You received an MRI of your 
___ which showed evidence of an old stroke, but no new strokes. 
There was concern for blood stream infection so you were treated 
with intravenous antibiotics.
- You underwent numerous tests, including multiple ultrasounds 
of your heart (echocardiograms). These showed signs of regional 
motion problems likely due to coronary artery disease (narrowing 
of the blood vessels around the heart). However, you did not 
undergo stenting given the likely chronic nature of your heart 
disease and due to concern for your gastrointestinal bleeding.
- You underwent regular hemodialysis on ___, and 
___ as scheduled.
- During this admission, you were also nauseous and vomiting 
blood. To evaluate the source of the bleeding, you were seen by 
the gastroenterologists and taken for esophagoduodenoscopy (EGD 
or "upper endoscopy"), and were found to have esophagitis 
(inflammation of the tube connecting your mouth to your stomach) 
and 2 different ulcers, one of which had a blood vessel that was 
clipped to prevent bleeding. you also had evidence of 
inflammation in your duodenum. For your ulcers, you were started 
on the medication pantoprazole.
-You were treated with intravenous antibiotics for suspicion for 
a bloodstream infection, a soft tissue infection at the site of 
your AV fistula, and a urinary tract infection.
-You developed diarrhea and were found to have C. difficile 
infection, for which you were started on treatment with oral 
vancomycin.
-You were also found to have difficulty speaking, and were 
evaluated by the speech language pathology team.
-You were found to have masses in both of your parotid glands 
(the largest glands in your cheeks that make saliva), which will 
require follow-up as an outpatient.

What should I do after leaving the hospital?  
-  Please take your medications as listed in discharge summary 
and follow up at the listed appointments. 

Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish 
you all the best!  

Sincerely,

Your ___ Healthcare Team

stenosis by NASCET criteria. There is no right cervical internal 
carotid artery stenosis by NASCET criteria. 
2. Diffuse right cervical vertebral artery occlusion with 
reconstitution at the right V3 segment appears chronic. The 
intracranial right vertebral artery is diffusely narrowed 
secondary to atherosclerotic disease. 
3. Atherosclerotic calcification of the intracranial circulation 
is identified, most prominently noted of the right vertebral 
artery, with severe stenosis near its junction with the basilar. 
The remainder of the intracranial circulation demonstrates no 
high-grade stenosis, occlusion or aneurysm. 
4. Multiple enhancing lesions in the parotid glands, the largest 
measure 1.5 x 2.0 cm in the right parotid gland. Findings likely 
represent bilateral Warthin's tumors. These can be further 
evaluated with ultrasound. 
5. Mediastinal lymphadenopathy partially imaged measuring up to 
1.7 cm. 
6. Large bilateral pleural effusions.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  

Why was I admitted to the hospital?  
 
- You were admitted because you had high blood pressure and you 
were confused. 

What happened while I was in the hospital?  

- You received medicine to help lower your blood pressure. Due 
to your elevated blood pressure, you were found to be having a 
non ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (a kind of heart 
attack), which did not progress further after your blood 
pressure was under better control. You received an MRI of your 
___ which showed evidence of an old stroke, but no new strokes. 
There was concern for blood stream infection so you were treated 
with intravenous antibiotics.
- You underwent numerous tests, including multiple ultrasounds 
of your heart (echocardiograms). These showed signs of regional 
motion problems likely due to coronary artery disease (narrowing 
of the blood vessels around the heart). However, you did not 
undergo stenting given the likely chronic nature of your heart 
disease and due to concern for your gastrointestinal bleeding.
- You underwent regular hemodialysis on ___, and 
___ as scheduled.
- During this admission, you were also nauseous and vomiting 
blood. To evaluate the source of the bleeding, you were seen by 
the gastroenterologists and taken for esophagoduodenoscopy (EGD 
or "upper endoscopy"), and were found to have esophagitis 
(inflammation of the tube connecting your mouth to your stomach) 
and 2 different ulcers, one of which had a blood vessel that was 
clipped to prevent bleeding. you also had evidence of 
inflammation in your duodenum. For your ulcers, you were started 
on the medication pantoprazole.
-You were treated with intravenous antibiotics for suspicion for 
a bloodstream infection, a soft tissue infection at the site of 
your AV fistula, and a urinary tract infection.
-You developed diarrhea and were found to have C. difficile 
infection, for which you were started on treatment with oral 
vancomycin.
-You were also found to have difficulty speaking, and were 
evaluated by the speech language pathology team.
-You were found to have masses in both of your parotid glands 
(the largest glands in your cheeks that make saliva), which will 
require follow-up as an outpatient.

What should I do after leaving the hospital?  
-  Please take your medications as listed in discharge summary 
and follow up at the listed appointments. 

Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish 
you all the best!  

Sincerely,

Your ___ Healthcare Team
