c/b NSTEMI, ESRD on HD, initially presenting with acute dyspnea 
in the setting of URI symptoms and subsequently found to be 
positive for flu initially admitted ICU for tachypnea requiring 
BiPAP, now back with a fib RVR (resolved) and new pna 

PRIMARY ISSUES:

#AFib w/ RVR: occurred in the setting of outpatient dialysis 
session. Pt noted to be tachycardic to 160s and this was seen in 
the ED upon arrival. It terminated spontaneously and never 
returned. Etiology was unknown but possibly 2'/2 numerous 
pulmonary problems including albuterol overuse, pna, flu, and 
cancer. He continued metoprolol. 

#Post-Viral Pneumonia: bronchopulmonary pneumonia on CT.  
Clinically, pt with shortness of breath and continued cough, but 
no fevers, or elevated WBC. Nevertheless, imaging rather 
convincing and post viral pneumonia is well described 
phenomenom. Most likely staph or strep and given lobectomy and 
current lung cancer, pt was treated with vancomycin and 
levofloxacin.

#Dyspnea on Exertion: Pt had persistent dyspnea on exertion and 
off oxygen would desaturate to <88% on RA. This was reportedly 
new for the pt. This was thought to be 2'/2 flu, pneumonia, and 
lobectomy with current active cancer leading to poor pulmonary 
substrate. He was discharged with a prescription for home O2. 

CHRONIC ISSUES: 

#ESRD: ___
-Continue sevelamer  
-Renally dose meds  

#BPH:  
-Continue tamsulosin  

#CAD:  
-Continue ASA, statin, and BB  

#Anemia: Chronic and at baseline  

#Chronic cough:  
-Continue chlorpheniramine-Hydrocodone  

#COPD:  
-Continue inhalers  

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
#post-flu pna: pt needs two mroe doses of vancomycin and 
levofloxacin

#hypoxia: multifactorial with lung ca, pna, and flu 
contributing. f/u response to supplemental O2

#lung ca: recurrent as suggested on PET, cytology positive from 
sputum cultures

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was a ___ transferred from OSH to the ACS service 
due to being hemodinamically stable from a liver laceration of 
unknown etiology. Upon report from the OSH surgeon, the patient 
was found down, altered, and hypotensive at home and rushed to 
the hospital by EMT. Upon evaluation the patient was taken 
emergently to the operating room where an exploratory laparotomy 
was performed. Upon entering the abdomen a laceration over the 
dome of the liver was seen and hemostasis was attempted. Due to 
not being able to control the bleeding, packing's where placed 
over and under the liver, the abdomen was temporarily closed 
with a ioban dressing and the patient was transferred to ___ 
for further care. Upon arrival the patient was hypotensive, on 
pressors and with a wbc of 48.3. The patient blood lost was 
sustained by Massive transfusion protocol. The abdominal 
dressing was opened and a wound vac suction was placed from 
which he was losing frank blood. During his stay in the ICU 
hemodynamic were maintain with multiple pressors medications, 
blood products and crystalloids. All his electrolytes where 
tried to be corrected during this time. The patient also 
received TXA for suspected coagulopathy. Due to continued 
deterioration of his symptoms, a family meeting was arranged and 
the decision of the family was to make him CMO. The patient 
expired shortly afterwards.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was a ___ transferred from OSH to the ACS service 
due to being hemodinamically stable from a liver laceration of 
unknown etiology. Upon report from the OSH surgeon, the patient 
was found down, altered, and hypotensive at home and rushed to 
the hospital by EMT. Upon evaluation the patient was taken 
emergently to the operating room where an exploratory laparotomy 
was performed. Upon entering the abdomen a laceration over the 
dome of the liver was seen and hemostasis was attempted. Due to 
not being able to control the bleeding, packing's where placed 
over and under the liver, the abdomen was temporarily closed 
with a ioban dressing and the patient was transferred to ___ 
for further care. Upon arrival the patient was hypotensive, on 
pressors and with a wbc of 48.3. The patient blood lost was 
sustained by Massive transfusion protocol. The abdominal 
dressing was opened and a wound vac suction was placed from 
which he was losing frank blood. During his stay in the ICU 
hemodynamic were maintain with multiple pressors medications, 
blood products and crystalloids. All his electrolytes where 
tried to be corrected during this time. The patient also 
received TXA for suspected coagulopathy. Due to continued 
deterioration of his symptoms, a family meeting was arranged and 
the decision of the family was to make him CMO. The patient 
expired shortly afterwards.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. F with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hepatitis C complicated 
by cirrhosis, varices, hepatic encephalopathy, and HCC, 
presented to ___ on morning of admission with 
shakiness found to have hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.  
.  
# Confusion: Etiologies were thought to include could include 
hepatic encephalopathy, infection, toxic metabolic from 
hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, or less likely metastatic disease. 
It was ultimately believed that her confusion was secondary to 
the patient not taking her insulin or eating in the morning. She 
was continued on rifaximin, and her blood sugar was kept under 
good control. Her mental status cleared and she was alert and 
oriented x 3 at time of discharge.
.  
# Hyponatremia: Believed to be complication of cirrhosis. There 
were no signs of CHF or renal failure. Cortisol level was 
normal. The patient was normonatremic at time of discharge.
.  
# Hyperkalemia: The patient was treated for her hyperkalemia in 
the Emergency Department. Etiologies were thought to include 
dietary indiscretion, spironolactone effect, bactrim therapy for 
UTI, and/or insulin deficiency. EKG's showed now peaked T waves 
or other concerning changes. She was educated about low 
potassium diet. She was also discharged on a reduced dose of 
spironolactone, in addition to low-dose furosemide.  
.  
# Blood on toilet paper: The patient reported this while in the 
Emergency Department. To admitting housestaff, however, she 
denied this. Her hematocrit and hemodynamics were stable.
.  
#UTI: The patient completed a seven day course of bactrim on the 
day of admission.
.
# End Stage Liver Disease ___ Hepatitis C; Hepatocellular 
Carcinoma: LFTs were at baseline. She was continued on 
propanolol and rifaximin per outpt regimen. Management of her 
HCC was deferred to the outpatient setting.
.
# Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: The patient was written for a 
diabetic diet and was placed on her home regimen of lantus and 
ISS

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. F with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hepatitis C complicated 
by cirrhosis, varices, hepatic encephalopathy, and HCC, 
presented to ___ on morning of admission with 
shakiness found to have hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.  
.  
# Confusion: Etiologies were thought to include could include 
hepatic encephalopathy, infection, toxic metabolic from 
hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, or less likely metastatic disease. 
It was ultimately believed that her confusion was secondary to 
the patient not taking her insulin or eating in the morning. She 
was continued on rifaximin, and her blood sugar was kept under 
good control. Her mental status cleared and she was alert and 
oriented x 3 at time of discharge.
.  
# Hyponatremia: Believed to be complication of cirrhosis. There 
were no signs of CHF or renal failure. Cortisol level was 
normal. The patient was normonatremic at time of discharge.
.  
# Hyperkalemia: The patient was treated for her hyperkalemia in 
the Emergency Department. Etiologies were thought to include 
dietary indiscretion, spironolactone effect, bactrim therapy for 
UTI, and/or insulin deficiency. EKG's showed now peaked T waves 
or other concerning changes. She was educated about low 
potassium diet. She was also discharged on a reduced dose of 
spironolactone, in addition to low-dose furosemide.  
.  
# Blood on toilet paper: The patient reported this while in the 
Emergency Department. To admitting housestaff, however, she 
denied this. Her hematocrit and hemodynamics were stable.
.  
#UTI: The patient completed a seven day course of bactrim on the 
day of admission.
.
# End Stage Liver Disease ___ Hepatitis C; Hepatocellular 
Carcinoma: LFTs were at baseline. She was continued on 
propanolol and rifaximin per outpt regimen. Management of her 
HCC was deferred to the outpatient setting.
.
# Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: The patient was written for a 
diabetic diet and was placed on her home regimen of lantus and 
ISS

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. F with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hepatitis C complicated 
by cirrhosis, varices, hepatic encephalopathy, and HCC, 
presented to ___ on morning of admission with 
shakiness found to have hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.  
.  
# Confusion: Etiologies were thought to include could include 
hepatic encephalopathy, infection, toxic metabolic from 
hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, or less likely metastatic disease. 
It was ultimately believed that her confusion was secondary to 
the patient not taking her insulin or eating in the morning. She 
was continued on rifaximin, and her blood sugar was kept under 
good control. Her mental status cleared and she was alert and 
oriented x 3 at time of discharge.
.  
# Hyponatremia: Believed to be complication of cirrhosis. There 
were no signs of CHF or renal failure. Cortisol level was 
normal. The patient was normonatremic at time of discharge.
.  
# Hyperkalemia: The patient was treated for her hyperkalemia in 
the Emergency Department. Etiologies were thought to include 
dietary indiscretion, spironolactone effect, bactrim therapy for 
UTI, and/or insulin deficiency. EKG's showed now peaked T waves 
or other concerning changes. She was educated about low 
potassium diet. She was also discharged on a reduced dose of 
spironolactone, in addition to low-dose furosemide.  
.  
# Blood on toilet paper: The patient reported this while in the 
Emergency Department. To admitting housestaff, however, she 
denied this. Her hematocrit and hemodynamics were stable.
.  
#UTI: The patient completed a seven day course of bactrim on the 
day of admission.
.
# End Stage Liver Disease ___ Hepatitis C; Hepatocellular 
Carcinoma: LFTs were at baseline. She was continued on 
propanolol and rifaximin per outpt regimen. Management of her 
HCC was deferred to the outpatient setting.
.
# Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: The patient was written for a 
diabetic diet and was placed on her home regimen of lantus and 
ISS

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ was admitted to the TSICU. Echo was performed at 
bedside by cardiology and no significant pericardial effusion 
visualized.  Psychiatry initiated a ___ and she remained 
hemodynamically stable was transferred to the floor with a 1:1 
sitter in place.   

Patient tolerated a regular diet with good urine output and pain 
control on the floor.  Vital signs and HCT were stable.  
Tertiary survey performed without additional injuries noted and 
repeat ECHO did not show any pericardial effusion with small 
amount or air visualized.  Small anterior epigastric wound is 
stable without drainage. 

On ___, she was noted to have tachycardia in the 140's on 
telemetry. An ECG was obtained and showed new atrial 
fibrillation. Electrolytes, cardiac enzymes, TSH levels were 
sent. A chest xray was obtained. She was given IV Lopressor. 
Cardiology was consulted and ultimately felt that this new a-fib 
was likely not acute coronary syndrome but rather pericarditis. 
Their recommendations were to start ASA 325 mg po daily and 
metoprolol 25 mg bid and she was also placed on telemetry. She 
did eventually revert back to normal sinus rhythm. Ibuprofen was 
also started to help with inflammation.

You were admitted to the hopsital after a self inflicted stab 
woundto your chest. You were monitored closely inthe ICU and 
once stable transferred to the surgical ward for ongoing 
monitoring. You were also seen by the cardiologist for an 
irregular heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation - it was felt 
this was likely due to pericarditis which is an inflammation of 
the outside lining of the heart. You are being treated with an 
aspirin, a beta blocker called metoprolol and ibuprofen to help 
with the inflammation.

You were also seen by Psychiatry during your stay and being 
recommended for inpatient mental health stay for ongoing 
evalution and treamtent.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ F with h/o HCV (VL ___; contracted from forcible 
injection with needle), remote ovarian torsion, endometriosis, 
nephrolithiasis and conversion disorder (multiple cranial 
neuropathies) who is transferred to ___ Hepatology service 
from ___ for evaluation of acute lower abdominal 
pain.  

#Abdominal pain: at ___, pt had an entirely normal workup 
including CT abd and 2 transvaginal US which only noted some 
free fluid in the pelvis near her left ovary. Repeat U/S 
completed here confirmed that there was no pathology, aside from 
the free fluid. LFTs were found to be consistent with her known 
hepatitis C infection. UA here was found to be positive, with 
sediment positive for RBCs. hCG and RPR were negative, and GC/CT 
were pending at time of discharge. It was discussed w the 
patient that she likely has some abd pain that she previously 
would have been able to tolerate, but due to her recent 
PTSD/sexual abuse lower abd pain triggers an intense subconcious 
stress response that leads to uncontrollable nausea and anxiety, 
to which she agreed.  

#UTI: pt complained of dysuria during admission and, urine 
sediment was found to be positive for WBC and RBCs. Pt was 
started on ciprofloxacin, after which her abdominal pain 
improved. She was discharged on cipro.

#PTSD: Pt has PTSD following reported kidnapping by gang six 
months ago with subsequetnt rape. Home prazosin and trazodone 
were continued for anxiety/insomnia during admission.  She 
described that she should not receive IV push narcotics any 
longer as it triggers her PTSD.

#Bell's palsy & conversion disorder: these were stable during 
admission. 

Transitional Issues:
- NO IV PUSH NARCOTICS -> triggers PTSD
- if presenting with abdominal pain, please strongly consider 
that pelvic examination and transvaginal ultrasound can trigger 
a PTSD response
- f/u urine culture
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Fluoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY 
2. TraZODone 100 mg PO HS:PRN anxiety, insomnia 
3. Prazosin 2 mg PO HS:PRN anxiety 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Fluoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY 
2. Prazosin 2 mg PO HS:PRN anxiety 
3. TraZODone 100 mg PO HS:PRN anxiety, insomnia 
4. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
Please make sure that you do not take MORE THAN 4 GRAMS a day. 
5. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H 
6. Naproxen 500 mg PO Q8H:PRN abd pain

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Abdominal pain
PTSD
UTI

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital for worsening abdominal pain 
and nausea/vomiting. You had a negative workup including a CT 
scan of your abdomen and 3 ultrasounds.  Your symptoms resolved 
over the course of your stay. It is likely that your pain is due 
to a ruptured ovarian follicle (due to fluid being noted around 
the left ovary near your pain), which is self limiting.  It is 
also possible that your pain was due to a UTI.

with IV morphine. No aggravating factors. Patient also complains 
of occasional streaks of blood in her vomit. At ___ she

had 1 episode of diarrhea but no constipation. Currently her BMs 
are formed and regular. Patient started her menstrual period on 
___, menses are now over. She is sexually active and uses 
condoms for birth control. Denies any unusual vaginal discharge 
or vaginal pain/pruritis. Endorses h/o endometriosis but says 
this pain feels much worse than that. Also c/o dysuria, no 
hesitancy or frequency. She denies fever or chills, sick 
contacts, ingestions.

for elevated LFTs (see labs below) c/w her known hepatitis that 
were stable from prior admissions. Lipase 122. Hepatitis 
serologies revealed positive HCV antibody, negative HAV and HBV 
studies. She received opioids (morphine, dilaudid) and zofran 
for her symptoms. While hospitalized, she was seen by GI Consult 
who performed EGD on ___. This was entirely unremarkable. She 
had urgent transvaginal ultrasound with dopplers which was 
showed unremarkable uterus, fallopian tubes and ovaries. 
Noncontrast CT ___ was unremarkable except for a 0.4cm 
cystic mass within the uterus which may communicate with the 
endometrial cavity. She was evaluated by Gynecology as inpt, who 
felt she did not require any further workup. Given unrevealing 
inpatient workup and ongoing abdominal pain, patient is now 
transferred from ___ to ___ for further workup of the 
pain.  
On arrival to ___, vitals are 97.8, 109/75, 76, 18, 97% RA. Pt 
complains of suprapubic pain which radiates to her flank, is 
paroxysmal, and feels "the same as when I had kidney stones in 
the past". C/O nausea and says she last vomited this morning. 
Denies ongoing hematesis. No diarrhea since ___.  
Of note, pt has h/o HCV which was diagnosed in ___. She 
states it occurred in setting of being "forcibly injected" with 
a syringe when kidnapped by a gang. She was admitted to ___ in 
___ for acute left flank pain of unclear etiology, 
ultimately thought ___ endometriosis. CT ___ showed no 
nephrolithiasis. Her LFTs rose during hospitalization and she 
underwent extensive testing for other causes of acute hepatitis 
including RUQ U/S, iron studies, autoimmune/inflammatory panel, 
and infectious studies. (Please see D/C summary from ___ for 
full summary of studies performed). EBV PCR was elevated, so 
thought acute EBV could be exacerbating her hepatitis. She also 
underwent liver bx on ___ which showed chronic HCV with grade 
II inflamm and stage 1 fibrosis.  
ROS: per HPI, denies fever, chills, night sweats, headache, 
vision changes, rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, 
shortness of breath, chest pain, BRBPR, melena, dysuria, 
hematuria.

- anxiety disorder  
- migraines

- s/p ovarian torsion surgery ___ ago at ___)  
- ovarian cysts, dysmenorrhea

Brief Hospital Course:
___ F with h/o HCV (VL ___; contracted from forcible 
injection with needle), remote ovarian torsion, endometriosis, 
nephrolithiasis and conversion disorder (multiple cranial 
neuropathies) who is transferred to ___ Hepatology service 
from ___ for evaluation of acute lower abdominal 
pain.  

#Abdominal pain: at ___, pt had an entirely normal workup 
including CT abd and 2 transvaginal US which only noted some 
free fluid in the pelvis near her left ovary. Repeat U/S 
completed here confirmed that there was no pathology, aside from 
the free fluid. LFTs were found to be consistent with her known 
hepatitis C infection. UA here was found to be positive, with 
sediment positive for RBCs. hCG and RPR were negative, and GC/CT 
were pending at time of discharge. It was discussed w the 
patient that she likely has some abd pain that she previously 
would have been able to tolerate, but due to her recent 
PTSD/sexual abuse lower abd pain triggers an intense subconcious 
stress response that leads to uncontrollable nausea and anxiety, 
to which she agreed.  

#UTI: pt complained of dysuria during admission and, urine 
sediment was found to be positive for WBC and RBCs. Pt was 
started on ciprofloxacin, after which her abdominal pain 
improved. She was discharged on cipro.

#PTSD: Pt has PTSD following reported kidnapping by gang six 
months ago with subsequetnt rape. Home prazosin and trazodone 
were continued for anxiety/insomnia during admission.  She 
described that she should not receive IV push narcotics any 
longer as it triggers her PTSD.

#Bell's palsy & conversion disorder: these were stable during 
admission. 

Transitional Issues:
- NO IV PUSH NARCOTICS -> triggers PTSD
- if presenting with abdominal pain, please strongly consider 
that pelvic examination and transvaginal ultrasound can trigger 
a PTSD response
- f/u urine culture

#Constipation:
Patient presented with abdominal pain, thought to be from 
constipation.  Treated with bowel regimen with good effect.  
Subsequently he had regular bowel movements with resolution of 
symptoms--they did not recur.  Maintained on daily miralax, with 

prn Bisacodyl, then if not moving bowels prn fleet enema, then 
if not moving bowels prn Magnesium Citrate 300mL.  At discharge 
he was pain free.

# Dysphagia secondary to ALS

seen by SLP and recommended to continue his modified diet.  He 
was seen by nutrition and underwent a calorie count.  He was 
felt to still be able to meet his nutritional needs with oral 
intake--this was dependent on attentive assisted feedings, with 
supplements: Magic Cup TID, Skandishake. 

A video swallow study was performed by Speech pathology and 
advised the following:

1. Diet: Pureed solids with nectar-thick liquids

Free Water protocol:

adhere

allowance

#Constipation:

constipation.  Treated with bowel regimen with good effect.

symptoms--they did not recur.  Maintained on daily miralax, with

Mr. ___ was admitted to general surgery from the pacu. He was 
maintained as NPO with IVF/PCA/Foley. With the return of bowel 
function and flatus his diet was advanced from sips to regular, 
tolerated well. His bridge will be removed on ___ by the 
___ care RN. He was instructed on how to titrate his imodium 
to maintain ostomy output between ___ liters daily. He had an 
uncomplicated post-op course. He will follow up with Dr. ___ 
in ___ weeks. 
 
Medications on Admission:
 Citalopram 40'

Home

Chrons

Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.
*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment 
with the surgeon.
*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
.
Incision Care:
-Your staples will be removed at  your follow up appointment. 
-Steri-strips will be applied and will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
.
Monitoring Ostomy output/Prevention of Dehydration:
-Keep well hydrated.
-Replace fluid loss from ostomy daily.
-Avoid only drinking plain water. Include Gatorade and/or other 
vitamin drinks to replace fluid.
-Try to maintain ostomy output between 1000mL to 1500mL per day. 

-If Ostomy output >1 liter, take 4mg of Imodium, repeat 2mg with 

each episode of loose stool. Do not exceed 16mg/24 hours
.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

PATIENT SUMMARY
====================
Ms. ___ is a ___ s/p emergent OR L4-5 laminectomy

MRI lumbar spine at OSH revealed residual L4-5 disc with

discontinued and IVC filter was placed at OSH prior to patient 
being transferred to ___ for neurosurgical evaluation. On 
admission patient was admitted to the ___ for close 
neurological monitoring with the following hospital course 
below.

ACTIVE ISSUES ADDRESSED
=======================
#Concern for epidural hemorrhage
When patient arrived to the ICU she reported her BLE 
strength/motor was stable to when she left ___ on ___ or 
possibly improved. A second opinion ___ was obtained on the OSH 
MRI L spine which showed the fluid collection was likely 
consistent with a postsurgical seroma. No hematoma present. She 
was restarted on heparin gtt for saddle PE and DVTs. 

#Saddle PE
Bilateral DVTs
Patient was admitted to the ICU satting 94-95% on RA. VSS. Based 
on second opinion ___ of her MRI L spine at the OSH there was 
no concern for hemorrhage and she was restarted on her heparin 
gtt for Saddle PE and DVTs with goal PTT 50-70. MASCOT was 
contacted who determined the patient was not a candidate for 
catheter based thrombolysis given her clinical exam, and stable 
respiratory picture. IVC filter was not removed. Heparin gtt was 
titrated for a ptt goal of 60-80, goal was attained on ___. 
Patient was started on Coumadin on ___ with plan for bridge off 
of heparin gtt. INRs were checked daily for a goal INR of ___. 
Patient was transitioned from her heparin gtt to Coumadin on 
___. On ___, her Coumadin was held for a supratherapeutic INR 
of 3.5. During morning rounds, it was noted that her left leg 
was significantly swollen and the patient was complaining of 
pain. An ultrasound was completed which demonstrated that there 
was no flow of the deep veins in the left leg. Vascular surgery 
was reconsulted; they wrapped her leg and pulse checks were 
initiated. A hematology/oncology consult was ordered and labs to 
rule out HIT were sent. Hematology recommended reversing the 
Coumadin since it is possible the patient is non-responsive and 
to start her on therapeutic Lovenox. CTA abdomen, pelvis, and 
lower extremities showed extension of DVT to level of common 
illiacs with partial occlusion to total occlusion of LLE. The 
patient's lovenox was titrated for therapeutic level of 0.86 at 
4 hrs post-administration of lovenox ___ mg SC Q12H. Patient to 
f/u with vascular medicine after discharge. Patient to obtain 
compression stockings for b/l leg swelling as outpatient to 
increase compression and blood return to lower extremities.

#Orthostatic hypotension: Likely ___ prolonged immobility over 
the
last few weeks, also poor cardiac reserve in the setting of 
large
clot burden. She has been persistently tachycardic, which is
expected for her RV function and clot burden. TTE on ___ showed 
normal RV function and size. AM cortisol negative for adrenal 
insufficiency. Her orthostatic hypotension improved and on day 
of d/c was negative for drop in BP and she was asymptomatic when 
standing and walking with physical therapy team.

#Elevated transaminases: Patient with increased AST, ALT, 
alkaline phosphatase on ___ from stable prior ___. No liver 
history. Transaminases were mildly elevated on arrival with peak 
of 5x ULN (AST 158, ALT 300) suggesting exacerbation of a 
pre-existing liver condition. Physical exam and CT with contrast 
are unremarkable for any evidence of chronic liver disease (and

taking
opioids. Likely ___ immobility and also has urinary retention 
after
surgery. Air fluid level with colonic ileus on KUB which

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,  

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___.  

WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- You were in the hospital because you had shortness of breath 
and you were found to have blood clots in the your legs and 
blood clots in your lungs.

WHAT HAPPENED TO ME IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- Your blood clots were treated with a blood thinning 
medications. Because the clots got bigger, the medication was 
changed from warfarin and heparin to Lovenox shots
- You had dizziness, fast heart rates, low blood pressure with 
standing which improved overtime and were thought to be related 
to the blood clots
- You received medication for constipation
- You had difficulty passing urine and had a catheter placed
- You had a fever that was thought to be due to your blood clots
- You were seen by our inpatient psychiatry team who recommended 
medications for anxiety

WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?  
- Continue to take all your medicines and keep your 
appointments.
- Inject the lovenox blood thinner medication every morning and 
every night  
- Make sure to take in enough fluids throughout the day to 
prevent your blood pressure from getting too low
- Follow the post-operative instructions below
- Consider enrolling in a partial psychiatric program to work on 
coping skills
- Please use compression stockings on your legs to minimize 
swelling and improve circulation

We wish you the best!  

Sincerely,  
Your ___ Team  

Surgery:

•Do not apply any lotions or creams to the surgical site. 
•Please avoid swimming for two weeks after staple removal.
•Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity:
•We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
•You may take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity 
at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
•No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
•No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications: 
•You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
•It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
•Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
•Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
•New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

ACTIVE ISSUES ADDRESSED

#Concern for epidural hemorrhage
When patient arrived to the ICU she reported her BLE 
strength/motor was stable to when she left ___ on ___ or 
possibly improved. A second opinion ___ was obtained on the OSH 
MRI L spine which showed the fluid collection was likely 
consistent with a postsurgical seroma. No hematoma present. She 
was restarted on heparin gtt for saddle PE and DVTs. 

#Saddle PE
Bilateral DVTs
Patient was admitted to the ICU satting 94-95% on RA. VSS. Based 
on second opinion ___ of her MRI L spine at the OSH there was 
no concern for hemorrhage and she was restarted on her heparin 
gtt for Saddle PE and DVTs with goal PTT 50-70. MASCOT was 
contacted who determined the patient was not a candidate for 
catheter based thrombolysis given her clinical exam, and stable 
respiratory picture. IVC filter was not removed. Heparin gtt was 
titrated for a ptt goal of 60-80, goal was attained on ___. 
Patient was started on Coumadin on ___ with plan for bridge off 
of heparin gtt. INRs were checked daily for a goal INR of ___. 
Patient was transitioned from her heparin gtt to Coumadin on 
___. On ___, her Coumadin was held for a supratherapeutic INR 
of 3.5. During morning rounds, it was noted that her left leg 
was significantly swollen and the patient was complaining of 
pain. An ultrasound was completed which demonstrated that there 
was no flow of the deep veins in the left leg. Vascular surgery 
was reconsulted; they wrapped her leg and pulse checks were 
initiated. A hematology/oncology consult was ordered and labs to 
rule out HIT were sent. Hematology recommended reversing the 
Coumadin since it is possible the patient is non-responsive and 
to start her on therapeutic Lovenox. CTA abdomen, pelvis, and 
lower extremities showed extension of DVT to level of common 
illiacs with partial occlusion to total occlusion of LLE. The 
patient's lovenox was titrated for therapeutic level of 0.86 at

f/u with vascular medicine after discharge. Patient to obtain 
compression stockings for b/l leg swelling as outpatient to 
increase compression and blood return to lower extremities.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,  

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___.  

WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- You were in the hospital because you had shortness of breath 
and you were found to have blood clots in the your legs and 
blood clots in your lungs.

WHAT HAPPENED TO ME IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- Your blood clots were treated with a blood thinning 
medications. Because the clots got bigger, the medication was 
changed from warfarin and heparin to Lovenox shots
- You had dizziness, fast heart rates, low blood pressure with 
standing which improved overtime and were thought to be related 
to the blood clots
- You received medication for constipation
- You had difficulty passing urine and had a catheter placed
- You had a fever that was thought to be due to your blood clots
- You were seen by our inpatient psychiatry team who recommended 
medications for anxiety

WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?  
- Continue to take all your medicines and keep your 
appointments.
- Inject the lovenox blood thinner medication every morning and 
every night  
- Make sure to take in enough fluids throughout the day to 
prevent your blood pressure from getting too low
- Follow the post-operative instructions below
- Consider enrolling in a partial psychiatric program to work on 
coping skills
- Please use compression stockings on your legs to minimize 
swelling and improve circulation

We wish you the best!  

Sincerely,  
Your ___ Team  

Surgery:

•Do not apply any lotions or creams to the surgical site. 
•Please avoid swimming for two weeks after staple removal.
•Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity:
•We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
•You may take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity 
at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
•No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
•No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications: 
•You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
•It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
•Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
•Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
•New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

prevent your blood pressure from getting too low

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with a past medical history of HTN, 
DM, CAD, obesity, OSA who presented to the ED with chest pain 
c/f ACS s/p cardiac catherization with no stentable disease.  

# NSTEMI: Patient has multiple risk factors for ACS. Patient had 
troponins that had peaked during stay, and was initially placed 
on maximal medical therapy and heparin gtt. Patient underwent 
cardiac catheterization which then showed 90% obstructing lesion 
in the acute RCA marginal branch, and 60-70% circumflex lesion, 
however unable to intervene with any stenting. Therefore, it was 
proposed that patient should optimize medical management and was 
continued on heparin gtt for 48 hours. Patient's blood pressure 
regimen was better optimized and was stable for discharge. We 
continued daily aspirin 81, changed atorvastatin 80 mg qhs to 
rosuvastatin 40 qhs, carvedilol 12.5 mg PO/NG BID. Patient will 
stay on  Plavix for ___ year at 75 mg/day. ECHO showed a preserved 
EF >55%.

# Diabetes Mellitus Type II: 
We continued home lantus and held home metformin in lieu of an 
insulin sliding scale while inpatient. 

# Hypertension: 
We exchanged metoprolol for carvedilol 12.5 mg BID and continued 
home amlodipine and HCTZ, losartan 100 and added isosorbide 
Mononitrate 30.

# Depression: 
- Continued home wellbutrin
- Continued home trazodone as needed

# Obstructive Sleep Apnea
- Continued CPAP

c/f ACS s/p cardiac catherization with no stentable disease.

cardiac catheterization which then showed 90% obstructing lesion 
in the acute RCA marginal branch, and 60-70% circumflex lesion, 
however unable to intervene with any stenting. Therefore, it was 
proposed that patient should optimize medical management and was 
continued on heparin gtt for 48 hours. Patient's blood pressure 
regimen was better optimized and was stable for discharge. We 
continued daily aspirin 81, changed atorvastatin 80 mg qhs to 
rosuvastatin 40 qhs, carvedilol 12.5 mg PO/NG BID. Patient will 
stay on  Plavix for ___ year at 75 mg/day. ECHO showed a preserved 
EF >55%.

# Diabetes Mellitus Type II: 
We continued home lantus and held home metformin in lieu of an 
insulin sliding scale while inpatient. 

# Hypertension: 
We exchanged metoprolol for carvedilol 12.5 mg BID and continued 
home amlodipine and HCTZ, losartan 100 and added isosorbide 
Mononitrate 30.

# Depression: 
- Continued home wellbutrin
- Continued home trazodone as needed

# Obstructive Sleep Apnea
- Continued CPAP

electrolyte panel at f/u appointment.

Brief Hospital Course:
Information for Outpatient Providers: ___ male with a 
past medical history of type 1 diabetes who presented with tooth 
pain and was found to be in DKA with BS 450 - admitted to the 
MICU for initiation of insulin gtt with closure of anion gap - 
transitioned to subcutaneous insulin successfully and discharged 
with basal+bolus insulin regimen. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
[] Please ensure that patient is checking his FSBG consistently 
and taking his insulin consistently and as prescribed 
[] Patient will need close f/u and titration of insulin in 
setting of recent DKA
[] Patient noted with large increase in triglycerides. Needs f/u 
for underlying etiologies, including genetic causes. 
(Triglycerides, nonfasting 993, HDL 19 cholesterol LDL 281. 
Fasting triglycerides 525, HDL 25, LDL 250) - this may represent 
a familial hypertriglyceridemia given his low HDL. 

ACUTE/ACTIVE ISSUES:
====================
#T1DM w/ hyperglycemia 
#DKA (resolved) 
Presented in DKA secondary possible medication noncompliance, 
though patient states that it was due to glucometer malfunction. 
VBG on admission was notable for pH of 7.07, gap of 26. He was 
admitted to the MICU and started on an insulin gtt with 
resolution of gap. On the floor, he was followed by ___ and 
his insulin regimen was uptitrated. Of note A1c 11.8. He was 
seen by diabetic nurse educator for insulin teaching and sent 
home with a new glucometer + strips and new insulin pens. At 
discharge, his insulin regimen was: 
 -25 units Lantus 
 -7 units Humalog with breakfast and lunch, 9 units Humalog
with dinner
 -Sliding scale 1 units for every 50 above 150 QACH. 1 unit for 
each 50>200 HS. 

#hypokalemia 
#hypophosphatemia 
#hypomagnesemia 
In the setting of DKA. Repleted with improvement 

#Tooth Pain
Examination without any obvious signs of dental 
infection/abscess. 
- outpt follow up

CHRONIC/STABLE ISSUES:
======================
#Anemia
Likely anemia of chronic disease
- CTM

#Hypertriglyceridemia
Triglycerides 993, HDL 19 on ___
Fasting repeat with triglycerides 525, HDL 25, LDL 250
- PCP follow up

Brief Hospital Course:
Information for Outpatient Providers: ___ male with a

transitioned to subcutaneous insulin successfully and discharged 
with basal+bolus insulin regimen.

and taking his insulin consistently and as prescribed

for underlying etiologies, including genetic causes. 
(Triglycerides, nonfasting 993, HDL 19 cholesterol LDL 281. 
Fasting triglycerides 525, HDL 25, LDL 250) - this may represent 
a familial hypertriglyceridemia given his low HDL.

====================

though patient states that it was due to glucometer malfunction.

admitted to the MICU and started on an insulin gtt with 
resolution of gap. On the floor, he was followed by ___ and 
his insulin regimen was uptitrated. Of note A1c 11.8. He was 
seen by diabetic nurse educator for insulin teaching and sent

 -25 units Lantus

with dinner

each 50>200 HS. 

#hypokalemia

#hypomagnesemia 
In the setting of DKA. Repleted with improvement 

#Tooth Pain
Examination without any obvious signs of dental 
infection/abscess. 
- outpt follow up

- CTM

from bid 0.5mg to tid (see note in OMR). She was up on the 
couch, no seizures, and then left the house with caretakers for

 - "Bolting" type of seizure (described above, initially a non
     responsive / staring spell with "stiffening" for ___,

     of the way if restrained. Retreats to the bathroom,
     confused/post-ictal for a minute or two afterwards;

 -  Bolting can be followed by drop seizures, althought the
     drops are rarely witnessed, but often associated with
     injury to her face.
 -  The drop seizures are often followed by a tonic extensor

History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with history of
non-insulin-dependent diabetes, bipolar disorder, hypertension,
hyperlipidemia, peripheral vascular disease who presents with
altered mental status and recent fall. 

History from patient is limited as she has been confused at home
and does not remember many events. Patient reports that for the
past week she has felt confused. She reports that her son called
her yesterday and was concerned because "I didn't sound good",
though she does not remember this conversation. She also reports
falling, and does not remember how this happened. She does
remember hitting her back, and notes that the back of the right
knee, which had been bothering her, has been more painful after
the fall. Patient otherwise reports that she has felt very tired
and not herself, with low energy. She states that her memory
hasn't been the same, though is not able to further describe
this. She has developed urinary incontinence, which is new in 
the
past month. She otherwise denies any pain with urination or
increased frequency. No fevers or chills that she is aware of.
She reports that she has not missed any medications, which she
manages herself.

She does report diarrhea, which has been ongoing for several
years, but has been fairly severe this week. She had a small
amount of dark pink blood after a recent bowel movement as well.
No abdominal pain. She normally takes loperamide for diarrhea,
and feels that it is related to certain foods as it has improved
over the years with decreasing dairy in her diet. 

Per ED report, "Her son reports that over the past month or so
she has been having a slow decline, with intermittent confusion
(he mentions things like starting her to check and forgetting
that she is writing to). 2 days ago she had a fall at home, and
since then she has been getting worse. He reports her speech
seems a bit slurred and she seems increasingly confused."

___ yo F PMHx T2DM c/b peripheral neuropathy, bipolar disorder,

# Hyperglycemia

# Toxic-metabolic encephalopathy ___ hyperglycemia

anion gap or acidosis on VBG.  A1c 12.2 despite reported
compliance with max doses of PO medications.  She was started on 
insulin.  Patient and family educated on insulin administration.

Humalog AC.
She will follow-up with PCP and ___.

# Fall
Patient and her son reported worsening confusion over month 
prior to admission,
mental status acutely worse in week prior to admission.  
She also reports a fall and decreased balance prior to 
admission.  
Suspect related to hyperglycemia, though does have underlying 
chronic small vessel disease seen on ___.  Patient recommended 
for home ___. 
She was cleared by OT.  It was recommended to follow-up with 
Cognitive Neurology 
for further testing. 

# ___ 
Cr 1.2 at admission from baseline 0.9. Likely prerenal in 
setting of hyperglycemia.  Resolved with IVF.

# Right knee pain 
Acute on chronic, worsening after fall.  Developed right knee 
effusion, likely post-traumatic.  XR negative for fracture.  
Recommend repeat right knee XR in 4 weeks to re-assess for 
resolution.

# Elevated TSH
TSH resulted high at time of discharge.  Recommend follow-up 
T3/T4 testing.

Continued home aspirin 81mg, cilostazol

CT-GUIDED ABSCESS DRAINAGE ___:
CT FINDINGS: 
Patient is known with a large superficial skin ulceration 
overlying the right hip.  Underneath this ulceration there are 
two linear collections 
communicating between them and going to that ulcer; the more 
superficial one contains a fat-fluid level and measures 11.5 x 
2.4 cm; the deepest one measures 13 x 2.4 cm, the collection is 
in the subcutaneous fat and goes up to the gluteus muscle.  
There is also a small collection in the anterior portion of the 
right maximus gluteus muscle (series 3, image 38) measuring 17 x 
27 mm. The greater trochanter lies just beneath the collection.  
There is minimal irregularity of the cortex but which is similar 
to the other side.  There is no significant sign of 
osteomyelitis. 
There is significant degenerative change of the spine with 
anterolisthesis of L4 over L5 measuring 7 mm. 
Multiple gallstones are seen without sign of cholecystitis.  
Small and large bowel of the pelvis are unremarkable.  A Foley 
catheter is in the bladder. The uterus is unremarkable.  There 
is a rectal and uterine prolapse. 
PROCEDURE: 
It was decided to aspirate and drain the more superficial 
collection which should be in continuity with the deepest one. 
The procedure risks and benefits and alternatives were discussed 
with the 
patient and written informed consent was obtained.  A 
preprocedure timeout was performed, discussing the planned 
procedure, confirming the patient's identity with three 
identifiers and reviewing a checklist per ___ protocol. 
The patient was placed on left lateral decubitus on the CT table 
to access the subcutaneous right hip collection.  Under CT 
guidance, an entrance site was selected and the skin was prepped 
and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  5 cc of lidocaine 1% 
was instilled for local anesthesia.  A 5 ___ ___ catheter 
needle was first inserted into the collection where 30 cc of pus 
was removed and sent to microbiology.  Then by a more anterior 
approach with an 18 gauge ___ needle, ___ wire was put 
into the collection and 6 ___ catheter was then inserted. 
Deep sedation was provided by the anesthesia, please refer to 
their note for further detail.  There was no complication after 
the procedure. 
IMPRESSION: 
CT-guided placement of a 6 ___ catheter inside the soft 
tissue abcess 
overlyng the right hip.  Pus was removed from the collection and 
sent to 
microbiology. 
.

Ms. ___ is an ___ with a hx ___ body dementia, AF (not

# R thigh abscess, infected bursitis, osteomyelitis ___ proteus 
Patient developed a right thigh abscess in the setting of a 
large pressure ulcer on the lateral right thigh. Abscess was 
likely present during prior admission (vs. superinfected sp 
bursa bx done on prior admission). Initially, fevers were 
attributed to sacral decubitus ulcer, and ACS was consulted to 
perform a bed-side debridement. Debridement on ___ revealed 
a clean-based sacral ulcer, which did not probe to bone. Given 
this, patient was scheduled to undergo US-guided biopsy of R 
thigh (swollen area on upper right thigh which was previously 
found to contain sterile bursitis). Repeat U/S was concerning 
for possible abscess. Pt underwent CT-guided aspiration of R 
thigh abscess under anesthesia (on ___ and surgical bedside 
debridement of R thigh abscess (on ___. She also underwent 
operative debridement and bone biopsy (on ___. She was treated 
with flagyl (___) and Vancomycin/Cefepime (___). She 
was evaluated by infectious disease and, after tissue culture 
from bone showed proteus growth, she was transitioned to PO 
monotherapy with Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO bid (day 1 = ___ with 
a plan to continue treatment until ___. Nutritional status 
remained tenuous and pt's diet was liberalized. Patient was 
evaluated by S+S, who recommedned ground dysphagia diet until 
re-assessment at a time when pt was able to obtain her dentures. 
Calorie counts were inconsistent but, with family's 
encouragement, pt was able to eat large meals. She was 
discharged with follow-up at Surgery clinic for further 
management of the R thigh wound.

CT-GUIDED ABSCESS DRAINAGE ___:
CT FINDINGS: 
Patient is known with a large superficial skin ulceration 
overlying the right hip.  Underneath this ulceration there are 
two linear collections 
communicating between them and going to that ulcer; the more 
superficial one contains a fat-fluid level and measures 11.5 x 
2.4 cm; the deepest one measures 13 x 2.4 cm, the collection is 
in the subcutaneous fat and goes up to the gluteus muscle.  
There is also a small collection in the anterior portion of the 
right maximus gluteus muscle (series 3, image 38) measuring 17 x 
27 mm. The greater trochanter lies just beneath the collection.  
There is minimal irregularity of the cortex but which is similar 
to the other side.  There is no significant sign of 
osteomyelitis. 
There is significant degenerative change of the spine with 
anterolisthesis of L4 over L5 measuring 7 mm. 
Multiple gallstones are seen without sign of cholecystitis.  
Small and large bowel of the pelvis are unremarkable.  A Foley 
catheter is in the bladder. The uterus is unremarkable.  There 
is a rectal and uterine prolapse. 
PROCEDURE: 
It was decided to aspirate and drain the more superficial 
collection which should be in continuity with the deepest one. 
The procedure risks and benefits and alternatives were discussed 
with the 
patient and written informed consent was obtained.  A 
preprocedure timeout was performed, discussing the planned 
procedure, confirming the patient's identity with three 
identifiers and reviewing a checklist per ___ protocol. 
The patient was placed on left lateral decubitus on the CT table 
to access the subcutaneous right hip collection.  Under CT 
guidance, an entrance site was selected and the skin was prepped 
and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  5 cc of lidocaine 1% 
was instilled for local anesthesia.  A 5 ___ ___ catheter 
needle was first inserted into the collection where 30 cc of pus 
was removed and sent to microbiology.  Then by a more anterior 
approach with an 18 gauge ___ needle, ___ wire was put 
into the collection and 6 ___ catheter was then inserted. 
Deep sedation was provided by the anesthesia, please refer to 
their note for further detail.  There was no complication after 
the procedure. 
IMPRESSION: 
CT-guided placement of a 6 ___ catheter inside the soft 
tissue abcess 
overlyng the right hip.  Pus was removed from the collection and 
sent to 
microbiology. 
.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ with a hx ___ body dementia, AF (not 
on AC), T2DM, who presented with recurrent fevers and R hip 
pain/swelling. She was found to have a R thigh abscess/infected 
bursitis and osteomyelitis of the R femur.  

# R thigh abscess, infected bursitis, osteomyelitis ___ proteus 
Patient developed a right thigh abscess in the setting of a 
large pressure ulcer on the lateral right thigh. Abscess was 
likely present during prior admission (vs. superinfected sp 
bursa bx done on prior admission). Initially, fevers were 
attributed to sacral decubitus ulcer, and ACS was consulted to 
perform a bed-side debridement. Debridement on ___ revealed 
a clean-based sacral ulcer, which did not probe to bone. Given 
this, patient was scheduled to undergo US-guided biopsy of R 
thigh (swollen area on upper right thigh which was previously 
found to contain sterile bursitis). Repeat U/S was concerning 
for possible abscess. Pt underwent CT-guided aspiration of R 
thigh abscess under anesthesia (on ___ and surgical bedside 
debridement of R thigh abscess (on ___. She also underwent 
operative debridement and bone biopsy (on ___. She was treated 
with flagyl (___) and Vancomycin/Cefepime (___). She 
was evaluated by infectious disease and, after tissue culture 
from bone showed proteus growth, she was transitioned to PO 
monotherapy with Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO bid (day 1 = ___ with 
a plan to continue treatment until ___. Nutritional status 
remained tenuous and pt's diet was liberalized. Patient was 
evaluated by S+S, who recommedned ground dysphagia diet until 
re-assessment at a time when pt was able to obtain her dentures. 
Calorie counts were inconsistent but, with family's 
encouragement, pt was able to eat large meals. She was 
discharged with follow-up at Surgery clinic for further 
management of the R thigh wound. 
 
# Sacral Decubitus Ulcer
Pt has a Stage IV sacral ulcer. As above, pt underwent 
debridement by ACS on ___. Wound care nursing was consulted and 
recommended instructions for care of the ulcer on discharge.

HCT is slightly below baseline (30s to low ___. There were no 
signs of active bleeding. 
  
# Dementia:
Pt was A+Ox2.5 but intermittently not responsive during 
interview. She was more readily responsive when family was at 
bedside. Mental status was at baseline per family. We continued 
Quetiapine and Oxcarbamazepine during this admission. 

# Well-controlled DM without complications:

CT-GUIDED ABSCESS DRAINAGE ___:
CT FINDINGS: 
Patient is known with a large superficial skin ulceration 
overlying the right hip.  Underneath this ulceration there are 
two linear collections 
communicating between them and going to that ulcer; the more 
superficial one contains a fat-fluid level and measures 11.5 x 
2.4 cm; the deepest one measures 13 x 2.4 cm, the collection is 
in the subcutaneous fat and goes up to the gluteus muscle.  
There is also a small collection in the anterior portion of the 
right maximus gluteus muscle (series 3, image 38) measuring 17 x 
27 mm. The greater trochanter lies just beneath the collection.  
There is minimal irregularity of the cortex but which is similar 
to the other side.  There is no significant sign of 
osteomyelitis. 
There is significant degenerative change of the spine with 
anterolisthesis of L4 over L5 measuring 7 mm. 
Multiple gallstones are seen without sign of cholecystitis.  
Small and large bowel of the pelvis are unremarkable.  A Foley 
catheter is in the bladder. The uterus is unremarkable.  There 
is a rectal and uterine prolapse. 
PROCEDURE: 
It was decided to aspirate and drain the more superficial 
collection which should be in continuity with the deepest one. 
The procedure risks and benefits and alternatives were discussed 
with the 
patient and written informed consent was obtained.  A 
preprocedure timeout was performed, discussing the planned 
procedure, confirming the patient's identity with three 
identifiers and reviewing a checklist per ___ protocol. 
The patient was placed on left lateral decubitus on the CT table 
to access the subcutaneous right hip collection.  Under CT 
guidance, an entrance site was selected and the skin was prepped 
and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  5 cc of lidocaine 1% 
was instilled for local anesthesia.  A 5 ___ ___ catheter 
needle was first inserted into the collection where 30 cc of pus 
was removed and sent to microbiology.  Then by a more anterior 
approach with an 18 gauge ___ needle, ___ wire was put 
into the collection and 6 ___ catheter was then inserted. 
Deep sedation was provided by the anesthesia, please refer to 
their note for further detail.  There was no complication after 
the procedure. 
IMPRESSION: 
CT-guided placement of a 6 ___ catheter inside the soft 
tissue abcess 
overlyng the right hip.  Pus was removed from the collection and 
sent to 
microbiology. 
.

Ms. ___ is an ___ with a hx ___ body dementia, AF (not 
on AC), T2DM, who presented with recurrent fevers and R hip 
pain/swelling. She was found to have a R thigh abscess/infected 
bursitis and osteomyelitis of the R femur.  

# R thigh abscess, infected bursitis, osteomyelitis ___ proteus 
Patient developed a right thigh abscess in the setting of a 
large pressure ulcer on the lateral right thigh. Abscess was 
likely present during prior admission (vs. superinfected sp 
bursa bx done on prior admission). Initially, fevers were 
attributed to sacral decubitus ulcer, and ACS was consulted to 
perform a bed-side debridement. Debridement on ___ revealed 
a clean-based sacral ulcer, which did not probe to bone. Given 
this, patient was scheduled to undergo US-guided biopsy of R 
thigh (swollen area on upper right thigh which was previously 
found to contain sterile bursitis). Repeat U/S was concerning 
for possible abscess. Pt underwent CT-guided aspiration of R 
thigh abscess under anesthesia (on ___ and surgical bedside 
debridement of R thigh abscess (on ___. She also underwent 
operative debridement and bone biopsy (on ___. She was treated 
with flagyl (___) and Vancomycin/Cefepime (___). She 
was evaluated by infectious disease and, after tissue culture 
from bone showed proteus growth, she was transitioned to PO 
monotherapy with Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO bid (day 1 = ___ with 
a plan to continue treatment until ___. Nutritional status 
remained tenuous and pt's diet was liberalized. Patient was 
evaluated by S+S, who recommedned ground dysphagia diet until 
re-assessment at a time when pt was able to obtain her dentures. 
Calorie counts were inconsistent but, with family's 
encouragement, pt was able to eat large meals. She was 
discharged with follow-up at Surgery clinic for further 
management of the R thigh wound.

Pt has a Stage IV sacral ulcer. As above, pt underwent

CT FINDINGS: 
Patient is known with a large superficial skin ulceration

communicating between them and going to that ulcer; the more

to the other side.  There is no significant sign of 
osteomyelitis.

anterolisthesis of L4 over L5 measuring 7 mm.

Small and large bowel of the pelvis are unremarkable.  A Foley 
catheter is in the bladder. The uterus is unremarkable.  There 
is a rectal and uterine prolapse. 
PROCEDURE: 
It was decided to aspirate and drain the more superficial 
collection which should be in continuity with the deepest one. 
The procedure risks and benefits and alternatives were discussed 
with the 
patient and written informed consent was obtained.  A 
preprocedure timeout was performed, discussing the planned 
procedure, confirming the patient's identity with three 
identifiers and reviewing a checklist per ___ protocol. 
The patient was placed on left lateral decubitus on the CT table 
to access the subcutaneous right hip collection.  Under CT 
guidance, an entrance site was selected and the skin was prepped 
and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  5 cc of lidocaine 1% 
was instilled for local anesthesia.  A 5 ___ ___ catheter 
needle was first inserted into the collection where 30 cc of pus 
was removed and sent to microbiology.  Then by a more anterior 
approach with an 18 gauge ___ needle, ___ wire was put 
into the collection and 6 ___ catheter was then inserted. 
Deep sedation was provided by the anesthesia, please refer to 
their note for further detail.  There was no complication after 
the procedure. 
IMPRESSION: 
CT-guided placement of a 6 ___ catheter inside the soft 
tissue abcess 
overlyng the right hip.  Pus was removed from the collection and 
sent to 
microbiology. 
.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ with a hx ___ body dementia, AF (not 
on AC), T2DM, who presented with recurrent fevers and R hip 
pain/swelling. She was found to have a R thigh abscess/infected 
bursitis and osteomyelitis of the R femur.  

# R thigh abscess, infected bursitis, osteomyelitis ___ proteus 
Patient developed a right thigh abscess in the setting of a 
large pressure ulcer on the lateral right thigh. Abscess was 
likely present during prior admission (vs. superinfected sp 
bursa bx done on prior admission). Initially, fevers were 
attributed to sacral decubitus ulcer, and ACS was consulted to 
perform a bed-side debridement. Debridement on ___ revealed 
a clean-based sacral ulcer, which did not probe to bone. Given 
this, patient was scheduled to undergo US-guided biopsy of R 
thigh (swollen area on upper right thigh which was previously 
found to contain sterile bursitis). Repeat U/S was concerning 
for possible abscess. Pt underwent CT-guided aspiration of R 
thigh abscess under anesthesia (on ___ and surgical bedside 
debridement of R thigh abscess (on ___. She also underwent 
operative debridement and bone biopsy (on ___. She was treated 
with flagyl (___) and Vancomycin/Cefepime (___). She 
was evaluated by infectious disease and, after tissue culture 
from bone showed proteus growth, she was transitioned to PO 
monotherapy with Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO bid (day 1 = ___ with 
a plan to continue treatment until ___. Nutritional status 
remained tenuous and pt's diet was liberalized. Patient was 
evaluated by S+S, who recommedned ground dysphagia diet until 
re-assessment at a time when pt was able to obtain her dentures. 
Calorie counts were inconsistent but, with family's 
encouragement, pt was able to eat large meals. She was 
discharged with follow-up at Surgery clinic for further 
management of the R thigh wound.

Pt has a Stage IV sacral ulcer. As above, pt underwent

recommended instructions for care of the ulcer on discharge.

effusions are present on this side. 
LEFT KNEE: AP views of the left knee is somewhat limited.  
Marked degenerative changes with almost complete loss of the 
joint space are present in the medial compartment and marked 
narrowing in the lateral compartment is also present. In all 
other areas degenerative changes are present.  No effusion is 
identified.  No areas of erosion are seen. 
IMPRESSION:  Severe degenerative changes.  No evidence of 
osteomyelitis. 
.
RLE US ___:
FINDINGS: 
In the skin overlying the right hip, there is a large 
superficial skin 
ulceration with purulent material draining from it.  
Just deep to this ulcer, there is a large fluid collection that 
appears 
densely packed with echogenic mobile debris.  Its margins are 
difficult to delineate with the ultrasound probe that is 
available.  At the periphery of this fluid collection there is 
an anechoic fluid collection, which may correspond to the bursa. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
The findings are most compatible with an abscess deep to a skin 
ulcer in the right buttock region.  The extent of this fluid 
collection should be better characterized with cross sectional 
imaging, after which, aspiration can be performed.   
.
CT-GUIDED ABSCESS DRAINAGE ___:
CT FINDINGS: 
Patient is known with a large superficial skin ulceration 
overlying the right hip.  Underneath this ulceration there are 
two linear collections 
communicating between them and going to that ulcer; the more 
superficial one contains a fat-fluid level and measures 11.5 x 
2.4 cm; the deepest one measures 13 x 2.4 cm, the collection is 
in the subcutaneous fat and goes up to the gluteus muscle.  
There is also a small collection in the anterior portion of the 
right maximus gluteus muscle (series 3, image 38) measuring 17 x 
27 mm. The greater trochanter lies just beneath the collection.  
There is minimal irregularity of the cortex but which is similar 
to the other side.  There is no significant sign of 
osteomyelitis. 
There is significant degenerative change of the spine with 
anterolisthesis of L4 over L5 measuring 7 mm. 
Multiple gallstones are seen without sign of cholecystitis.  
Small and large bowel of the pelvis are unremarkable.  A Foley 
catheter is in the bladder. The uterus is unremarkable.  There 
is a rectal and uterine prolapse. 
PROCEDURE: 
It was decided to aspirate and drain the more superficial 
collection which should be in continuity with the deepest one. 
The procedure risks and benefits and alternatives were discussed 
with the 
patient and written informed consent was obtained.  A 
preprocedure timeout was performed, discussing the planned 
procedure, confirming the patient's identity with three 
identifiers and reviewing a checklist per ___ protocol. 
The patient was placed on left lateral decubitus on the CT table 
to access the subcutaneous right hip collection.  Under CT 
guidance, an entrance site was selected and the skin was prepped 
and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  5 cc of lidocaine 1% 
was instilled for local anesthesia.  A 5 ___ ___ catheter 
needle was first inserted into the collection where 30 cc of pus 
was removed and sent to microbiology.  Then by a more anterior 
approach with an 18 gauge ___ needle, ___ wire was put 
into the collection and 6 ___ catheter was then inserted. 
Deep sedation was provided by the anesthesia, please refer to 
their note for further detail.  There was no complication after 
the procedure. 
IMPRESSION: 
CT-guided placement of a 6 ___ catheter inside the soft 
tissue abcess 
overlyng the right hip.  Pus was removed from the collection and 
sent to 
microbiology. 
.
PATHOLOGY OF NECROTIC R HIP TISSUE ___: Skin with ulceration 
and gangrenous necrosis of dermal and subcutaneous soft tissues.
.
CXR ___:
New right subclavian line ends in the mid SVC.  No pneumothorax, 
pleural 
effusion or mediastinal widening.  Mild leftward mediastinal 
shift 
unexplained, since both lungs are well expanded and clear and 
there is no 
pneumothorax or effusion on the right.  Heart size normal. The 
study and the report were reviewed by the staff radiologist. 
.
CXR ___:
FINDINGS:  In comparison with study of ___, there is little 
interval change. Specifically, there is no evidence of pneumonia 
following central line removal. There are low lung volumes, but 
no evidence of acute pneumonia or vascular congestion. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ with a hx ___ body dementia, AF (not 
on AC), T2DM, who presented with recurrent fevers and R hip 
pain/swelling. She was found to have a R thigh abscess/infected 
bursitis and osteomyelitis of the R femur.  

# R thigh abscess, infected bursitis, osteomyelitis ___ proteus 
Patient developed a right thigh abscess in the setting of a 
large pressure ulcer on the lateral right thigh. Abscess was 
likely present during prior admission (vs. superinfected sp 
bursa bx done on prior admission). Initially, fevers were 
attributed to sacral decubitus ulcer, and ACS was consulted to 
perform a bed-side debridement. Debridement on ___ revealed 
a clean-based sacral ulcer, which did not probe to bone. Given 
this, patient was scheduled to undergo US-guided biopsy of R 
thigh (swollen area on upper right thigh which was previously 
found to contain sterile bursitis). Repeat U/S was concerning 
for possible abscess. Pt underwent CT-guided aspiration of R 
thigh abscess under anesthesia (on ___ and surgical bedside 
debridement of R thigh abscess (on ___. She also underwent 
operative debridement and bone biopsy (on ___. She was treated 
with flagyl (___) and Vancomycin/Cefepime (___). She 
was evaluated by infectious disease and, after tissue culture 
from bone showed proteus growth, she was transitioned to PO 
monotherapy with Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO bid (day 1 = ___ with 
a plan to continue treatment until ___. Nutritional status 
remained tenuous and pt's diet was liberalized. Patient was 
evaluated by S+S, who recommedned ground dysphagia diet until 
re-assessment at a time when pt was able to obtain her dentures. 
Calorie counts were inconsistent but, with family's 
encouragement, pt was able to eat large meals. She was 
discharged with follow-up at Surgery clinic for further 
management of the R thigh wound. 
 
# Sacral Decubitus Ulcer
Pt has a Stage IV sacral ulcer. As above, pt underwent 
debridement by ACS on ___. Wound care nursing was consulted and 
recommended instructions for care of the ulcer on discharge.  

# Chronic Normocytic Anemia: 
HCT is slightly below baseline (30s to low ___. There were no 
signs of active bleeding. 
  
# Dementia:
Pt was A+Ox2.5 but intermittently not responsive during 
interview. She was more readily responsive when family was at 
bedside. Mental status was at baseline per family. We continued 
Quetiapine and Oxcarbamazepine during this admission. 

# Well-controlled DM without complications: 
FSG was well-controlled during admission. Continued pt's home 
Lantus and HISS.   

# Atrial fibrillation: 
CHADS score is ___ (pt has hx of CVA). She has not been 
anticoagulation as it is currently thought that afib has 
resolved. Digoxin and ASA were continued.

# Hypercholesterolemia: Continued atorvastatin 10mg po qd  

# CAD: Continued ASA 81 mg daily  

# GERD: Continued omeprazole 40mg po qd

___ CT head noncontrast: There is a 2.7 x 1.3 cm right frontal 
intraparenchymal hemorrhage with surrounding edema.  There are 
small bilateral bifrontal subdural hemorrhages measuring 
approximately 4 mm in maximal thickness on the right and 3 mm on 
the left.  
There is no significant mass effect, including no shift of the 
midline 
structures.  The basilar cisterns are patent.  The ventricles 
and sulci remain prominent consistent with atrophy.  There is 
periventricular white matter hypodensity consistent with chronic 
small vessel ischemic disease.  There is mild mucosal thickening 
of the maxillary sinuses bilaterally.   There are no acute 
fractures.  Calcifications are noted within the globes 
bilaterally.  There are dense vascular calcifications.  

___ Pelvis and additional views of right hip Xray: IMPRESSION:  
No acute fracture or evidence of hardware complication.

___ CXR: no acute process, Single supine view of the chest.  The 
lungs are clear without focal consolidation.  Left costophrenic 
angle is excluded from the field of view.  There is no obvious 
effusion.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette is within normal limits. 
 Median sternotomy wires and mediastinal clips are again noted.  
No acute osseous abnormality is identified. 

___ ECHO: Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of 
___, regional (inferior) LV systolic function has 
improved. The left atrium is normal in size. No atrial septal 
defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall 
thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional 
left ventricular systolic dysfunction with basal inerior 
hypokinesis. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left 
ventricle. There is no left ventricular outflow obstruction at 
rest or with Valsalva. There is no ventricular septal defect. 
Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. 
The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels 
are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened 
but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic regurgitation 
is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild 
(1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. 

___ Carotid Duplex: IMPRESSION: 40-59% stenosis in the right 
internal carotid artery and less than 40% stenosis in the left 
internal carotid artery. 

___ CT head: Stable right frontal intraparenchymal hemorrhage 
with progression of left frontal intraparenchymal hemorrhage 
with more surrounding edema and sulcal effacement.  No evidence 
of midline shift. Stable bifrontal subdural hematomas. 

___ CT head: No change in size of bilateral frontal hemorrhagic 
contusions 
with surrounding edema. Stable bifrontal SDH.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ was admitted to the Neurosurgery service for 
frequent neuro checks and blood pressure control in the setting 
of bifrontal contusions and SDHs after a syncopal fall.  She was 
transfused with 1 unit of plts given the extensive contusions on 
Aspirin therapy.  The nephrology service was consulted given her 
hx of renal transplant and they contributed to her management 
directing immunosuppressive agents.  She was started on Dilantin 
for seizure prophylaxis but switched to  Keppra 500mg BID at the 
direction of nephrology as dilantin can alter Tacrolimus 
metabolism by the liver.  Neurologically she remained stable 
however on ___ repeat head CT showed mild blossoming of the 
frontal contusions.  Cardiac ECHO and carotid dopplers were 
perform in addition to EKG for her syncopal work up without any 
evidence of cardiogenic or vascular cause of syncope.  

She remained stable on ___.  Tacrolimus dosing was changed under 
direction of Nephrology based on a tacrolimus level of 3.8.

On ___ repeat head CT was stable.  She was seen and evaluated by 
___ who felt that she was safe to return home.  SW was 
consulted given the patient's new diagnosis of TBI and ___ was 
arranged for a home safety evaluation in the setting of her new 
TBI and pre-existing blindness.  

At the time of discharge she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating with the aid of her seeing eye dog, afebrile with 
stable vitals.

•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.

Ibuprofen etc.

•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
•New onset of the loss of function, or decrease of function on 
one whole side of your body.

frequent neuro checks and blood pressure control in the setting 
of bifrontal contusions and SDHs after a syncopal fall.  She was 
transfused with 1 unit of plts given the extensive contusions on

hx of renal transplant and they contributed to her management 
directing immunosuppressive agents.  She was started on Dilantin

frontal contusions.  Cardiac ECHO and carotid dopplers were

ambulating with the aid of her seeing eye dog, afebrile with 
stable vitals.

Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left frontal intraparanchymal hemorrhage

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.
General Instructions

•Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, or 
Ibuprofen etc. 
•You were taking Aspirin prior to your injury, you may safely 
resume taking this on ___.
 

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

•New onset of tremors or seizures.
•Any confusion, lethargy or change in mental status. 
•Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
•New onset of the loss of function, or decrease of function on 
one whole side of your body.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Mrs. ___ was admitted to the Neurosurgery service for 
frequent neuro checks and blood pressure control in the setting 
of bifrontal contusions and SDHs after a syncopal fall.  She was 
transfused with 1 unit of plts given the extensive contusions on 
Aspirin therapy.  The nephrology service was consulted given her 
hx of renal transplant and they contributed to her management 
directing immunosuppressive agents.  She was started on Dilantin 
for seizure prophylaxis but switched to  Keppra 500mg BID at the 
direction of nephrology as dilantin can alter Tacrolimus 
metabolism by the liver.  Neurologically she remained stable 
however on ___ repeat head CT showed mild blossoming of the 
frontal contusions.  Cardiac ECHO and carotid dopplers were 
perform in addition to EKG for her syncopal work up without any 
evidence of cardiogenic or vascular cause of syncope.

direction of Nephrology based on a tacrolimus level of 3.8.

___ who felt that she was safe to return home.  SW was 
consulted given the patient's new diagnosis of TBI and ___ was 
arranged for a home safety evaluation in the setting of her new 
TBI and pre-existing blindness.  

At the time of discharge she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating with the aid of her seeing eye dog, afebrile with 
stable vitals.

Discharge Instructions:
Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.
General Instructions

•Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, or 
Ibuprofen etc. 
•You were taking Aspirin prior to your injury, you may safely 
resume taking this on ___.
 

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

•New onset of tremors or seizures.
•Any confusion, lethargy or change in mental status. 
•Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
•New onset of the loss of function, or decrease of function on 
one whole side of your body.
