Brief Hospital Course:
HOSPITAL COURSE
This is a ___ year old gentleman with complex medical issues, 
including recent hospitalization for medically managed 
cholecystitis, presenting with chest pain, found to be in atrial 
fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and admitted to 
Medicine. Patient was transferred to the CCU for monitoring 
after pericardiocentesis (no tamponade physiology on echo, 
procedure performed for diagnostic purposes), who subsequently 
developed fever and hypotension requiring pressure support with 
phenylephrine. He ultimately opted for re-focus of medical 
management to pain management and positioning therapy and was 
discharged to a rehabilitation facility.
.
ACTIVE ISSUES
# GOALS OF CARE: After significant discussion with both his 
family and his medical providers the patient voiced his desire 
for re-focus of his medical management to control of his pain, 
and focus on comfort. These discussions arose in the setting of 
initiation of permanent dialysis and prolonged and profound 
physical and emotional decompensation. The patient stated he 
understood that termination of dialysis would not be compatible 
with life. The patient was transferred to a rehabilitation 
facility for management of pain and positioning therapy.
.
# PERICARDIAL EFFUSION: Echo performed on admission demonstrated 
large circumferential pericardial effusion, no evidence of 
tamponade. Since the patient had been having transient episodes 
of hypotension during HD sessions, and in order to better 
clarify the etiology of the pericardial fluid, a 
pericardiocentesis was performed. Per report, 260 cc of yellow 
serous fluid was removed. Two hours post-procedure the patient 
became hypotensive, initially responding to fluid boluses, then 
requiring Neo for pressure support. He was pan-cultured and 
started on broad antibiotics- vancomycin, cefepime and 
metronidazole. It was noted that his pericardial fluid changed 
in nature from serous to cloudy pink thick fluid. He then became 
febrile, and received more volume resuscitation for likely 
septic shock.  Studies were consistent with an exudative 
effusion and culture grew vancomycin resistant enterococcus. 
Broad spectrum antibiotics were discontinued and daptomycin was 
started. The source remained unclear, given nothing on imaging 
to support contiguous spread, and highly unlikely that the 
procedure introduced the organism. Furthermore, blood and urine 
cultures were negative throughout his hospital stay. A TEE was 
negative for evidence of valvular vegetations. Repeat imaging 
showed the effusion was resolved and the pericardial drain was 
removed. He was treated with a 5 day course of Daptomycin before 
antibiotics were discontinued on discharge following the wishes 
of the patient.
.
# HYPOTENSION: The patient was noted to be hypotensive on 
admission, thought to be secondary to hypovolemia from poor PO 
intake. He also had a recent history of transient hypotension 
during hemodialysis for which he was started on midodrine. 
Echocardiogram revealed an enlarged pericardial effusion 
(details above). Post-pericardiocentesis the patient was treated 
with fluid resuscitation and broad antibiotics for presumed 
septic shock. His blood pressure was supported with 
phenylephrine. A ___ test was negative for adrenal 
insufficiency.  Additionally, albumin of 1.7 so likely has poor 
intravascular osmotic pressure. Given his history of recent 
medically-managed cholecystitis, and known intra-abdominal fluid 
collections, a CT torso was obtained to investigate potential 
sources of infection. His HD catheter was removed. Surgery was 
consulted to investigate possible cholecystitis (details below), 
and ___ performed a drainage of an intraabdominal fluid 
collection, a hematoma. Serial blood and urine cultures were 
negative. His hypotension resolved, and he was weaned off 
phenylephrine prior to discharge. His midodrine was increased to 
5 TID. Medical management was discontinued as the patient 
declined further medical management.
.  
# SUSPECTED CHOLECYSTITIS: The patient had a recent history of 
medically-managed cholecystitis. On admission he was initially 
treated with broad spectrum antibiotics, which were then 
narrowed to Levaquin. Given our clinical concern for sepsis, a 
RUQ ultrasound was obtained and demonstrated a sludge-filled 
gallbladder and a small, unchanged fluid collection. CT torso 
demonstrated stranding, concerning for acute cholecystitis. 
Surgery was consulted and recommended HIDA scan given low 
suspicion on physical exam. HIDA scan was positive and a 
percutaneous drain was attempted; however, the procedure was 
complicated by collapse of the gallbladder (inconsistent with 
acute cholecystitis) and development of a small hematoma. A 
drain was placed in the abdominal fluid collection, which 
appeared to be an old hematoma. Microbiology was sent and was 
negative for growth. The drain was removed.  
.
# ESRD on HD: The patient normally receives HD on ___. 
Renal was consulted. HD initially was on hold given new pressor 
requirement and stable electrolytes. Given concern for sepsis, 
the tunneled dialysis catheter was removed and replaced with a 
temporary catheter. Once stable, the patient received CVVH with 
phenylephrine for pressure support. Culture of the catheter tip 
revealed no growth. A permanent catheter was not placed as the 
patient declined further dialysis.
.
# ATRIAL FIBRILLATION with RAPID VENTRICULAR RESPONSE: Present 
on admission. The patient spontaneously cardioverted and 
remained in sinus for the rest of his admission. The patient has 
___ S2 score of 3; however, given his history of 
intraabdominal hematomas, we elected to continue aspirin 325 for 
anticoagulation. Medical management was discontinued as the 
patient declined further medical management.
.
# CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE: Presented with CP in setting of AF 
with RVR, found to have ST changes and elevated troponin 
consistent with demand ischemia. Enzymes were cycled and the 
patient ruled out for an acute myocardial infarction. We 
continued his aspirin and statin. Medical management was 
discontinued as the patient declined further medical management.
.
# ANEMIA: No evidence of acute bleeding. Likely secondary to 
chronic inflammation. Is on Aranesp as outpatient. Hct trended 
down initially on admission and was stable around 20 at the time 
of discharge. He required a transfusion of 1 unit of pRBCs with 
appropriate response.
.  
# THROMBOCYTOPENIA: Relatively stable. Unclear etiology, 
reportedly has chronic ITP, and is status post splenectomy.  
.
# PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY: Continued on gabapentin 100 qhs. 
Medical management was discontinued as the patient declined 
further medical management.
.
# GASTROPARESIS: Continued on metoclopramide 5 mg PO QIDACHS. 
Medical management was discontinued as the patient declined 
further medical management.
.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- ___ Management: Management of pain and optimization of 
positional comfort.
- Pending Studies: Pericardial and Abdominal Fluid Cytology, 
finalized culture data
- Code Status: DNR/DNI, do not resuscitate.

Brief Hospital Course:
HOSPITAL COURSE
This is a ___ year old gentleman with complex medical issues, 
including recent hospitalization for medically managed 
cholecystitis, presenting with chest pain, found to be in atrial 
fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and admitted to 
Medicine. Patient was transferred to the CCU for monitoring 
after pericardiocentesis (no tamponade physiology on echo, 
procedure performed for diagnostic purposes), who subsequently 
developed fever and hypotension requiring pressure support with 
phenylephrine. He ultimately opted for re-focus of medical 
management to pain management and positioning therapy and was 
discharged to a rehabilitation facility.
.
ACTIVE ISSUES
# GOALS OF CARE: After significant discussion with both his 
family and his medical providers the patient voiced his desire 
for re-focus of his medical management to control of his pain, 
and focus on comfort. These discussions arose in the setting of 
initiation of permanent dialysis and prolonged and profound 
physical and emotional decompensation. The patient stated he 
understood that termination of dialysis would not be compatible 
with life. The patient was transferred to a rehabilitation 
facility for management of pain and positioning therapy.
.
# PERICARDIAL EFFUSION: Echo performed on admission demonstrated 
large circumferential pericardial effusion, no evidence of 
tamponade. Since the patient had been having transient episodes 
of hypotension during HD sessions, and in order to better 
clarify the etiology of the pericardial fluid, a 
pericardiocentesis was performed. Per report, 260 cc of yellow 
serous fluid was removed. Two hours post-procedure the patient 
became hypotensive, initially responding to fluid boluses, then 
requiring Neo for pressure support. He was pan-cultured and 
started on broad antibiotics- vancomycin, cefepime and 
metronidazole. It was noted that his pericardial fluid changed 
in nature from serous to cloudy pink thick fluid. He then became 
febrile, and received more volume resuscitation for likely 
septic shock.  Studies were consistent with an exudative 
effusion and culture grew vancomycin resistant enterococcus. 
Broad spectrum antibiotics were discontinued and daptomycin was 
started. The source remained unclear, given nothing on imaging 
to support contiguous spread, and highly unlikely that the 
procedure introduced the organism. Furthermore, blood and urine 
cultures were negative throughout his hospital stay. A TEE was 
negative for evidence of valvular vegetations. Repeat imaging 
showed the effusion was resolved and the pericardial drain was 
removed. He was treated with a 5 day course of Daptomycin before 
antibiotics were discontinued on discharge following the wishes 
of the patient.
.
# HYPOTENSION: The patient was noted to be hypotensive on 
admission, thought to be secondary to hypovolemia from poor PO 
intake. He also had a recent history of transient hypotension 
during hemodialysis for which he was started on midodrine. 
Echocardiogram revealed an enlarged pericardial effusion 
(details above). Post-pericardiocentesis the patient was treated 
with fluid resuscitation and broad antibiotics for presumed 
septic shock. His blood pressure was supported with 
phenylephrine. A ___ test was negative for adrenal 
insufficiency.  Additionally, albumin of 1.7 so likely has poor 
intravascular osmotic pressure. Given his history of recent 
medically-managed cholecystitis, and known intra-abdominal fluid 
collections, a CT torso was obtained to investigate potential 
sources of infection. His HD catheter was removed. Surgery was 
consulted to investigate possible cholecystitis (details below), 
and ___ performed a drainage of an intraabdominal fluid 
collection, a hematoma. Serial blood and urine cultures were 
negative. His hypotension resolved, and he was weaned off 
phenylephrine prior to discharge. His midodrine was increased to 
5 TID. Medical management was discontinued as the patient 
declined further medical management.
.  
# SUSPECTED CHOLECYSTITIS: The patient had a recent history of 
medically-managed cholecystitis. On admission he was initially 
treated with broad spectrum antibiotics, which were then 
narrowed to Levaquin. Given our clinical concern for sepsis, a 
RUQ ultrasound was obtained and demonstrated a sludge-filled 
gallbladder and a small, unchanged fluid collection. CT torso 
demonstrated stranding, concerning for acute cholecystitis. 
Surgery was consulted and recommended HIDA scan given low 
suspicion on physical exam. HIDA scan was positive and a 
percutaneous drain was attempted; however, the procedure was 
complicated by collapse of the gallbladder (inconsistent with 
acute cholecystitis) and development of a small hematoma. A 
drain was placed in the abdominal fluid collection, which 
appeared to be an old hematoma. Microbiology was sent and was 
negative for growth. The drain was removed.  
.
# ESRD on HD: The patient normally receives HD on ___. 
Renal was consulted. HD initially was on hold given new pressor 
requirement and stable electrolytes. Given concern for sepsis, 
the tunneled dialysis catheter was removed and replaced with a 
temporary catheter. Once stable, the patient received CVVH with 
phenylephrine for pressure support. Culture of the catheter tip 
revealed no growth. A permanent catheter was not placed as the 
patient declined further dialysis.
.
# ATRIAL FIBRILLATION with RAPID VENTRICULAR RESPONSE: Present 
on admission. The patient spontaneously cardioverted and 
remained in sinus for the rest of his admission. The patient has 
___ S2 score of 3; however, given his history of 
intraabdominal hematomas, we elected to continue aspirin 325 for 
anticoagulation. Medical management was discontinued as the 
patient declined further medical management.
.
# CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE: Presented with CP in setting of AF 
with RVR, found to have ST changes and elevated troponin 
consistent with demand ischemia. Enzymes were cycled and the 
patient ruled out for an acute myocardial infarction. We 
continued his aspirin and statin. Medical management was 
discontinued as the patient declined further medical management.
.
# ANEMIA: No evidence of acute bleeding. Likely secondary to 
chronic inflammation. Is on Aranesp as outpatient. Hct trended 
down initially on admission and was stable around 20 at the time 
of discharge. He required a transfusion of 1 unit of pRBCs with 
appropriate response.
.  
# THROMBOCYTOPENIA: Relatively stable. Unclear etiology, 
reportedly has chronic ITP, and is status post splenectomy.  
.
# PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY: Continued on gabapentin 100 qhs. 
Medical management was discontinued as the patient declined 
further medical management.
.
# GASTROPARESIS: Continued on metoclopramide 5 mg PO QIDACHS. 
Medical management was discontinued as the patient declined 
further medical management.
.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- ___ Management: Management of pain and optimization of 
positional comfort.
- Pending Studies: Pericardial and Abdominal Fluid Cytology, 
finalized culture data
- Code Status: DNR/DNI, do not resuscitate.

Brief Hospital Course:
HOSPITAL COURSE
This is a ___ year old gentleman with complex medical issues, 
including recent hospitalization for medically managed 
cholecystitis, presenting with chest pain, found to be in atrial 
fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and admitted to 
Medicine. Patient was transferred to the CCU for monitoring 
after pericardiocentesis (no tamponade physiology on echo, 
procedure performed for diagnostic purposes), who subsequently 
developed fever and hypotension requiring pressure support with 
phenylephrine. He ultimately opted for re-focus of medical 
management to pain management and positioning therapy and was 
discharged to a rehabilitation facility.
.
ACTIVE ISSUES
# GOALS OF CARE: After significant discussion with both his 
family and his medical providers the patient voiced his desire 
for re-focus of his medical management to control of his pain, 
and focus on comfort. These discussions arose in the setting of 
initiation of permanent dialysis and prolonged and profound 
physical and emotional decompensation. The patient stated he 
understood that termination of dialysis would not be compatible 
with life. The patient was transferred to a rehabilitation 
facility for management of pain and positioning therapy.
.
# PERICARDIAL EFFUSION: Echo performed on admission demonstrated 
large circumferential pericardial effusion, no evidence of 
tamponade. Since the patient had been having transient episodes 
of hypotension during HD sessions, and in order to better 
clarify the etiology of the pericardial fluid, a 
pericardiocentesis was performed. Per report, 260 cc of yellow 
serous fluid was removed. Two hours post-procedure the patient 
became hypotensive, initially responding to fluid boluses, then 
requiring Neo for pressure support. He was pan-cultured and 
started on broad antibiotics- vancomycin, cefepime and 
metronidazole. It was noted that his pericardial fluid changed 
in nature from serous to cloudy pink thick fluid. He then became 
febrile, and received more volume resuscitation for likely 
septic shock.  Studies were consistent with an exudative 
effusion and culture grew vancomycin resistant enterococcus. 
Broad spectrum antibiotics were discontinued and daptomycin was 
started. The source remained unclear, given nothing on imaging 
to support contiguous spread, and highly unlikely that the 
procedure introduced the organism. Furthermore, blood and urine 
cultures were negative throughout his hospital stay. A TEE was 
negative for evidence of valvular vegetations. Repeat imaging 
showed the effusion was resolved and the pericardial drain was 
removed. He was treated with a 5 day course of Daptomycin before 
antibiotics were discontinued on discharge following the wishes 
of the patient.
.
# HYPOTENSION: The patient was noted to be hypotensive on 
admission, thought to be secondary to hypovolemia from poor PO 
intake. He also had a recent history of transient hypotension 
during hemodialysis for which he was started on midodrine. 
Echocardiogram revealed an enlarged pericardial effusion 
(details above). Post-pericardiocentesis the patient was treated 
with fluid resuscitation and broad antibiotics for presumed 
septic shock. His blood pressure was supported with 
phenylephrine. A ___ test was negative for adrenal 
insufficiency.  Additionally, albumin of 1.7 so likely has poor 
intravascular osmotic pressure. Given his history of recent 
medically-managed cholecystitis, and known intra-abdominal fluid 
collections, a CT torso was obtained to investigate potential 
sources of infection. His HD catheter was removed. Surgery was 
consulted to investigate possible cholecystitis (details below), 
and ___ performed a drainage of an intraabdominal fluid 
collection, a hematoma. Serial blood and urine cultures were 
negative. His hypotension resolved, and he was weaned off 
phenylephrine prior to discharge. His midodrine was increased to 
5 TID. Medical management was discontinued as the patient 
declined further medical management.
.  
# SUSPECTED CHOLECYSTITIS: The patient had a recent history of 
medically-managed cholecystitis. On admission he was initially 
treated with broad spectrum antibiotics, which were then 
narrowed to Levaquin. Given our clinical concern for sepsis, a 
RUQ ultrasound was obtained and demonstrated a sludge-filled 
gallbladder and a small, unchanged fluid collection. CT torso 
demonstrated stranding, concerning for acute cholecystitis. 
Surgery was consulted and recommended HIDA scan given low 
suspicion on physical exam. HIDA scan was positive and a 
percutaneous drain was attempted; however, the procedure was 
complicated by collapse of the gallbladder (inconsistent with 
acute cholecystitis) and development of a small hematoma. A 
drain was placed in the abdominal fluid collection, which 
appeared to be an old hematoma. Microbiology was sent and was 
negative for growth. The drain was removed.  
.
# ESRD on HD: The patient normally receives HD on ___. 
Renal was consulted. HD initially was on hold given new pressor 
requirement and stable electrolytes. Given concern for sepsis, 
the tunneled dialysis catheter was removed and replaced with a 
temporary catheter. Once stable, the patient received CVVH with 
phenylephrine for pressure support. Culture of the catheter tip 
revealed no growth. A permanent catheter was not placed as the 
patient declined further dialysis.
.
# ATRIAL FIBRILLATION with RAPID VENTRICULAR RESPONSE: Present 
on admission. The patient spontaneously cardioverted and 
remained in sinus for the rest of his admission. The patient has 
___ S2 score of 3; however, given his history of 
intraabdominal hematomas, we elected to continue aspirin 325 for 
anticoagulation. Medical management was discontinued as the 
patient declined further medical management.
.
# CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE: Presented with CP in setting of AF 
with RVR, found to have ST changes and elevated troponin 
consistent with demand ischemia. Enzymes were cycled and the 
patient ruled out for an acute myocardial infarction. We 
continued his aspirin and statin. Medical management was 
discontinued as the patient declined further medical management.
.
# ANEMIA: No evidence of acute bleeding. Likely secondary to 
chronic inflammation. Is on Aranesp as outpatient. Hct trended 
down initially on admission and was stable around 20 at the time 
of discharge. He required a transfusion of 1 unit of pRBCs with 
appropriate response.
.  
# THROMBOCYTOPENIA: Relatively stable. Unclear etiology, 
reportedly has chronic ITP, and is status post splenectomy.  
.
# PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY: Continued on gabapentin 100 qhs. 
Medical management was discontinued as the patient declined 
further medical management.
.
# GASTROPARESIS: Continued on metoclopramide 5 mg PO QIDACHS. 
Medical management was discontinued as the patient declined 
further medical management.
.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- ___ Management: Management of pain and optimization of 
positional comfort.
- Pending Studies: Pericardial and Abdominal Fluid Cytology, 
finalized culture data
- Code Status: DNR/DNI, do not resuscitate.

Brief Hospital Course:
HOSPITAL COURSE
This is a ___ year old gentleman with complex medical issues, 
including recent hospitalization for medically managed 
cholecystitis, presenting with chest pain, found to be in atrial 
fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and admitted to 
Medicine. Patient was transferred to the CCU for monitoring 
after pericardiocentesis (no tamponade physiology on echo, 
procedure performed for diagnostic purposes), who subsequently 
developed fever and hypotension requiring pressure support with 
phenylephrine. He ultimately opted for re-focus of medical 
management to pain management and positioning therapy and was 
discharged to a rehabilitation facility.
.
ACTIVE ISSUES
# GOALS OF CARE: After significant discussion with both his 
family and his medical providers the patient voiced his desire 
for re-focus of his medical management to control of his pain, 
and focus on comfort. These discussions arose in the setting of 
initiation of permanent dialysis and prolonged and profound 
physical and emotional decompensation. The patient stated he 
understood that termination of dialysis would not be compatible 
with life. The patient was transferred to a rehabilitation 
facility for management of pain and positioning therapy.
.
# PERICARDIAL EFFUSION: Echo performed on admission demonstrated 
large circumferential pericardial effusion, no evidence of 
tamponade. Since the patient had been having transient episodes 
of hypotension during HD sessions, and in order to better 
clarify the etiology of the pericardial fluid, a 
pericardiocentesis was performed. Per report, 260 cc of yellow 
serous fluid was removed. Two hours post-procedure the patient 
became hypotensive, initially responding to fluid boluses, then 
requiring Neo for pressure support. He was pan-cultured and 
started on broad antibiotics- vancomycin, cefepime and 
metronidazole. It was noted that his pericardial fluid changed 
in nature from serous to cloudy pink thick fluid. He then became 
febrile, and received more volume resuscitation for likely 
septic shock.  Studies were consistent with an exudative 
effusion and culture grew vancomycin resistant enterococcus. 
Broad spectrum antibiotics were discontinued and daptomycin was 
started. The source remained unclear, given nothing on imaging 
to support contiguous spread, and highly unlikely that the 
procedure introduced the organism. Furthermore, blood and urine 
cultures were negative throughout his hospital stay. A TEE was 
negative for evidence of valvular vegetations. Repeat imaging 
showed the effusion was resolved and the pericardial drain was 
removed. He was treated with a 5 day course of Daptomycin before 
antibiotics were discontinued on discharge following the wishes 
of the patient.
.
# HYPOTENSION: The patient was noted to be hypotensive on 
admission, thought to be secondary to hypovolemia from poor PO 
intake. He also had a recent history of transient hypotension 
during hemodialysis for which he was started on midodrine. 
Echocardiogram revealed an enlarged pericardial effusion 
(details above). Post-pericardiocentesis the patient was treated 
with fluid resuscitation and broad antibiotics for presumed 
septic shock. His blood pressure was supported with 
phenylephrine. A ___ test was negative for adrenal 
insufficiency.  Additionally, albumin of 1.7 so likely has poor 
intravascular osmotic pressure. Given his history of recent 
medically-managed cholecystitis, and known intra-abdominal fluid 
collections, a CT torso was obtained to investigate potential 
sources of infection. His HD catheter was removed. Surgery was 
consulted to investigate possible cholecystitis (details below), 
and ___ performed a drainage of an intraabdominal fluid 
collection, a hematoma. Serial blood and urine cultures were 
negative. His hypotension resolved, and he was weaned off 
phenylephrine prior to discharge. His midodrine was increased to 
5 TID. Medical management was discontinued as the patient 
declined further medical management.
.  
# SUSPECTED CHOLECYSTITIS: The patient had a recent history of 
medically-managed cholecystitis. On admission he was initially 
treated with broad spectrum antibiotics, which were then 
narrowed to Levaquin. Given our clinical concern for sepsis, a 
RUQ ultrasound was obtained and demonstrated a sludge-filled 
gallbladder and a small, unchanged fluid collection. CT torso 
demonstrated stranding, concerning for acute cholecystitis. 
Surgery was consulted and recommended HIDA scan given low 
suspicion on physical exam. HIDA scan was positive and a 
percutaneous drain was attempted; however, the procedure was 
complicated by collapse of the gallbladder (inconsistent with 
acute cholecystitis) and development of a small hematoma. A 
drain was placed in the abdominal fluid collection, which 
appeared to be an old hematoma. Microbiology was sent and was 
negative for growth. The drain was removed.  
.
# ESRD on HD: The patient normally receives HD on ___. 
Renal was consulted. HD initially was on hold given new pressor 
requirement and stable electrolytes. Given concern for sepsis, 
the tunneled dialysis catheter was removed and replaced with a 
temporary catheter. Once stable, the patient received CVVH with 
phenylephrine for pressure support. Culture of the catheter tip 
revealed no growth. A permanent catheter was not placed as the 
patient declined further dialysis.
.
# ATRIAL FIBRILLATION with RAPID VENTRICULAR RESPONSE: Present 
on admission. The patient spontaneously cardioverted and 
remained in sinus for the rest of his admission. The patient has 
___ S2 score of 3; however, given his history of 
intraabdominal hematomas, we elected to continue aspirin 325 for 
anticoagulation. Medical management was discontinued as the 
patient declined further medical management.
.
# CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE: Presented with CP in setting of AF 
with RVR, found to have ST changes and elevated troponin 
consistent with demand ischemia. Enzymes were cycled and the 
patient ruled out for an acute myocardial infarction. We 
continued his aspirin and statin. Medical management was 
discontinued as the patient declined further medical management.
.
# ANEMIA: No evidence of acute bleeding. Likely secondary to 
chronic inflammation. Is on Aranesp as outpatient. Hct trended 
down initially on admission and was stable around 20 at the time 
of discharge. He required a transfusion of 1 unit of pRBCs with 
appropriate response.
.  
# THROMBOCYTOPENIA: Relatively stable. Unclear etiology, 
reportedly has chronic ITP, and is status post splenectomy.  
.
# PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY: Continued on gabapentin 100 qhs. 
Medical management was discontinued as the patient declined 
further medical management.
.
# GASTROPARESIS: Continued on metoclopramide 5 mg PO QIDACHS. 
Medical management was discontinued as the patient declined 
further medical management.
.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- ___ Management: Management of pain and optimization of 
positional comfort.
- Pending Studies: Pericardial and Abdominal Fluid Cytology, 
finalized culture data
- Code Status: DNR/DNI, do not resuscitate.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
History of liver transplant
Chest pain: resolved
Hypertension
Weight loss

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call the transplant clinic at ___ for fever of 
101 or greater, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, 
constipation, inability to tolerate food, fluids or medications, 
yellowing of skin or eyes, increased abdominal pain, incisional 
redness, drainage or bleeding, dizziness or weakness, decreased 
urine output or dark, cloudy urine, swelling of abdomen or 
ankles, weight gain of 3 pounds in a day or any other concerning 
symptoms.
.
Bring your pill box and list of current medications to every 
clinic visit.
.
You will have labwork drawn twice weekly as arranged by the 
transplant clinic, with results to the transplant clinic (Fax 
___ . CBC, Chem 10, AST, ALT, Alk phos, T Bili, Trough 
Tacro level.
.
*** On the days you have your labs drawn, do not take your 
Tacrolimus until your labs are drawn. Bring your Tacrolimus with 
you so you may take your medication as soon as your labwork has 
been drawn.
.
Follow your medication card, keep it updated with any dosage 
changes, and always bring your card with you to any clinic or 
hospital visits.
.
Continue outpatient dialysis as directed 
(___)
.
You may shower. Allow the water to run over your incision and 
pat area dry. No rubbing, no lotions or powder near the 
incision. You may leave the incision open to the air as it is 
well healed. 
.
Avoid direct sun exposure. Wear protective clothing and a hat, 
and always wear sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher when you go 
outdoors.
.
Check your blood pressure at home. Report consistently elevated 
values above 160 or less than 110 systolic to the transplant 
clinic. Please make an appointment with the cardiologist 
recommended to you, Dr. ___.
.
Check blood sugars and treat as recommended per home scale.
.
Do not increase, decrease, stop or start medications without 
consultation with the transplant clinic at ___. There 
are significant drug interactions with anti-rejection 
medications which must be considered in medication management 
following transplant.
.
Consult transplant binder, and there is always someone on call 
at the transplant clinic with any questions that may arise

his chest pain, and transplant surgery was consulted given his
recent liver transplant.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ female with a PMH of HTN, PMR, anemia, IBS, and anxiety 
presents with hypotension and pre-syncope.  
.  
#. Hypotension/Pre-Syncope: The patient with BP 75/30 in her PCP 
___. Pt has had similar episodes over the last week that only 
occur in the AM. The patient states she has ___ watery BM in the 
morning, then takes HCTZ. Likely patient was volume depleted by 
her diarrhea and exacerbated by her BP med in the AM. These 
episode resolves after lying down and only occurs in the AM. The 
patient states that the episodes correlate with her prednisone 
dosing, unlikely adrenal suppression given patient has only been 
on low dose steriod for short period of time.  The patient was 
volume depleted on admission and in acute renal failure.  She 
received 2L NS in the ED and pressures have improved. There were 
no ECG changes and CE negative x3.  The patient's HCTZ was held 
in the AM and her lisinopril was discontinued over convern for 
renal artery stenosis. The patient remained euvolemic and did 
not have any further episodes during her admission after he HCTZ 
was stopped.  Her BP remained elevated thoughout her admission, 
but near her baseline of 150-160's.  She was not orthostatic, 
but was tested after 2L IVF.  The patient remained asx and was 
discahrged with PCP ___.  
.

currently hypertensive with SBP 166. LVH on ECG. Her BP regimen 
was changed recently due to complaints of dizziness with HCTZ in 
the AM, atenolol at noon and lisinopril in the pm. Her HCTZ was 
stopped as above and her lisinopril was held due to concerns for 
renal artery stenosis.  Her atenolol was increased to 50mg daily 
and continued the noon time dosing given her symptoms usually 
occur in the morning.  The patient has ___ with her PCP 
regarding further titration of her BP meds.

renal artery stenosis given her ARF on lisinopril and HTN. She 
underwent U/S doppler that showed wave forms that could be 
consistent with renal artery stenosis, however recent CT scan of 
her abd w/ contrast showed patent renal arteries.  The patient 
was scheduled for outpatient MRA for further evaluation.  Her 
lisinopril was held and not restarted until the results of her

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old ___ woman with h/o systolic CHF with EF 
40%, CAD with 2-vessel disease, COPD, afib on coumadin 
presenting with SOB likely due to acute CHF exacerbation. Her 
CXR is interesting for a stable left pleural effusion with only 
mild pulmonary vascular congestion. She was diuresed and 
discharged to rehab. 

ACTIVE ISSUES: 
#  CHF exacerbation: the patient presented with SOB and hypoxia 
most likely due to a CHF exacerbation. The trigger for her 
exacerbation was unclear, but she has been admitted from rehab 
facility for CHF exacerbations multiple times in the past year. 
It was possible that d/t agitation and restlessness she had 
hypertensive episodes that caused flash pulmonary edema. Her 
condition was certainly exacerbated by underlying reactive 
airway disease. She received 80 IV lasix in the ED and continued 
to receive IV lasix on a BID basis for fluid overload. Her urine 
output was monitored with a Foley. She required periodic 2 L NC 
for hypoxia, although she was not requiring O2 by day of 
discharge. During this time, her home torsemide was initially 
stopped. It was recontinued on the day prior to discharge at an 
unchanged dose of 80 mg daily. Her other CHF 
medications--amlodipine, metoprolol tartrate, and 
valsartan--were continued. 

# tremor: patient was noted to have tremor/shaking on exam in 
the ED. She had no other focal neurological deficits, although 
this was difficult to interpret in light of her agitated mental 
state. Her daughter reports has happened in the past when she 
gets diuretics (confirmed by discharge summaries). This could be 
due to electrolyte loss but the association between tremor and 
lasix is unclear at the moment. As she continued to receive 
diuretics, she did not develop worsening of the tremor, and it 
in fact improved such that it was gone by hospital day #2 and 
did not recur. 

# UTI: She had a negative UA on admission, although she has h/o 
severe UTI in the past. After day #3 with the Foley in place, 
turbid and foul-smelling urine was noted, prompting a repeat UA 
that showed 12 WBCs and bacteria. She was started on empiric 
5-day course of PO Cipro for UTI, with ucx pending at time of 
discharge. 

#  atrial fibrillation: the patient's home dose of warfarin was 
decreased to 3 on hospital day #1, and continued at this dose 
given supratherapeutic INR, although she missed a dose on ___ 
due to pharmacy withholding the dose for an INR of 4.7. She was 
discharged with a changed dose of 2 mg warfarin daily. She was 
continued on her home dose of metoprolol.  

CHRONIC ISSUES: 

# dementia: patient has h/o dementia and agitated delirium which 
is usual for her in the setting of hospitalizations where she is 
exposed to new people and environments. During her stay, she was 
more agitated for the first couple of days, and at one point was 
throwing things at her nurses. ___ was intermittently agitated, 
and completely dis-oriented to place, time, and location which 
is her known norm. She did not require olanzapine (which in the 
past has not been successful). She was continued on her home 
12.5 mg quetiapine and 25 mg tramadol qhs. Beginning on ___, 
she refused IV access and pulled out her IVs so could not be

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old ___ woman with h/o systolic CHF with EF 
40%, CAD with 2-vessel disease, COPD, afib on coumadin 
presenting with SOB likely due to acute CHF exacerbation. Her 
CXR is interesting for a stable left pleural effusion with only 
mild pulmonary vascular congestion. She was diuresed and 
discharged to rehab. 

ACTIVE ISSUES: 
#  CHF exacerbation: the patient presented with SOB and hypoxia 
most likely due to a CHF exacerbation. The trigger for her 
exacerbation was unclear, but she has been admitted from rehab 
facility for CHF exacerbations multiple times in the past year. 
It was possible that d/t agitation and restlessness she had 
hypertensive episodes that caused flash pulmonary edema. Her 
condition was certainly exacerbated by underlying reactive 
airway disease. She received 80 IV lasix in the ED and continued 
to receive IV lasix on a BID basis for fluid overload. Her urine 
output was monitored with a Foley. She required periodic 2 L NC 
for hypoxia, although she was not requiring O2 by day of 
discharge. During this time, her home torsemide was initially 
stopped. It was recontinued on the day prior to discharge at an 
unchanged dose of 80 mg daily. Her other CHF 
medications--amlodipine, metoprolol tartrate, and 
valsartan--were continued. 

# tremor: patient was noted to have tremor/shaking on exam in 
the ED. She had no other focal neurological deficits, although 
this was difficult to interpret in light of her agitated mental 
state. Her daughter reports has happened in the past when she 
gets diuretics (confirmed by discharge summaries). This could be 
due to electrolyte loss but the association between tremor and 
lasix is unclear at the moment. As she continued to receive 
diuretics, she did not develop worsening of the tremor, and it 
in fact improved such that it was gone by hospital day #2 and 
did not recur. 

# UTI: She had a negative UA on admission, although she has h/o 
severe UTI in the past. After day #3 with the Foley in place, 
turbid and foul-smelling urine was noted, prompting a repeat UA 
that showed 12 WBCs and bacteria. She was started on empiric 
5-day course of PO Cipro for UTI, with ucx pending at time of 
discharge. 

#  atrial fibrillation: the patient's home dose of warfarin was 
decreased to 3 on hospital day #1, and continued at this dose 
given supratherapeutic INR, although she missed a dose on ___ 
due to pharmacy withholding the dose for an INR of 4.7. She was 
discharged with a changed dose of 2 mg warfarin daily. She was 
continued on her home dose of metoprolol.  

CHRONIC ISSUES: 

# dementia: patient has h/o dementia and agitated delirium which 
is usual for her in the setting of hospitalizations where she is 
exposed to new people and environments. During her stay, she was 
more agitated for the first couple of days, and at one point was 
throwing things at her nurses. ___ was intermittently agitated, 
and completely dis-oriented to place, time, and location which 
is her known norm. She did not require olanzapine (which in the 
past has not been successful). She was continued on her home 
12.5 mg quetiapine and 25 mg tramadol qhs. Beginning on ___, 
she refused IV access and pulled out her IVs so could not be 
given IV meds. She had to be persuaded by ___ staff 
to allow the phlebotomist to draw her blood. She had to be 
coaxed to take her PO medications with chocolate ice cream, 
which she enjoys. 

#  CAD: two-vessel disease as seen on cath in ___. She was 
continued on her home 81 mg ASA, metoprolol, atorvastatin 10 mg 
  
#  HTN: she was continued on home metoprolol 50 mg TID, imdur 90 
mg 
 
#  Reactive airway disease: she was given duonebs as needed for 
SOB 

#  CKD: patient's admitting Cr was 1.7, giving her an eGFR of 
24.6. Her outpt nephrologist feels this is most likely a 
combination of microvascular disease from diabetes and 
hypertension with an overlay of cardiorenal syndrome. Her Cr 
remained stable around 1.5 for most of her stay and increased to 
1.8 on day of discharge, felt to ___ ___ UTI. 

***Transitional issues:***

- anticoagulation: Please check INR on ___. Pt is on reduced 
dose of warfarin (2 mg). ___ need to adjust coumadin while on 
abx. 
- torsemide dose: pt will be continued on 80 torsemide daily. 
Discuss any changes to her HF regimen with heart failure clinic. 

- pending labs: please follow up on urine and blood cultures 
from this stay. UPEP is still pending as well. 
- ***DNR/DNI*** during this hospitalization DNR/DNI with 
non-invasive ventilation allowed was confirmed with pt's 
daughter and HCP ___ ___ (see OMR note)

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old ___ woman with h/o systolic CHF with EF 
40%, CAD with 2-vessel disease, COPD, afib on coumadin 
presenting with SOB likely due to acute CHF exacerbation. Her 
CXR is interesting for a stable left pleural effusion with only 
mild pulmonary vascular congestion. She was diuresed and 
discharged to rehab. 

ACTIVE ISSUES: 
#  CHF exacerbation: the patient presented with SOB and hypoxia 
most likely due to a CHF exacerbation. The trigger for her 
exacerbation was unclear, but she has been admitted from rehab 
facility for CHF exacerbations multiple times in the past year. 
It was possible that d/t agitation and restlessness she had 
hypertensive episodes that caused flash pulmonary edema. Her 
condition was certainly exacerbated by underlying reactive 
airway disease. She received 80 IV lasix in the ED and continued 
to receive IV lasix on a BID basis for fluid overload. Her urine 
output was monitored with a Foley. She required periodic 2 L NC 
for hypoxia, although she was not requiring O2 by day of 
discharge. During this time, her home torsemide was initially 
stopped. It was recontinued on the day prior to discharge at an 
unchanged dose of 80 mg daily. Her other CHF 
medications--amlodipine, metoprolol tartrate, and 
valsartan--were continued. 

# tremor: patient was noted to have tremor/shaking on exam in 
the ED. She had no other focal neurological deficits, although 
this was difficult to interpret in light of her agitated mental 
state. Her daughter reports has happened in the past when she 
gets diuretics (confirmed by discharge summaries). This could be 
due to electrolyte loss but the association between tremor and 
lasix is unclear at the moment. As she continued to receive 
diuretics, she did not develop worsening of the tremor, and it 
in fact improved such that it was gone by hospital day #2 and 
did not recur. 

# UTI: She had a negative UA on admission, although she has h/o 
severe UTI in the past. After day #3 with the Foley in place, 
turbid and foul-smelling urine was noted, prompting a repeat UA 
that showed 12 WBCs and bacteria. She was started on empiric 
5-day course of PO Cipro for UTI, with ucx pending at time of 
discharge. 

#  atrial fibrillation: the patient's home dose of warfarin was 
decreased to 3 on hospital day #1, and continued at this dose 
given supratherapeutic INR, although she missed a dose on ___ 
due to pharmacy withholding the dose for an INR of 4.7. She was 
discharged with a changed dose of 2 mg warfarin daily. She was 
continued on her home dose of metoprolol.  

CHRONIC ISSUES: 

# dementia: patient has h/o dementia and agitated delirium which 
is usual for her in the setting of hospitalizations where she is 
exposed to new people and environments. During her stay, she was 
more agitated for the first couple of days, and at one point was 
throwing things at her nurses. ___ was intermittently agitated, 
and completely dis-oriented to place, time, and location which 
is her known norm. She did not require olanzapine (which in the 
past has not been successful). She was continued on her home 
12.5 mg quetiapine and 25 mg tramadol qhs. Beginning on ___, 
she refused IV access and pulled out her IVs so could not be 
given IV meds. She had to be persuaded by ___ staff 
to allow the phlebotomist to draw her blood. She had to be 
coaxed to take her PO medications with chocolate ice cream, 
which she enjoys. 

#  CAD: two-vessel disease as seen on cath in ___. She was 
continued on her home 81 mg ASA, metoprolol, atorvastatin 10 mg 
  
#  HTN: she was continued on home metoprolol 50 mg TID, imdur 90 
mg 
 
#  Reactive airway disease: she was given duonebs as needed for 
SOB 

#  CKD: patient's admitting Cr was 1.7, giving her an eGFR of 
24.6. Her outpt nephrologist feels this is most likely a 
combination of microvascular disease from diabetes and 
hypertension with an overlay of cardiorenal syndrome. Her Cr 
remained stable around 1.5 for most of her stay and increased to 
1.8 on day of discharge, felt to ___ ___ UTI. 

***Transitional issues:***

- anticoagulation: Please check INR on ___. Pt is on reduced 
dose of warfarin (2 mg). ___ need to adjust coumadin while on 
abx. 
- torsemide dose: pt will be continued on 80 torsemide daily. 
Discuss any changes to her HF regimen with heart failure clinic. 

- pending labs: please follow up on urine and blood cultures 
from this stay. UPEP is still pending as well.

daughter and HCP ___ ___ (see OMR note)

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old ___ woman with h/o systolic CHF with EF 
40%, CAD with 2-vessel disease, COPD, afib on coumadin 
presenting with SOB likely due to acute CHF exacerbation. Her 
CXR is interesting for a stable left pleural effusion with only 
mild pulmonary vascular congestion. She was diuresed and 
discharged to rehab. 

ACTIVE ISSUES: 
#  CHF exacerbation: the patient presented with SOB and hypoxia 
most likely due to a CHF exacerbation. The trigger for her 
exacerbation was unclear, but she has been admitted from rehab 
facility for CHF exacerbations multiple times in the past year. 
It was possible that d/t agitation and restlessness she had 
hypertensive episodes that caused flash pulmonary edema. Her 
condition was certainly exacerbated by underlying reactive 
airway disease. She received 80 IV lasix in the ED and continued 
to receive IV lasix on a BID basis for fluid overload. Her urine 
output was monitored with a Foley. She required periodic 2 L NC 
for hypoxia, although she was not requiring O2 by day of 
discharge. During this time, her home torsemide was initially 
stopped. It was recontinued on the day prior to discharge at an 
unchanged dose of 80 mg daily. Her other CHF 
medications--amlodipine, metoprolol tartrate, and 
valsartan--were continued. 

# tremor: patient was noted to have tremor/shaking on exam in 
the ED. She had no other focal neurological deficits, although 
this was difficult to interpret in light of her agitated mental 
state. Her daughter reports has happened in the past when she 
gets diuretics (confirmed by discharge summaries). This could be 
due to electrolyte loss but the association between tremor and 
lasix is unclear at the moment. As she continued to receive 
diuretics, she did not develop worsening of the tremor, and it 
in fact improved such that it was gone by hospital day #2 and 
did not recur. 

# UTI: She had a negative UA on admission, although she has h/o 
severe UTI in the past. After day #3 with the Foley in place, 
turbid and foul-smelling urine was noted, prompting a repeat UA 
that showed 12 WBCs and bacteria. She was started on empiric 
5-day course of PO Cipro for UTI, with ucx pending at time of 
discharge. 

#  atrial fibrillation: the patient's home dose of warfarin was 
decreased to 3 on hospital day #1, and continued at this dose 
given supratherapeutic INR, although she missed a dose on ___

continued on her home dose of metoprolol.

features of acute heart failure or cardiogenic shock, found to 
have STEMI (V2-V4 ST elevations on arrival). Cardiac cath 
revealed total occlusion of mid-LAD as well as chronic total 
occlusion of the mid-RCA and 70% stenosis OM1. DES was deployed 
to culprit LAD lesion and then loaded with ticagrelor. ST 
elevations later spread, involving V5-V6 and inferior leads. 
Required nitro gtt following cath. Started on dual anti-platelet 
therapy with ASA/ticagrelor (90 mg BID). TTE showed EF 28% and 
apical LV thrombus, started on apixaban 5mg BID. Was also

and spironolactone 12.5mg daily.

Presented to the ED in the setting of chest pain, stable without 
features of acute heart failure or cardiogenic shock, found to 
have STEMI (V2-V4 ST elevations on arrival). Cardiac cath 
revealed total occlusion of mid-LAD as well as chronic total 
occlusion of the mid-RCA and 70% stenosis OM1. DES was deployed 
to culprit LAD lesion and then loaded with ticagrelor. ST 
elevations later spread, involving V5-V6 and inferior leads. 
Required nitro gtt following cath. Started on dual anti-platelet 
therapy with ASA/ticagrelor (90 mg BID). TTE showed EF 28% and 
apical LV thrombus, started on apixaban 5mg BID. Was also 
discharged on atorvastatin 80mg, metop XL 100mg, lisinopril 10mg 
and spironolactone 12.5mg daily.

ACUTE ISSUES: 
==============
#STEMI, anterolateral
#reduced EF 28% 
#LV thrombus 
Presented to the ED in the setting of chest pain, stable without 
features of acute heart failure or cardiogenic shock, found to 
have STEMI (V2-V4 ST elevations on arrival). Cardiac cath 
revealed total occlusion of mid-LAD as well as chronic total 
occlusion of the mid-RCA and 70% stenosis OM1. DES was deployed 
to culprit LAD lesion and then loaded with ticagrelor. ST 
elevations later spread, involving V5-V6 and inferior leads. 
Required nitro gtt following cath. Started on dual anti-platelet 
therapy with ASA/ticagrelor (90 mg BID). TTE showed EF 28% and 
apical LV thrombus, started on apixaban 5mg BID. Was also 
discharged on atorvastatin 80mg, metop XL 100mg, lisinopril 10mg 
and spironolactone 12.5mg daily.

worse in the left lower quadrant and left flank pain. She 
underwent a CT scan in the ED which showed acute diverticulitis 
with a microperforation showing a focus of free air, but no sign 
of abscess. She was started on ciprofloxacin and flagyl to cover 
gram negative enterics and anaerobes - she had completed 5 days 
at the time of discharge, and will take 5 more days as an 
outpatient to complete a 10 day total course. Her WBC remained 
within normal range without bandemia. Blood cultures showed no 
growth x 4. Her pain resolved and her diet was advanced without 
difficulty. She was transitioned to PO pain medication and 
antibiotics.
.

was <55 copies. We continued all of her home medications as well 
as her Bactrim prophylaxis. She remained stable throughout 
hospitalization.  She refused HIV medications for 2 days 
secondary to nausea.  The importance of taking these medications 
was stressed.
.

was maintained on IVF throughout hospital stay and electrolytes 
were repleted as needed. When her pain resolved, her diet was 
advanced and tolerated. 
.
#Prophylaxis: She was on heparin SC throughout hospital stay. 
Ambulation was encouraged.

infection. He reported high sugars at home after receiving a 
steroid injection for hip pain three days prior to admission.

.

.

pain or shortness of breath. Continued home ASA, statin, BB, 
___. 
.  
#. Outstanding Labs: None 
.  
#. Transitions of Care:
- Will require insulin titration, as dose was increased during 
hospital stay as discussed above.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
.
You were admitted to the hospital because you were noted to have 
abnormal bloodwork and a high blood sugar during an outpatient 
doctor's visit. When your bloodwork was re-peated in the 
Emergency Room, your labs were found to be within normal limts. 
However, you continued to have a very high blood sugar. It is 
unclear why your blood sugars have been running so high, though 
it is possibly related to the injection you underwent for hip 
pain. Your blood sugars were monitored during your inpatient 
stay, and showed some improvement.
.
We will make a slight increase to your home dosing of insulin 
upon discharge. It will be important for you to check your 
sugars three times daily (morning, 2 hrs post lunch and 2 hrs 
post dinner)over the coming week. You will follow-up with Dr. 
___ in the next few days. If you find that your blood sugars 
are running abnormally high or low, please call Dr. ___ 
___ or return to the Emergency Room.
.
Please make the following CHANGES to your insulin regimen:
INCREASE HUMALOG MIX ___ from 50 units in the morning and 60 
units in the evening to 53 units in the morning and 63 units in 
the evening.
.
Please continue all other medications as they have been 
prescribed.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ or return to the Emergency Room.

History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a very pleasant ___ year old woman who presents to
clinic today as a referral from Dr. ___ surgical evaluation
of her thyroid nodules and multi-nodular goiter. 

In brief, Ms. ___ was initially diagnosed with 
hypothyroidism
in ___ by means of routine blood work and started on
levothyroxine therapy. On exam, the patient was found to have
palpable thyroid nodules and goiter in ___. A follow up
thyroid ultrasound showed a 3.8cm left thyroid nodule and 1.7cm
right thyroid nodule. Subsequent FNA of the LEFT thyroid nodule
was read as benign ("adequate but suboptimal due to
hypocellularity of follicular cells" - ___ II) and the 
RIGHT
thyroid nodule showed atypia of undetermined significance
(___ III).
  
Ms. ___ reports that her goiter has been noticeably
increasing in size over the past six months, causing compressive
symptoms. She states that her voice has changed, growing
increasingly raspy. She also notes that she has difficulty
swallowing, with dryness of her throat and a nagging cough. She
also states she has dry skin, noticeably on her legs. 

Further, she reports increasing fatigue, noting that she never
feels fully rested, even after a full night's rest. This is
likely secondary to her concurrent OSA - after ___uring weekdays, she feels drained the subsequent morning. Even
after 10 hours of rest on the weekends, she still feels
exhausted. She does not tolerate a CPAP machine, stating the it
causes her to choke. She has attempted using a device that
mechanically thrusts the jaw forward to open the airway during
sleep. She naps during the day on her lunch break secondary to
fatigue. 

She also has global body pain, mostly localized to the low back,
hips, and thighs. She has been loosely diagnosed with
fibromyalgia, noting that there has been no other identified
source of her pain. Her weight has been stable (230lb) over the
past ___ years, but noted a 50lb weight gain after simultaneous
smoking cessation and total hysterectomy (___). 

 
Past Medical History:
- thyroid nodules, hypothyroidism
- obstructive sleep apnea, does not tolerate CPAP
- asthma (when sick with concurrent illness, specifically
pneumonia) - has required steroids in past
- type II diabetes mellitus 
- obesity
- hypertension
- hyperlipidemia
- anxiety
- GERD
- hidradenitis suppuritiva
- ?fibromyalgia
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
- Mother: hypothyroidism, h/o thyroidectomy for goiter
- Sister: hypothyroidism and thyroid nodules
- No family h/o thyroid cancer or other endocrinopathies apart
from hypothyroidism
 
Physical Exam:
Upon Discharge:

Gen: Appears well, AAOx3
CV: RRR
Resp: Normal effort, no distress
Abdomen: Soft, nondistended, nontender, no rebound or guarding
Wound: Incision C/D/I without evidence of hematoma
Ext: Warm, well perfused, no edema
 
Pertinent Results:
Please see OMR for pertinent results
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with history of multinodular goiter, now s/p total 
thyroidectomy. She tolerated the procedure well without 
complications (Please see operative note for further details). 
After a brief and uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient was 
transferred to the floor for further post-operative management.

Neuro: Pain was well controlled on Tylenol. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Pulm: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
oxygen saturation was routinely monitored. Had good pulmonary 
toileting, as early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization.
GI: The patient was initially started on a clear liquid diet 
after the procedure. The patient was later advanced to and 
tolerated a regular diet at time of discharge. Patient's intake 
and output were closely monitored
GU: Urine output was monitored as indicated. At time of 
discharge, the patient was voiding without difficulty.
Endocrine: The patient was started on thyroid hormone 
replacement, 150 mcg daily on POD #1. She had no symptoms of 
hypocalcemia. Calcium level was normal. 
ID: The patient was closely monitored for signs and symptoms of 
infection and fever.
Heme: ___ dyne boots were used during this stay and she was 
encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible.  
n POD1, the patient was discharged to home. At discharge, she 
was tolerating a regular diet, voiding, and ambulating 
independently. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Albuterol 0.083% Neb Soln 1 NEB IH Q6H:PRN Cough, wheeze, 
chest tightness 
2. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM 
3. Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY 
4. Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH BID 
5. Gabapentin 300 mg PO QHS:PRN Insomnia 
6. Lantus U-100 Insulin (insulin glargine) 10 units subcutaneous 
QHS 
7. Levothyroxine Sodium 50 mcg PO DAILY 
8. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 
9. MetFORMIN (Glucophage) ___ mg PO DAILY 
10. Montelukast 10 mg PO DAILY 
11. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY

1.  Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO TID 
RX *calcium carbonate 500 mg calcium (1,250 mg) 2 tablet(s) by 
mouth twice a day Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*3 
2.  Levothyroxine Sodium 150 mcg PO DAILY 
RX *levothyroxine 150 mcg 1 tablet(s) by mouth DAILY Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*3 
3.  Albuterol 0.083% Neb Soln 1 NEB IH Q6H:PRN Cough, wheeze, 
chest tightness  
4.  Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM  
5.  Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY  
6.  Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH BID  
7.  Gabapentin 300 mg PO QHS:PRN Insomnia  
8.  Lantus U-100 Insulin (insulin glargine) 10 units 
subcutaneous QHS  
9.  Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY

11.  Montelukast 10 mg PO DAILY  
12.  Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Multinodular goiter

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for observation following your 
surgery. You did well postoperatively and were discharged home 
once you were eating, on oral medications, walking, and 
completing daily activities as normal. 

Medications: 
You were started on thyroid hormone medication, take as 
prescribed. For pain medication you may take acetaminophen 
(Tylenol)as directed for mild pain. 

Your calcium level is normal at discharge and no calcium 
supplement is needed. However, monitor for symptoms of low 
calcium: If you develop tingling or numbness around your mouth 
or fingertips this may be a sign of a low calcium and you should 
call our office. If you develop severe symptoms, please go to 
emergency room.

Wound care:
You may shower normally. Allow warm soapy water to run over the 
wound, rinse and pat dry gently. There is no need to keep a 
dressing over the wound. Do not apply creams or ointments. Do 
not submerge the wound in a swimming pool or bath until cleared 
at your follow up visit. Do not pull off the steri strip 
tapes--these will fall off by themselves over the next ___ 
weeks.

Diet:
You may resume your regular home diet without restriction. You 
should use stick to foods that do not upset your stomach. You 
may need to start with small meals first and may not feel very 
hungry at first. This will improve over time. You may supplement 
your diet with protein shakes as needed if you do not feel you 
are taking in enough nutrition.

Activity:
You may resume all of your normal home activities, except for 
straining or lifting heavy weight. We recommend you resume 
walking, exercise, bathing, per your normal regimen. 

Warning signs:
You should contact our clinic or return to the ED immediately if 
you experience any of the following signs or symptoms:
Fever above 101.5
Worsening pain
Worsening GI upset, nausea/vomiting, diarrhea
Change in the appearance of your incision, or redness, swelling, 
or change in drainage from your incision
Any other symptoms that concern you

You can contact our clinic at any time with questions or 
concerns. You should be seen in our clinic for follow up 
following your discharge from the hospital. 

Best wishes,
Your ___ Care Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for observation following your 
surgery. You did well postoperatively and were discharged home 
once you were eating, on oral medications, walking, and 
completing daily activities as normal. 

Medications: 
You were started on thyroid hormone medication, take as 
prescribed. For pain medication you may take acetaminophen 
(Tylenol)as directed for mild pain. 

Your calcium level is normal at discharge and no calcium 
supplement is needed. However, monitor for symptoms of low 
calcium: If you develop tingling or numbness around your mouth 
or fingertips this may be a sign of a low calcium and you should 
call our office. If you develop severe symptoms, please go to 
emergency room.

Wound care:
You may shower normally. Allow warm soapy water to run over the 
wound, rinse and pat dry gently. There is no need to keep a 
dressing over the wound. Do not apply creams or ointments. Do 
not submerge the wound in a swimming pool or bath until cleared 
at your follow up visit. Do not pull off the steri strip 
tapes--these will fall off by themselves over the next ___ 
weeks.

Diet:
You may resume your regular home diet without restriction. You 
should use stick to foods that do not upset your stomach. You 
may need to start with small meals first and may not feel very 
hungry at first. This will improve over time. You may supplement 
your diet with protein shakes as needed if you do not feel you 
are taking in enough nutrition.

Activity:
You may resume all of your normal home activities, except for 
straining or lifting heavy weight. We recommend you resume 
walking, exercise, bathing, per your normal regimen. 

Warning signs:
You should contact our clinic or return to the ED immediately if 
you experience any of the following signs or symptoms:
Fever above 101.5
Worsening pain
Worsening GI upset, nausea/vomiting, diarrhea
Change in the appearance of your incision, or redness, swelling, 
or change in drainage from your incision
Any other symptoms that concern you

You can contact our clinic at any time with questions or 
concerns. You should be seen in our clinic for follow up 
following your discharge from the hospital. 

Best wishes,
Your ___ Care Team

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN, AS REVIEWED AND DISCUSSED IN 
MULTIDISCIPLINARY ROUNDS  
Patient is a ___ yo female with past hx of CVA (___), DVT, and 
HTN presenting with 2 brief episodes of CP and syncopal event 
found to be in 2nd degree heart block (type II), s/p cath 
showing no significant CAD and s/p successful pacemaker 
placement ___.  
.

catheterization which showed no significant occlusive coronary 
disease.  
.

immediately after her syncopal event which showed new 2nd degree 
heart block (type II). She was given atropine there with 
response. She was monitored on telemetry upon admission with no 
events. Her home dose of Coumadin was held and she was given 5mg 
of po vitamin K. One her INR was less than 2, she was brought 
for pacemaker placement on ___, which was successful. Chest 
X-ray confirmed proper lead placement.
.  
#. Hypertension: Pt's home dose of hydrochlorothiazide was 
continued.
.  
#. Head trauma: The patient underwent repeat CT Head upon 
admission for persistent headache and concern regarding Coumadin 
use at time of fall. She had no evidence of intracranial 
hemorrhage or facial fracture. A plastic surgery consult was 
obtained and steristrips placed over superficial lacteration on 
nasal bridge.
.  
#. She was seen by physical therapy after pacemaker placement 
and felt too unsteady initially. Repeat evaluation the next day 
was much improved and she was able to ambulate with her walker 
without difficulty and she was discharged home.

Patient is a ___ yo female with past hx of CVA (___), DVT, and 
HTN presenting with 2 brief episodes of CP and syncopal event 
found to be in 2nd degree heart block (type II), s/p cath 
showing no significant CAD and s/p successful pacemaker 
placement ___.

catheterization which showed no significant occlusive coronary 
disease.

immediately after her syncopal event which showed new 2nd degree 
heart block (type II). She was given atropine there with 
response. She was monitored on telemetry upon admission with no 
events. Her home dose of Coumadin was held and she was given 5mg 
of po vitamin K. One her INR was less than 2, she was brought 
for pacemaker placement on ___, which was successful. Chest 
X-ray confirmed proper lead placement.
.

continued.
.

admission for persistent headache and concern regarding Coumadin 
use at time of fall. She had no evidence of intracranial 
hemorrhage or facial fracture. A plastic surgery consult was 
obtained and steristrips placed over superficial lacteration on 
nasal bridge.
.

and felt too unsteady initially. Repeat evaluation the next day 
was much improved and she was able to ambulate with her walker 
without difficulty and she was discharged home.

and hit your head. You had a CT of your head which showed no 
sign of bleeding or fracture. Your heart rhythm was found to be 
dangerously slow due to disease of the conducting system of your

.

pain, headache, unsteady gait, nausea, loss of consciousness, or 
if you feel worse in any way, seek immediate medical attention.

monitor was ordered prior to discharge.

In comparison with study of ___, there is little overall 
change.  Cardiac silhouette is within normal limits and there is 
no vascular congestion or pleural effusion.  No acute focal 
pneumonia. 

TTE
Normal biventricular cavity sizes with preserved global and 
regional biventricular systolic function. Mildly dilated aortic 
arch. No cardiac cause of syncope identified.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
HOSPITAL COURSE BY PROBLEM

1. Episodes of altered mental status: Review of ambulatory EEG 
obtained between patient's admissions as well as continuous 
video EEG during this hospitalization again did not reveal clear 
epileptiform activity on preliminary review, although changes 
consistent with his prior TBI were noted. Chest x-ray and 
laboratory testing did not reveal evidence of infection. 
Patient's mental status otherwise improved during the admission 
without intervention. Given ongoing concern for medication 
effect, a Psychiatry consultation was obtained, who recommended 
reducing quetiapine (due to patient's previously noted episodic 
sinus tachycardia), follow-up with outpatient sleep specialist, 
and considering alternatives to benzodiazepines for anxiety 
management. These concerns were also discussed with patient's 
primary care provider, who also expressed concerns regarding 
patient's opioid regimen, from which he was being weaned in the 
period preceding admission.

With respect to cardiac evaluation for syncope, transthoracic 
echocardiogram did not reveal concerning findings, and event 
monitor was ordered prior to discharge.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
1. Follow up event monitoring for possible arrhythmias.
2. Consider switching to a non-benzodiazepine agent for anxiety.
3. Outpatient follow-up with sleep specialist.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for 
evaluation of two episodes of altered mental status. Your mental 
status cleared following admission, and review of your EEG (both 
from before the hospitalization and during) preliminarily did 
not show signs of seizures. Testing did not show signs of an 
infection, and an ultrasound of your heart (echocardiogram) did 
not show signs of severe heart valve disease that could have 
limited blood flow to your brain. You were also fitted with an 
event monitor prior to leaving the hospital to look for 
arrhythmias.

You were also evaluated by the Psychiatry service, who 
recommended decreasing your dose of quetiapine at night and 
talking to your outpatient providers about switching from 
clonazepam to a different medication for your anxiety. An 
appointment was also scheduled with the Sleep Clinic due to your 
sleep issues, which may be contributing to your symptoms.

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___.

Sincerely,
Neurology at ___

uncomplicated. He received continuous bladder irrigation 
overnight. On POD1 the CBI was discontinued and Foley catheter 
was removed with an active vodiding trial.  Post void residuals 
were checked (450/150, 700/30). His urine was clear and and

without assistance, and voiding without difficulty.  He was 
given oral pain medications on discharge along with explicit

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
BPH

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks.
 
-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience 
urgency and frequecy over the next month.
 
-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.  
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.  Max daily 
Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also 
contains Tylenol (acetaminophen)
 
-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics
 
-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.
 
-Resume all of your home medications, except hold NSAID 
(aspirin,  and ibuprofen containing products such as advil & 
motrin,) until you see your urologist in follow-up
 
-Resume all of your home medications, but please avoid 
aspirin/advil for one week.  
 
-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, 
or inability to urinate, call your doctor or go to the nearest 
emergency room. 

resume regular home diet
remember to drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated
remember to take stool softener and avoid constipating foods for 
___ weeks!

Discharge Diagnosis:
BPH

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks.
 
-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience 
urgency and frequecy over the next month.
 
-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.  
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.  Max daily 
Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also 
contains Tylenol (acetaminophen)
 
-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics
 
-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.
 
-Resume all of your home medications, except hold NSAID 
(aspirin,  and ibuprofen containing products such as advil & 
motrin,) until you see your urologist in follow-up
 
-Resume all of your home medications, but please avoid 
aspirin/advil for one week.  
 
-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, 
or inability to urinate, call your doctor or go to the nearest 
emergency room. 

resume regular home diet
remember to drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated
remember to take stool softener and avoid constipating foods for 
___ weeks!
 
-Call Dr. ___ office  ___ 
follow-up AND if you have any questions (page Dr. ___ 
___ at ___.

___

following negative serial cardiac biomarkers for evaluation of

changes. Baseline diasolic hypertension. Blunted HR response to
exercise. Poor functional capacity.

Lung volumes are low but the lungs appear clear.  The 
cardiomediastinal silhouette, hilar contours, and pleural 
surfaces are normal. There is no pleural effusion or 
pneumothorax.
IMPRESSION: 
No acute cardiopulmonary abnormality.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with multiple risk factors for CAD presents with 
intermittent CP during stress test without ECG changes, admitted 
for further workup of ACS. 

# Chest pain - Symptoms have both typical and atypical features. 
No ECG changes, though did not reach 85% predictive heart rate 
and low METS. Moderate treadmill risk score given poor 
functional status and chest pain. Smoking and family history are 
also concerning. Admitted for persantineMIBI  given blunted 
response to exercise ___ but cannot do it on the weekend and as 
patient's chest pain resolved after admission, scheduled an 
appointment for him to get the test on ___ as an 
outpatient.

CHRONIC:
# Hypertension - continued home hydrochlorothiazide.
# Smoking - used to be 2PPD smoker but quit a few months ago, 
now smokes e-cigarettes. Offerred nicotine patch but patient 
said he'd rather see how he does without it. Counseled on 
smoking cessation (including e-cigarettes.)

Transitional Issues:
- No medication changes
- Outpatient pharmMIBI on ___ (they will 
call him ___ morning to make an appointment and he was also 
given the information to call in case there is any problem)

2. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY

Home

Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure to take care of you at ___ 
___. You were admitted to the hospital with chest 
pain. Your electrocardiogram (ECG) and blood work was reassuring 
and showed no evidence of a heart attack. You had a stress test 
which produced chest pain without any findings on the ECG. Your 
chest pain improved. You will need to follow up with a 
cardiologist and have a nuclear stress test performed as an 
outpatient. Please call them on ___ to have both of this 
scheduled.

Sincerely,

Your ___ Cardiology Team

The left parafalcine subdural hemorrhage is slightly larger

is no evidence of infarction or mass. 
  
No osseous abnormalities seen.  Trace mucosal thickening of the 
right 
maxillary sinus, and fluid-filled sphenoid sinuses are

___
Degenerative changes. Likely old fracture of distal radius. 
Acute injury 
either at the level of the elbow joint or wrist cannot be 
excluded on these views, recommend clinical correlation consider 
dedicated elbow and/or wrist radiographs depending on site of 
symptoms. 

___ EKG

ST-T wave 
changes most pronounced in the inferior and anteroseptal leads. 
Compared to

findings are

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was transferred from ___ psych unit after 
a fall. NCHCT reportedly revealed a small SDH. Per report of OSH 
patient also had L radial fx. CT uploaded showed small 
parafalcine hemorrhage.

On ___ Patient was evaluated by ___ and OT who recommend rehab. A 
Repeat NCHCT was stable. A repeat xray of the radius revealed an 
old healed fracture but no acute injury. 

On ___ Patient was neurologically stable pending rehab 
placement. Given 500cc bolus for low urine output and poor PO 
intake.  

On ___, the patient became more agitated, requiring ativan in 
the evening with improvement in her mental status. 

On ___, the patient was alert and oriented to person and place, 
cooperative with exam. Agitation was resolved. 

On ___, the patient had reported foul-smelling urine. was 
otherwise stable. 

0n ___, exam was stable, patient was straight-cathed for

reassuring. Her labs however were notable for hypokalemia (2.8).

repleted 

0n ___: exam was stable, patient continued to have poor PO 
intake, refusing some PO meds. K, Phos repleted. 

On ___ Electrolytes were all normal. She was evaluated by the 
geriactrics service who recommended decreasing remeron dose to 
stimulate appetite, decreased PRN IV ativan, and stopping 
keppra. They have also recommend ___ eval as an 
outpatient. Given patient has recieved a 8 day course of keppra 
this is quite reasonable. RN report concern for a day of loose 
stools. Patient has never been febrile and WBC count has never 
been elevated. Given these things cdiff is very unlikely. 
Patient was offered bed at rehab. She was discharged in stable 
condition with instructions for follow up.

climbing, or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up 
appointment.

·     You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.

·     No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating 
medication. 

·     If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 

·     No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications

·     Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 

·     You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort 
if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:

·     You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, 
and remembering new information.

·     Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. 

·     Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
swings are also common.

·     Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids 
and eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics 
(prescription pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool 
softener.

 

Headaches:

·     Headache is one of the most common symptom after a brain 
bleed. 

·     Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your 
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, 
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a 
headache. 

·     Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches 
but avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless 
prescribed by your doctor. 

·     There are other things that can be done to help with your 
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, 
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. 


When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:

·     Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the 
incision site. 

·     Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit

·     Nausea and/or vomiting

·     Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake

·     Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers

·     Seizures

·     Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak

·     Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or 
leg

 

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:

·     Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg

·     Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding

·     Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination

·     Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

  Grip  Bi  Tri  Delt  IP  Quad  Ham  Gastoc  AT ___
