Exam on Discharge
***
 
Pertinent Results:
___ NCHCT
The left parafalcine subdural hemorrhage is slightly larger 
compared with the immediate prior study with no significant mass 
effect or surrounding edema.  
The subdural hematoma extends inferiorly to the level of the 
tentorium. No additional sites of hemorrhage are identified. The 
ventricles and sulci are normal in size and configuration. There 
is no evidence of infarction or mass. 
  
No osseous abnormalities seen.  Trace mucosal thickening of the 
right 
maxillary sinus, and fluid-filled sphenoid sinuses are 
unchanged. The orbits are unremarkable. 
  
___
Degenerative changes. Likely old fracture of distal radius. 
Acute injury 
either at the level of the elbow joint or wrist cannot be 
excluded on these views, recommend clinical correlation consider 
dedicated elbow and/or wrist radiographs depending on site of 
symptoms. 

___ EKG
Probable sinus tachycardia with baseline artifact. Non-specific 
ST-T wave 
changes most pronounced in the inferior and anteroseptal leads. 
Compared to 
the previous tracing of ___ the heart rate has increased. The 
findings are 
otherwise similar. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was transferred from ___ psych unit after 
a fall. NCHCT reportedly revealed a small SDH. Per report of OSH 
patient also had L radial fx. CT uploaded showed small 
parafalcine hemorrhage.

On ___ Patient was evaluated by ___ and OT who recommend rehab. A 
Repeat NCHCT was stable. A repeat xray of the radius revealed an 
old healed fracture but no acute injury. 

On ___ Patient was neurologically stable pending rehab 
placement. Given 500cc bolus for low urine output and poor PO 
intake.  

On ___, the patient became more agitated, requiring ativan in 
the evening with improvement in her mental status. 

On ___, the patient was alert and oriented to person and place, 
cooperative with exam. Agitation was resolved. 

On ___, the patient had reported foul-smelling urine. was 
otherwise stable. 

0n ___, exam was stable, patient was straight-cathed for 
urinalysis (given ongoing urinary incontinence) which was 
reassuring. Her labs however were notable for hypokalemia (2.8). 
An EKG was performed which was reassuring. Her K, Mg, Phos were 
repleted 

0n ___: exam was stable, patient continued to have poor PO 
intake, refusing some PO meds. K, Phos repleted. 

On ___ Electrolytes were all normal. She was evaluated by the 
geriactrics service who recommended decreasing remeron dose to 
stimulate appetite, decreased PRN IV ativan, and stopping 
keppra. They have also recommend ___ eval as an 
outpatient. Given patient has recieved a 8 day course of keppra 
this is quite reasonable. RN report concern for a day of loose 
stools. Patient has never been febrile and WBC count has never 
been elevated. Given these things cdiff is very unlikely. 
Patient was offered bed at rehab. She was discharged in stable 
condition with instructions for follow up.

seroquel, ativan, remeron, prilosec, sinemet, colace

Subdural hematoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Activity

·     We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, 
climbing, or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up 
appointment.

·     You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.

·     No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating 
medication. 

·     If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 

·     No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications

·     Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 

·     You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort 
if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:

·     You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, 
and remembering new information.

·     Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. 

·     Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
swings are also common.

·     Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids 
and eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics 
(prescription pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool 
softener.

 

Headaches:

·     Headache is one of the most common symptom after a brain 
bleed. 

·     Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your 
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, 
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a 
headache. 

·     Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches 
but avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless 
prescribed by your doctor. 

·     There are other things that can be done to help with your 
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, 
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. 


When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:

·     Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the 
incision site. 

·     Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit

·     Nausea and/or vomiting

·     Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake

·     Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers

·     Seizures

·     Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak

·     Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or 
leg

 

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:

·     Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg

·     Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding

·     Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination

·     Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

services to facilitate your transition to home care of your

and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor

-___ you have been prescribed IBUPROFEN, please note that you may 
take this in addition to the prescribed NARCOTIC pain 
medications ___ tylenol. FIRST, alternate Tylenol 
(acetaminophen) and Ibuprofen for pain control.

-REPLACE the Tylenol with the prescribed narcotic if the 
narcotic is combined with Tylenol (examples include brand names 
___, Tylenol #3 w/ codeine and their generic 
equivalents). ALWAYS discuss your medications (especially when 
using narcotics or new medications) use with the pharmacist when 
you first retrieve your prescription if you have any questions. 
Use the narcotic pain medication for break-through pain that is 
>4 on the pain scale.

-The MAXIMUM dose of Tylenol (ACETAMINOPHEN) is 4 grams (from 
ALL sources) PER DAY and remember that the prescribed narcotic 
pain medication may also contain Tylenol (acetaminophen) so this 
needs to be considered when monitoring your daily dose and 
maximum.

-If you are taking Ibuprofen (Brand names include ___ 
this should always be taken with food. If you develop stomach 
pain or note black stool, stop the Ibuprofen.

-Please do NOT drive, operate dangerous machinery, or consume 
alcohol while taking narcotic pain medications.

-Do NOT drive and until you are cleared to resume such 
activities by your PCP or urologist. You may be a passenger

-Colace may have been prescribed to avoid post surgical 
constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain 
medication. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. 
Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.

-You may shower 2 days after surgery, but do not tub bathe, 
swim, soak, or scrub incision for 2 weeks

-If you had a drain or skin clips (staples) removed from your 
abdomen; bandage strips called “steristrips” have been applied 
to close the wound OR the site was covered with a gauze 
dressing. Allow any steristrips/bandage strips to fall off on 
their own ___ days). PLEASE REMOVE any "gauze" dressings within 
two days of discharge. Steristrips may get wet.

-No heavy lifting for 4 weeks (no more than 10 pounds). Do "not" 
be sedentary. Walk frequently. Light household chores (cooking, 
folding laundry, washing dishes) are generally “ok” but AGAIN, 
avoid straining, pulling, twisting (do NOT vacuum).

activities by your PCP or urologist. You may be a passenger

constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain 
medication. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.

-You may shower 2 days after surgery, but do not tub bathe, 
swim, soak, or scrub incision for 2 weeks

-If you had a drain or skin clips (staples) removed from your 
abdomen; bandage strips called “steristrips” have been applied 
to close the wound OR the site was covered with a gauze 
dressing. Allow any steristrips/bandage strips to fall off on 
their own ___ days). PLEASE REMOVE any "gauze" dressings within 
two days of discharge. Steristrips may get wet.

-No heavy lifting for 4 weeks (no more than 10 pounds). Do "not" 
be sedentary. Walk frequently. Light household chores (cooking, 
folding laundry, washing dishes) are generally “ok” but AGAIN, 
avoid straining, pulling, twisting (do NOT vacuum).

-___ you have been prescribed IBUPROFEN, please note that you may 
take this in addition to the prescribed NARCOTIC pain 
medications ___ tylenol. FIRST, alternate Tylenol 
(acetaminophen) and Ibuprofen for pain control.

-REPLACE the Tylenol with the prescribed narcotic if the 
narcotic is combined with Tylenol (examples include brand names 
___, Tylenol #3 w/ codeine and their generic 
equivalents). ALWAYS discuss your medications (especially when 
using narcotics or new medications) use with the pharmacist when 
you first retrieve your prescription if you have any questions. 
Use the narcotic pain medication for break-through pain that is 
>4 on the pain scale.

-The MAXIMUM dose of Tylenol (ACETAMINOPHEN) is 4 grams (from 
ALL sources) PER DAY and remember that the prescribed narcotic 
pain medication may also contain Tylenol (acetaminophen) so this 
needs to be considered when monitoring your daily dose and 
maximum.

-If you are taking Ibuprofen (Brand names include ___ 
this should always be taken with food. If you develop stomach 
pain or note black stool, stop the Ibuprofen.

-Please do NOT drive, operate dangerous machinery, or consume 
alcohol while taking narcotic pain medications.

-Do NOT drive and until you are cleared to resume such 
activities by your PCP or urologist. You may be a passenger

-Colace may have been prescribed to avoid post surgical 
constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain 
medication. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. 
Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.

-You may shower 2 days after surgery, but do not tub bathe, 
swim, soak, or scrub incision for 2 weeks

-If you had a drain or skin clips (staples) removed from your 
abdomen; bandage strips called “steristrips” have been applied 
to close the wound OR the site was covered with a gauze 
dressing. Allow any steristrips/bandage strips to fall off on 
their own ___ days). PLEASE REMOVE any "gauze" dressings within 
two days of discharge. Steristrips may get wet.

-No heavy lifting for 4 weeks (no more than 10 pounds). Do "not" 
be sedentary. Walk frequently. Light household chores (cooking, 
folding laundry, washing dishes) are generally “ok” but AGAIN, 
avoid straining, pulling, twisting (do NOT vacuum).

Brief Hospital Course:
___ male with metastatic L renal clear cell carcinoma in 
the setting of an atrophic right kidney and chronic renal 
failure, currently on pazopanib and steroids presenting with 
persistent N/V and new retro-orbital mass on NCHCT.

# Metastatic RCC: Tolerating pazopanib fairly well with minimal
nausea at last clinic visit. Pazopanib had been held in ___ in case of infection, as he was having more nausea than 
before and reporting mouth pain. Resumed pazopanib on ___. 
He did not take pazopanib for 4 days PTA given nausea/vomiting. 
He is on 10mg Prednisone daily (for chemo/gout) but had not 
taken his dose for 4 days PTA ___ nausea/vomiting. Pt had CT 
torso w/o contrast on ___ for routine cancer staging (was 
scheduled as outpatient for ___ but performed in-house for pt 
convenience), which showed unchanged small scattered mediastinal 
LNs, no new pulmonary nodules, an indeterminate hyperdense 
exophytic lesion arising from the upper pole of the left kidney 
measuring 16 x 19 mm (previously 12 x 16 mm), known renal cell 
carcinoma arising from the interpolar left kidney that is 
partially exophytic and measuring 26 x 30 mm (previously 26 x 32 
mm), known atrophic right kidney, and stable retroperitoneal 
lymphadenopathy. Pazopanib held during admission and will be 
restarted at rehab. Prednisone 10mg daily continued. Pt may need 
PET as outpatient for staging given known metastatic disease.

# Retro-orbital Lesion on ___:
CT head ___ showed 1.3cm retro-orbital lesion that had been 
present on CT ___ but was much smaller at that time. PERRL, 
EOMI, no pain with eye movements, no double or blurry vision per 
pt, possible inferior visual field defect on exam (but Dr. 
___ Neuro ___ did not appreciate any visual field 
deficits). Suspect that this lesion is most likely a vascular 
structure. Patient was scheduled to follow-up with ophthalmology 
regarding further evaluation of this lesion.  Further imaging 
could be considered including open MRI with contrast, although 
his CKD is borderline for gadolinium contrast. 

# Nausea/vomiting: Resolved and pt tolerating PO by HD2 after 
starting ceftriaxone for suspected UTI. Therefore, 
nausea/vomiting was most likely related to UTI, as pt reports 
nausea/vomiting with prior UTIs. On presentation, pt was not 
endorsing urinary urgency/frequency/dysuria, but UA with large 
___, >182 WBCs, and few bacteria. Urine cx with mixed bacterial 
flora. Cannot rule out that nausea/vomiting is due to viral 
gastroenteritis or side effect of pazopanib (although had not 
taken for 4 days PTA). Unlikely GI/biliary source of 
nausea/vomiting as LFTs and tbili were WNL. Pt discharged with 4 
more days of cipro to complete 7-day course of UTI treatment. 
Pazopanib held throughout admission and per outpatient 
oncologist, Dr. ___ should restart it while at rehab. 
Pt discharged with PRN PO Zofran, PO Compazine, and PO Ativan 
for possible nausea related to pazopanib. Pt instructed to take 
PO Compazine 30 minutes prior to his pazopanib dose to reduce 
risk of nausea, although QTc should be checked prior to 
initiating this regimen, as pt has not required Compazine or 
Zofran in the hospital and will be initiating Cipro to start at 
___. 

# UTI: Has h/o recurrent UTIs. Pt not reporting dysuria, 
frequency, or urgency on admission. UA on admission with large 
___, >182 WBCs, and few bacteria. Urine cx with mixed bacterial 
flora. Initially treated with ceftriaxone, and nausea/vomiting 
resolved. Given improvement in nausea/vomiting symptoms after 
starting UTI treatment, pt discharged with ciprofloxacin for 4 
days to end on ___ for a total of a 7 day course of abx.

# Thrush: Given thrush on examination and poor dentition, 
concern for oropharyngeal candidiasis. Pt should continue 
Nystatin swish and swallow QID PRN.

# Poor Dentition and Mouth/Cheek Pain/Paresthesia: Pt reports 
having L molar extraction in ___ with paresthesia in 
cheek and continued pain in mouth. OMFS consulted. Per their 
exam, no appreciable asymmetric edema in his cheeks. Panorex 
ordered, and per their read no obvious orthodontic infection or 
source of pain/paresthesia. Could not definitively r/o 
metastasis to jaw with x-rays, so consider PET CT as outpatient 
(as above). Started Peridex mouth rinse BID and 
Benadryl/Maalox/Lidocaine mouthwash TID PRN mouth pain. Pt 
should f/u with outpatient dentist for further management of 
poor dentition.

# H/o Fall at Home: Pt with at least two recent mechanical falls 
at home. ___ consult saw him and recommended acute rehab due to 
risk for falls given decreased balance, decreased muscle 
strength, falls history, and pain.  Expect less than 2 week 
duration of stay.   

# Gout: No evidence of recurrence. Continued renally dosed 
allopurinol and prednisone.

# CKD: CKD likely due to RCC on left and atrophic right kidney. 
Cr in-house 2.1 -> 1.9, both of which appear to be about his 
baseline.  

# Hypothyroidism: Levothyroxine continued.

[] Pt should restart pazopanib at rehab.
[] Pt should continue ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID x4 days after 
discharge, QTc should be checked prior to administration of 
Compazine or Zofran after starting cipro
[] Routine surveillance CT C/A/P w/o contrast had been ordered 
to be performed as an outpatient on ___ but was performed as 
an inpatient for pt convenience. Outpatient oncologist should 
f/u the results of the CT C/A/P, and can consider PET CT as 
outpatient for further cancer staging/monitoring. 
[] Outpatient oncologist can consider ordering outpatient open 
MRI head with gadolinium with thin cuts through the orbits to 
further characterize 1.3cm retro-orbital lesion that was seen on 
___ ___.
[] Pt should follow up with oculoplastic orbital specialist on

Benadryl/Maalox/Lidocaine mouthwash TID PRN for mouth pain. Pt 
should follow up with his outpatient dentist for further 
management of his poor dentition.

pt has not required these medications in-house.

management.

vision, unchanged from prior.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is an ___ year-old male who was transferred to ___ from 
an OSH after having being found to have a right 8th rib fracture 
and hemothorax on a non-contrast CT chest s/p fall 3 days prior. 
 He was admitted to the Trauma/Acute Care Surgery service for 
further medical care.  On HD1, the patient had a CT Abd/Pelvis 
to rule out intraabdominal bleeding as simple fluid surrounding 
the liver was demonstrated on imaging.  There was no evidence of 
hemoperitoneum, or other sequelae of acute trauma. It also 
revealed bilateral right greater the left pleural effusions, 
also simple in attenuation. 

The patient was noted to have ecchymosis on the left anterior 
aspect of his LLE, so an x-ray left tibula/fibula was ordered 
which was negative for fracture.  

On HD2, the patient was started on a regular diet, home meds and 
chest physical therapy was provided. On HD3, Physical Therapy 
worked with the patient and recommended discharge to rehab. His 
foley catheter was exchanged for a new catheter.  His eyebrow 
laceration sutures were removed. 

While in the hospital, the patient was alert and oriented pain 
was managed with oral acetaminophen and oxycodone prn. The 
patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital 
signs were routinely monitored. The patient remained stable from 
a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. 
Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry 
were encouraged throughout hospitalization.
Patient's intake and output were closely monitored. The 
patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.The patient's blood counts 
were closely watched for signs of bleeding, of which there were 
none.
The patient's warfarin was initially held for INR of 3.0 and 
concern for hemothorax.  His warfarin was restarted at 0.5 mg on 
___. ___ dyne boots were used during this stay and was 
encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service at ___ 
after suffering an earlier fall and were found to have a 
fracture of your right 8th rib and associated fluid surrounding 
the lung and a blood collection within the lung. While in the 
hospital, you had a repeat chest x-ray which was stable.  You 
additionally had a left lower leg x-ray which was negative for 
fracture. 

You have worked with Physical Therapy and are now medically 
cleared to be discharged to rehab to continue your recovery.  
Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

 
Followup Instructions:

to rule out intraabdominal bleeding as simple fluid surrounding 
the liver was demonstrated on imaging.  There was no evidence of 
hemoperitoneum, or other sequelae of acute trauma. It also 
revealed bilateral right greater the left pleural effusions,

aspect of his LLE, so an x-ray left tibula/fibula was ordered 
which was negative for fracture.

worked with the patient and recommended discharge to rehab. His 
foley catheter was exchanged for a new catheter.  His eyebrow 
laceration sutures were removed.

a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.

agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service at ___ 
after suffering an earlier fall and were found to have a 
fracture of your right 8th rib and associated fluid surrounding 
the lung and a blood collection within the lung. While in the 
hospital, you had a repeat chest x-ray which was stable.  You 
additionally had a left lower leg x-ray which was negative for 
fracture. 

You have worked with Physical Therapy and are now medically 
cleared to be discharged to rehab to continue your recovery.  
Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
___ Diagnosis:
Right 8th rib fracture, b/l pleural effusions, simple fluid 
around liver.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service at ___ 
after suffering an earlier fall and were found to have a 
fracture of your right 8th rib and associated fluid surrounding 
the lung and a blood collection within the lung. While in the 
hospital, you had a repeat chest x-ray which was stable.  You 
additionally had a left lower leg x-ray which was negative for 
fracture. 

You have worked with Physical Therapy and are now medically 
cleared to be discharged to rehab to continue your recovery.  
Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

 
Followup Instructions:
___
question: What was found on the CT ABD/PEL?
answer_text: Small amount of intra-abdominal and intrapelvic fluid is simple in attenuation. No definite evidence of hemoperitoneum, or other sequelae of acute trauma besides right lateral eighth rib fracture.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service for 
chest pain, shortness of breath, and abdominal pain following 
Lupron trigger and oocyte retrieval at ___ IVF on ___.

She originally presented to ___ IVF on ___ AM with chest 
pain and SOB. She was then transferred to ___ for further 
evaluation. She had a CTA that was negative for PE or pleural 
effusions. EKG was within normal limits. D-dimer was 206. CT 
abdomen pelvis showed enlarged ovaries, R 9.5x6cm L 7x5cm, 
numerous large follicles in both ovaries, and moderate ascites 
in the abdomen and pelvis. She was then transferred to ___ ED 
on ___ for further evaluation and admission to the gynecology 
service on ___ for observation and pain control. 

Upon admission to the gynecology service, her pleuritic chest 
pain had resolved. She had ongoing abdominal pain that was 
monitored with serial abdominal exams. Her pain was controlled 
with PO oxycodone. She had intermittent nausea that improved 
with Zofran.   

By hospital day 3, she was tolerating a regular diet without 
nausea or vomiting, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Lupron trigger, otherwise denies

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild/Fever 
do not exceed 4000mg in 24 hours 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours 
Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild 
please take with food 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours Disp 
#*30 Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  Ondansetron ODT ___ mg PO Q8H:PRN Nausea/Vomiting - First 
Line 
RX *ondansetron 4 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) hours 
Disp #*10 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Severe 
do not drink or drive while taking this medication 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours Disp #*10 
Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
chest and abdominal pain following oocyte retrieval, ascites 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service as a transfer for 
chest pain and shortness of breath following your procedure at 
___ IVF on ___. They did an EKG that was normal and did 
imaging that showed no blood clots in your lungs. We did imaging 
of your abdomen and pelvis, which showed some fluid collected in 
your pelvis called ascites. We monitored you in the hospital for 
nausea and pain control. You have recovered well and the team 
believes you are ready to be discharged home. Please call ___ 
IVF office with any questions or concerns. Please follow the 
instructions below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

Constipation:
* Drink ___ liters of water every day.
* Incorporate 20 to 35 grams of fiber into your daily diet to 
maintain normal bowel function. Examples of high fiber foods 
include:
Whole grain breads, Bran cereal, Prune juice, Fresh fruits and 
vegetables, Dried fruits such as dried apricots and prunes, 
Legumes, Nuts/seeds. 
* Take Colace stool softener ___ times daily.
* Use Dulcolax suppository daily as needed.
* Take Miralax laxative powder daily as needed. 
* Stop constipation medications if you are having loose stools 
or diarrhea.

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service as a transfer for 
chest pain and shortness of breath following your procedure at 
___ IVF on ___. They did an EKG that was normal and did 
imaging that showed no blood clots in your lungs. We did imaging 
of your abdomen and pelvis, which showed some fluid collected in 
your pelvis called ascites. We monitored you in the hospital for 
nausea and pain control. You have recovered well and the team 
believes you are ready to be discharged home. Please call ___ 
IVF office with any questions or concerns. Please follow the 
instructions below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

Constipation:
* Drink ___ liters of water every day.
* Incorporate 20 to 35 grams of fiber into your daily diet to 
maintain normal bowel function. Examples of high fiber foods 
include:
Whole grain breads, Bran cereal, Prune juice, Fresh fruits and 
vegetables, Dried fruits such as dried apricots and prunes, 
Legumes, Nuts/seeds. 
* Take Colace stool softener ___ times daily.
* Use Dulcolax suppository daily as needed.
* Take Miralax laxative powder daily as needed. 
* Stop constipation medications if you are having loose stools 
or diarrhea.

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

 
Followup Instructions:

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where 
the patient underwent CABG x 4, AVR (tissue) with Dr. ___. 
See operative note for full details. Overall the patient 
tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was 
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and 
invasive monitoring.  
POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable. Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The 
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further 
recovery. Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued without 
complication. He had a foley reinserted for urinary retention 
and was started on Flomax. He voided successfully after the 
foley was removed for the second time. He had a brief episode of 
atrial fibrillation. Lopressor was increased, Amiodarone bolus 
was given and the patient converted to sinus rhythm. He remained 
in sinus rhythm for the remainder of his hospital course. He was 
evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with 
strength and mobility. By the time of discharge on POD 4 the 
patient was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain 
was controlled with oral analgesics. The patient was discharged 
home with visiting nurse services in good condition with 
appropriate follow up instructions.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where 
the patient underwent CABG x 4, AVR (tissue) with Dr. ___. 
See operative note for full details. Overall the patient 
tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was 
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and 
invasive monitoring.  
POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable. Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The 
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further 
recovery. Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued without 
complication. He had a foley reinserted for urinary retention 
and was started on Flomax. He voided successfully after the 
foley was removed for the second time. He had a brief episode of 
atrial fibrillation. Lopressor was increased, Amiodarone bolus 
was given and the patient converted to sinus rhythm. He remained 
in sinus rhythm for the remainder of his hospital course. He was 
evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with 
strength and mobility. By the time of discharge on POD 4 the 
patient was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain 
was controlled with oral analgesics. The patient was discharged 
home with visiting nurse services in good condition with 
appropriate follow up instructions.

that the patient was staring at a far point and blinking fast,
When he asked him if he is alright, the patient bent and
eventually fell on his right side, with his left elbow flexed on

open, as if he was scared.

and
his tongue was out. He did not develop incontinence or tongue

called EMS, EMS arrived in ___ min and the whole episode lasted

he started fighting with the staff, talking in ___ he is
fluent in ___, answered the questions in ___. then he

without midline shift, he was tx here for further evaluation.
At OSH, received 2mg ativan, keppra, and decadron 8mg.

Currently the patient is drowsy and inattentive, but denied any
pain.
He can not remember what happened to him, also can not remember
if he ever went to work or not.
He is calm and denied headache.
But per his daughter who lives with him, recently he does not 
eat
much, feels full after small portion of food and complains of
abdominal pain after eating.

knowledge, fever, chest pain or rash.

loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia,
lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus or hearing difficulty. Denies

weakness, numbness, parasthesiae. No bowel or bladder
incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with gait.

lobes,R lower temporal and  R cerebellar lobe.

CT Chest w/wo contrast: 
1.  Innumerable pulmonary nodules are identified, with the

Additional multiple nodules are seen throughout the lungs 
bilaterally measuring up to 1.1 cm concerning for diffusely 
metastatic disease. 
2.  Sclerotic lesions within the vertebral bodies and ribs are 
concerning for metastatic lesions.  A bone scan is recommended 
for further evaluation. 

CT abdomen/pelvis w/wo contrast: 
1.  Lesion in the lower pole of the right kidney is of 
intermediate density. A non-urgent ultrasound is recommended for 
further evaluation. 
2.  Innumerable sclerotic foci are seen throughout the vertebral 
bodies and pelvis, concerning for metastatic lesion. 
3.  No other intra-abdominal metastatic lesions are identified. 

MR head w/wo contrast: 1.  Innumerable, predominantly 
hemorrhagic, metastatic lesions throughout both cerebral and 
cerebellar hemispheres and the brainstem, representing 
widespread metastases, as queried clinically. 
2.  The associated susceptibility artifact likely represents 
hemorrhage rather than melanin, as the bulk of the lesions do 
not demonstrate intrinsic hyperintensity on T1-weighted imaging. 

3.  Relatively little associated vasogenic edema, except in 
association with the lesions in the frontal poles and, to a 
lesser extent, the right cerebellar hemisphere, with no 
significant mass effect or central herniation; this pattern is 
sometimes observed with non-small cell carcinoma of the lung, 
though hemorrhage is unusual. 

Bone scan: Multiple foci of tracer uptake within the thoracic 
and lumbar spine, ribs, and left mid femoral shaft consistent 
with metastatic disease.

Patient was admitted after presenting with confusion and altered 
mental status and behavior and having Head CT at OSH showing 
multiple brain lesions concerning for metastatic disease.

showed innumerable, predominantly hemorrhagic, metastatic 
lesions throughout both cerebral and cerebellar hemispheres and 
the brainstem, representing widespread metastases. 
Neuro-oncology was consulted after further studies showed 
pulmonary nodules and bony lesions further suggesting metastatic 
disease. They recommended biopsy of pulmonary nodule.

innumerable pulmonary nodule with the largest in the right upper 
lobe as well as bony lesions in vertebral bodies and ribs. Bone 
scan done and showed multiple foci of tracer uptake within the 
thoracic and lumbar spine, ribs, and left mid femoral shaft 
consistent with metastatic disease. Neuro-oncology consulted and 
recommended biopsy of lung lesion. Radiation Oncology was also 
consulted for possible whole brain radiation. Patient underwent 
lung biopsy by ___ on ___.

no further seizures. You were found on brain MRI to have 
multiple lesions throughout your brain, concerning for cancer. 
On further evaluation and imaging of your body, you were also
